Unfortunately, wget only supports the use of wildcards over ftp, not http. I
believe OSU's OSL does make things available via ftp, so you should be able
to do that.

ftp://slackware.osuosl.org/pub/slackware/slackware-12.0/patches/packages/

[rshepard at salmo ~]$ wget -A.tgz
> http://slackware.osuosl.org/slackare-12.0/patches/packages/
> --06:38:03--<http://slackware.osuosl.org/slackare-12.0/patches/packages/--06:38:03-->
> http://slackware.osuosl.org/slackare-12.0/patches/packages/
>            =>  `index.html'
> Resolving slackware.osuosl.org... 140.211.166.134
> Connecting to slackware.osuosl.org|140.211.166.134|:80... connected.
> HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 404 Not Found
> 06:38:03 ERROR 404: Not Found.
>

I don't know why this doesn't work, but it doesn't work for me either. I've
never gotten multiple-file fetching to work over http. I have always found
some other workaround first, like using ftp, or creating lists of what I
want to get, and getting them 1 at a time via a shell loop. This is a bit
more advanced though, so I would suggest you take the easy ftp out while you
have the chance :)


>   What syntax should I use? Or, is there a better tool than wget for this
> task?
>

Some may advocate curl, but I am not particularly familiar with that tool.
It may be worth a glance at the man page to see if it will do what you want.
I'm sure it might come in handy some day either way.


> Rich

> eventually. I believe the OP mentioned that the purpose for creating the
> local repository was for longevity, which OSU does not provide.

The mirror at Portland State, fedora.cat.pdx.edu (rsync, ftp, http),
does not seem to expire anything that is not expired on the master server.

For older Fedora stuff the master server is archives.fedoraproject.org.
(http, rsync). I've not found a local mirror for this one.

If you want to go way back in time to the pre-Fedora Red Hat releases
they can be found on archive.download.redhat.com. (http, ftp)

For the defunct fedoralegacy project there's a mirror on UofO's server,
limestone.uoregon.edu (http, ftp, rsync). Fedora Legacy had post-EOL
updates for Red Hat 8.0 through Fedora Core 6. 

Terry

On Thu, Nov 27, 2008 at 16:13, wes <plug at the-wes.com> wrote:
> Is there a way to get bind to log the results of its queries?

I've never used the logging directive to named.conf, but i have used
the 'trace' command to rndc to log queries, responses, and everything
else under the sun:

rndc trace
find /var -name named.run

i've not experimented with getting trace output to syslogd--i
basically never want that (and my logserver is overloaded enough
anyway).

This works in vim...

Position the cursor on the offending character and do:

:ascii

to find out its decimal/hex/octal values. Use the decimal value as
follows...

:%s/[<C-V>decimal_value]/replacement_value/g

...where <C-V> is a Ctrl-V. In the example you provided, ...

:%s/[<C-V>146]/'/g

I've not tested this with vanilla vi.

Sandy

From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Dec  1 13:28:40 2008
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 1 Dec 2008 13:28:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] stupid circumflex a from M$ Word cut-and-paste into vi
In-Reply-To: <b11ea23c0812011238j581ac652s98ecdea74121c141@mail.gmail.com>
References: <b11ea23c0812011238j581ac652s98ecdea74121c141@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20081201132840.742669b7.johnxj@comcast.net>

On Mon, 1 Dec 2008 12:38:11 -0800
"Webb Sprague" <webb.sprague at gmail.com> dijo:

> (I am working in Portland today, so you are the LUG list of choice :) )
> 
> When I cut and paste text from Word into vi, I get gremlin characters,
> especially with quotes; the single quote gives me a "circumflex-a"
> like in "region?s" which should be "region's".
> 
> How can I substitute all of these with 's///g'?  I can't figure out
> how to ctrl-v it or anything.  Googling "circumflex a vi" just gives
> me a bunch of junk.

Sounds like a codepage problem. 

Windows defaults to 8859-X, where X reflects the country. MacOSX
defaults to UTF-16. All Linux machines in my experience default to
UTF-8. 

If your Linux box has OpenOffice.org, KOffice, or Abiword, I recommend
opening (not pasting) in one them as an alternate step. In my
experience their Word import filters are clever enough to recognize the
codepage of the original document and adjust it as necessary. 

I'd also try just pasting into one of the word processor programs, but
use Paste Special (usually Ctrl-Shift-v instead of just Ctrl-v). 

I know zero about vi, but if it has a paste special option, that would
be my first attempt, using the word processor programs as
intermediaries only if necessary.

Others have explained the issue. I would like to suggest one other
workaround: paste into notepad on your windows machine first, then copy
again and paste into vi. This should remove any "special" formatting or
characters in the copied block.

-wes

   In versions of Slackware through 12.0 the psmouse module was blacklisted
and not loaded, yet the ps/2 protocol was used in /etc/X11/xorg.conf and the
trackpad worked when X was running.

   Now that I've upgraded to 12.1 I no longer have a cursor that moves in X.
The module, psmouse, is no longer automatically blacklisted. I've futzed
(i.e., trial-and-error) with /etc/modprobe.d/psmouse and the xorg.conf file
but cannot get the cursor to move. No one's responded to my post on
linuxquestions.org (although quite a few have looked at it, tut-tutted, and
moved on).

   If anyone has an idea how to get the mouse working again, please share it
with me.

References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812011533370.24093@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <c834ec80812011619u4c3c77b8o809caf2258a707e1@mail.gmail.com>

On Mon, Dec 1, 2008 at 3:43 PM, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>   In versions of Slackware through 12.0 the psmouse module was blacklisted
> and not loaded, yet the ps/2 protocol was used in /etc/X11/xorg.conf and the
> trackpad worked when X was running.
>
>   Now that I've upgraded to 12.1 I no longer have a cursor that moves in X.
> The module, psmouse, is no longer automatically blacklisted. I've futzed
> (i.e., trial-and-error) with /etc/modprobe.d/psmouse and the xorg.conf file

Is this a device issue, or a protocol issue?  If the former, you can
test more easily than restarting X by catting the device (as root) and
wiggling the mouse.  You should see a bunch of garbage show up on
screen.

If the latter, then I'd suggest trying ImPS/2. That's been the "just
works" mouse driver on all my machines since.... 2000?

eg:

Section "InputDevice"
        Identifier      "Configured Mouse"
        Driver          "mouse"
        Option          "CorePointer"
        Option          "Device"                "/dev/input/mice"
        Option          "Protocol"              "ImPS/2"
        Option          "Emulate3Buttons"       "true"
EndSection

Here's the section for my touchpad, just in case that helps:

Section "InputDevice"
        Identifier      "Synaptics Touchpad"
        Driver          "synaptics"
        Option          "SendCoreEvents"        "true"
        Option          "Device"                "/dev/psaux"
        Option          "Protocol"              "auto-dev"
        Option          "HorizScrollDelta"      "0"
EndSection


--Rogan

From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 1 Dec 2008 16:36:36 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Notebook Touch Pad Protocols
In-Reply-To: <c834ec80812011619u4c3c77b8o809caf2258a707e1@mail.gmail.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812011533370.24093@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<c834ec80812011619u4c3c77b8o809caf2258a707e1@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812011630470.24093@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 1 Dec 2008, Rogan Creswick wrote:

> Is this a device issue, or a protocol issue?  If the former, you can test
> more easily than restarting X by catting the device (as root) and wiggling
> the mouse.  You should see a bunch of garbage show up on screen.

Rogan,

   Well, that certainly trashes the console display. :-) After the garbage
displayed as I moved my hand across the screen, the text was no longer
readable.

> If the latter, then I'd suggest trying ImPS/2. That's been the "just
> works" mouse driver on all my machines since.... 2000?

   I think it's protocol. The touchpad (and USB mouse) work on the console,
but not when X is running. Here are the appropriate sections of xorg.conf:

Section "InputDevice"
    Identifier "Mouse0"
    Driver "mouse"
    Option "Protocol" "IMPS/2"
    Option "Device" "/dev/psaux"
    Option "Emulate3Buttons"
    Option "Emulate3Timeout" "50"
    Option "AlwaysCore"
    Option "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
EndSection

Section "InputDevice"
    Identifier "USBMouse0"
    Driver "mouse"
    Option "Protocol" "IMPS/2"
    Option "Device" "/dev/input/mice"
    Option "AlwaysCore"
    Option "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
    Option "Emulate3Buttons"
    Option "Emulate3Timeout" "50"
    #Option "Buttons" "5"
EndSection

Thanks,

Rich

From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 1 Dec 2008 16:45:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Bluetooth keyboard recommendation?
In-Reply-To: <20081201222319.GA22056@onyx.spiritone.com>
References: <20081201222319.GA22056@onyx.spiritone.com>
Message-ID: <20081201164516.f6ca2ef5.johnxj@comcast.net>

On Mon, 1 Dec 2008 14:23:20 -0800
Eric House <eehouse at eehouse.org> dijo:

> I'm thinking of getting a bluetooth keyboard (and mouse, ideally).
> Anybody using one with Linux and *very* happy with it?

Yes and no.

I have a bluetooth mouse (Razer) and I love it. I use it with my laptop
(Hardy, x86_64). However, about two or three times a week it just quits
working randomly. I have never figured out the trigger. There is
nothing in any log files that I can find. Luckily the laptop is a
Thinkpad which has both a touchpad and a trackpoint. I disabled the
touchpad in the BIOS, but I left the trackpoint working because it is
not really annoying. So when the mouse quits I can just open a terminal
and reconnect -  "sudo hidd --connect 00:0F:F6:6C:6C:DB." Having to
reconnect is worth it because the USB mice I used to use all require a
receiver sticking out of the laptop.

I tried the Intrepid live CD and noted that the bluetooth GUI is
changed. Maybe the code underneath is also. I'm hoping that after I
upgrade my laptop to Intrepid the random disconnects will disappear.
But that has to wait until finals are over.

I have never tried a bluetooth keyboard, but I have read a number of
posts about them on the Ubuntu forums and elsewhere. The big problem is
that they don't work until the OS is loaded. Therefore, you can't use
them if you need to deal with the BIOS, or even edit your Grub boot
options on the fly.

I discovered after upgrading my desktop to Intrepid that the mouse and
keyboard had been moved to HAL and all the entries in the xorg.conf
file had been #-ed out. If yours are now #-ed out you'll have to
configure the mouse elsewhere (but I can't remember where it was).

   Well, the plot thickens (or sickens, depending on one's point of view).
There are three definitions of the LJ5 in /etc/cups/printers.conf: laser5
(generic), laser5_single (simplex printing), and the default laser5_duplex.
Trying to print with either of the latter two fails; lpstat shows a failed
socket.

   _However_, if I print using -Plaser5 (the generic definition), it works!
It works both from the command line ('lpr -P laser5 -l <filename>.ps') and
from within xpdf if I change the printer definition.

   Here's the current /etc/cups/printers.conf (after I hand edited it to
change the stopped state to idle and removed the messages:

Subject: [PLUG] HPLIP Issue? -- FIXED!!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812011828430.24093@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 1 Dec 2008, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Can anyone enlighten me on what seems to be inexplicable?

   Regardless of enlightenment, I fixed this issue by a very round-about way.

   Since Apple took over CUPS from EasySoftware Products (who apparently
floated to the surface on their back), the web-based admin page is rather
difficult to access. Trying http://localhost:631 doesn't work for me. But,
opening one of the doc pages and using that to navigate to
http://localhost:631/admin does work.

   Under 'manage printers' I cancelled all stuck jobs for laser5_duplex and
laser5_single. Then I used the page button to start each printer and printed
a test page. Starting the printer from the BUI removed the failed socket
message.

   A final test printed a page from within xpdf. It worked.

   So, this makes two down (both with the -11.0 to -12.0 upgrade on my
server/workstation) and one to go (the stuck cursor on my notebook running
-12.1).

   Great insight and ideas on how to fix xorg.conf or otherwise get the
touchpad or external mouse to work on the notebook continues to be
encouraged.

Thanks all!

Rich

wes wrote:
> Others have explained the issue. I would like to suggest one other
> workaround: paste into notepad on your windows machine first, then copy
> again and paste into vi. This should remove any "special" formatting or
> characters in the copied block.

Apostrophes are weird though. Word uses a slanted -> ? <- version, and 
this doesn't cross over well onto a *nix system. I end up having to 
search/replace them before pasting.

-- 
- m0gely

On Mon, 1 Dec 2008 17:01:31 -0800 (PST)
Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> dijo:

> On Mon, 1 Dec 2008, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> 
> > Maybe you've already done this, but look again in your xorg.conf file. I
> > discovered after upgrading my desktop to Intrepid that the mouse and
> > keyboard had been moved to HAL and all the entries in the xorg.conf file
> > had been #-ed out. If yours are now #-ed out you'll have to configure the
> > mouse elsewhere (but I can't remember where it was).

>    No, they're not commented out, but I can always give that a try. The
> README files tell me to build a new xorg.conf but provide no guidance on
> what to include/exclude.

OK, one other thing just occurred to me, although it is unlikely to be
the source of your problem, but it's a straw to grasp anyway.

After I upgraded my Hardy desktop computer to Intrepid the mouse and
keyboard both failed completely. Nada. After much futzing around, by
sheer coincidence, I discovered that I was running kernel 2.6.24-19.
That's the Hardy kernel. Yeah, the update had hopelessly hosed Grub and
I was booting to Intrepid all right, but with the Hardy kernel. Running
all the Intrepid drivers and stuff on the Hardy kernel is not a good
plan. 

So just to eliminate the possibility, do a "uname -a" to verify that
your kernel is what you think it is.

As for rebuilding xorg.config, there is a command (can't remember it,
but it has "phigh" in it) that will do that automagically for you.
Theoretically, anyway.

Quoting someone <plug_1 at robinson-west.com>:


> My goal is to update a local yum updates repository via rsync for CentOS 5.2,
> Fedora 9, and Fedora 10.

I think you'll find yourself spending a lot of time chasing  
dependencies if you try to mix RPMs from CentOS 5.2, Fedora 9 and  
Fedora 10 on one system. I'd recommend choosing *one* of the three,  
depending on the mission of the system, and sticking with it and not  
mixing in software from other sources without a compelling reason to  
do so.

Your first problem:
http://fedora.cat.pdx.edu/fedora-enchilada/linux/updates/9/i386/

404 Not Found
________________________________
nginx/0.6.32

You might want to change your URL.  The updates are here:
http://fedora.cat.pdx.edu/linux/updates/9/i386.newkey/

and the Everything repo is here:
http://fedora.cat.pdx.edu/linux/releases/9/Everything/i386/os/Packages/

For one thing the Fedora system did have a compromise, but it was not
totally "hacked".  No packages were effected, but as a precautionary
measure they created new signing keys for all packages for Fedora 8
and 9.
This did not affect Fedora 10 (new keys were already in place before release).
All updates for Fedora 9 should pull from the [arch].newkey repos.

Details here:
https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Enabling_new_signing_key

This has been all over the Fedora mailing lists, and on the website
for some time now.
Main intrusion announcement:
https://www.redhat.com/archives/fedora-announce-list/2008-August/msg00012.html

Also, +1 on not mixing repos for different versions of the same OS,
let alone different OSes.
Pick a version and stick with it.

----------
Matt M.
LinuxKnight

I've always had pretty good luck getting a system on the air with

# X -configure

which makes "~root/xorg.conf.new" from looking at the hardware and
software. If it had trouble, there will be copious information in
"/var/log/Xorg.0.log". The only things I've had to change in the result
file are that sometimes it can't find the mouse and it usually does not
create a "Modes" line to define the screen sizes.

I did have some laptop touchpad problems recently that might be relevant
here. I am now running openSUSE 11.1 RC1 (2.6.27) on the laptop, but
this also happened with 11.0 (2.6.25). I installed WindowMaker and
brought it up. It worked fine, but when I switched back to Gnome, it
would boot up, see the touchpad for a while, and then the pointer would
freeze wherever it happened to be. The openSUSE "sax2" X configuration
utility would find it and generate a new Xorg.conf correctly, but once I
went back to the desktop, it would freeze again.

There were some messages in Xorg.log.0 saying that it had disabled the
touchpad, although no reason was given. It turned out that if I just did
"X -configure" and used that file, it treated the touchpad as "an
ordinary mouse" and it started working again, so that's how I ran
things. I'm a bit short of troubleshooting time right now, but I plan to
go back to it late next week.

Speaking of openSUSE 11.1, the release is December 18th. I ended up
loading openSUSE 11.1 RC1 on my AMD64 box over the holiday -- I finally
gave up on Gentoo, in particular trying to get a working Gnome 2.24
desktop. I've been running openSUSE on the laptop since 11.0 was released.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Dec  2 08:39:45 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 2 Dec 2008 08:39:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] remote support tool for firewalled clients
In-Reply-To: <b399d1c10811281256saa30524pd6a0f07f0497b668@mail.gmail.com>
References: <200811281231.55495.scratchcomputing@gmail.com>
	<b399d1c10811281256saa30524pd6a0f07f0497b668@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20081202163945.GA2448@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Fri, Nov 28, 2008 at 12:56:05PM -0800, wes wrote:

> This all assumes you don't have access to the firewall. If you did, you
> could configure it to forward port 22 to the linux box, then use ssh port
> forwarding to connect to the machines inside from there.

I am currently playing with an ALIX Single Board Computer that will
become my firewall.   A box like this (or as simple as a Linux
reprogrammable router or access point) can be set up to drive an
outbound VPN from the client's LAN to your own site, bypassing the
clien'ts firewall and the ISP's blocked ports.  All the client
would have to do is power the box and plug it into their network. 
The box would reach out to you and provide a tunnel to reach all the
machines on the client's LAN, without reprogramming their firewall.

If the box was two-port, it could sit in between the client's
network and the firewall, and watch traffic as well.  

The ALIX box with trimmings is about $180, and is perhaps overkill
for this task.  You can probably find new WRT54GL access points
for $50, and used ones cheaper.  There are a few dozen models of
wireless access point that can run OpenWRT Linux, and perhaps some
cheaper hardware without the radio (see the openwrt.org site).

I thought about making bootable USB thumb drives that would do this,
but those would depend too much on the hardware they are plugged into.

Keith

From facetcounter at gmail.com  Tue Dec  2 10:23:02 2008
From: facetcounter at gmail.com (Nathan Young)
Date: Tue, 2 Dec 2008 10:23:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] problem getting wake on lan from suspend in ubuntu
Message-ID: <6b2e08160812021023k6be5a09ey8e695c555842cd89@mail.gmail.com>

Hi.

I have an in depth problem statement that I'll go into below but let me
describe my overall goal in case there's a better way of going about it.

I have a home server that I want to leave on but I need it to spin down disk
and fans when not in use.  This is a system that some days will get a four
hour block of use, while some weekends it will get no use at all.

I've been chasing a combination of shutdown with no activity (as configured
from the ubuntu gui) and wake on lan (wol) using a magic packet.  An end
state where I wake it up with a magic packet when I need to use it and then
it sleeps when it has 20 minutes (or whatever) of inactivity would be great.

So far I can get it to wake on lan from a powered off state if I do the
following:

a) use ethtool to turn on wake on lan 'ethtool -s eth0 wol g'
b) shutdown from the command line 'sudo shutdown -h now'
c) send a magic packet from another machine on the network

If I shutdown from the GUI or sleep from the GUI I cannot wol.

If I sleep using 'acpitool -s' it goes into a sleep that I can wol from, but
when it does come back my video is garbled and the system is unresponsive.

I have tried enabling entries in /proc/acpi/wakeup but it didn't seem to
make a difference so I abondonded that path.

Here is my speculation about what's going on but please take it with a grain
of salt.

I know that sleep and resume scripts match up a set of things to turn
off/store away on the way out with a set of things to turn on/enable/restore
on the way back.  I think that the shutdown and sleep scripts from the GUI
are disabling my network interface and so wol is not finding purchase.  I've
found a shutdown method that does not shut down the nic which is why I can
wol later in that case.  I've found a sleep script that also does not
disable the nic, but at the same time it does not leave the system in a
state of sanity that the resume scripts can rebuild into a working session.

Does anyone have hints, help or other info? Thanks in advance!

------------>Nathan

My preferred Windows text editor (aside from Vim) is notepad++. It
handles the conversion without trouble. So does plain ol' notepad.

It's really not necessary to take this extra step, though - reference my
earlier follow-up on how to do this directly in vim. One more
interesting point - I just tested this with /bin/vi (not vim), and the
paste into vi translates the "smart" quote into a normal one, obviating
the need for further remedies.

RT has its foibles like anything else, but in the realm of OSS ticketing
systems its the top of a very shabby group. Stuff like bugzilla and trac are
geared toward software development and use a bunch of jargon that can be
very confusing to end users. RT's function of replying to emails
automatically updating tickets is probably the biggest selling point imo.

From facetcounter at gmail.com  Tue Dec  2 14:51:01 2008
From: facetcounter at gmail.com (Nathan Young)
Date: Tue, 2 Dec 2008 14:51:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] problem getting wake on lan from suspend in ubuntu
In-Reply-To: <alpine.OSX.2.00.0812021046090.3507@guild.galois.com>
References: <6b2e08160812021023k6be5a09ey8e695c555842cd89@mail.gmail.com>
	<alpine.OSX.2.00.0812021046090.3507@guild.galois.com>
Message-ID: <6b2e08160812021451m2c4f992bv4c34176cc7435226@mail.gmail.com>

Oh thanks.

I will go on a short rant now:

My experience in phrasing questions comes purely from other mailing lists...
the perl list in the late 90s, XML and XSL lists in the early 00's, jquery
lists a year and a half ago... In each case the absolute best and brightest
with the technology swamped with endless waves of newcomers asking the same
questions as the last wave.  It was probably the 10th time I heard someone
saying "XML has a bug where ampersands don't work right"
that I realized "wow these self organizing groups have a weak spot but it's
not anything to do with the technology, there are ciritcal social skills
that carry over fine from one technology to another" of course not that
eloquently.

Then reading ESR's "how to ask a question" paper made perfect sense and gave
me vocab for it (and also something resonably impersonal but also slightly
obnoxious to forward on to egregious cases):

http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

All in all I learned two things:
 - don't go into tech support
 - if you want a smart answer, ask your dumb question as smart as you can

-------->N

From creswick at gmail.com  Tue Dec  2 21:06:14 2008
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue, 2 Dec 2008 21:06:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] The ridiculous Karla project...
In-Reply-To: <1228278392.13899.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1228278392.13899.4.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <c834ec80812022106s3045c95bmbcb9099b5b39aa2f@mail.gmail.com>

On Tue, Dec 2, 2008 at 8:26 PM, robinson-west user
<plug_1 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
> Well, so far on the road to converting C++ code to Java using Java I
> have discovered StringTokenizer which gives me the words on each

First off, StringTokenizer has been largely obviated by
String.split(...).  It's generally easier to use split than the
tokenizer.  However, *neither* of those is sufficiently complex to
properly tokenize c++.

The general approach is to use a Lexer which encompasses some sort of
tokenizer that will break the input into tokens according to the
tokenization rules of the language you are parsing, and does some
syntactic analysis of the code.  Any book on compilers that's worth
it's salt will go into great detail about how to build a Lexer, and
the wikipedia page on Lexical analysis is not a shabby place to start.
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexical_analysis

You *might* be able to hack something together with Java's
*Stream*Tokenizer (note the difference from *string* tokenizer), and
it might even work for the cases you need to address.

--Rogan

From john_re at fastmail.us  Wed Dec  3 04:04:27 2008
From: john_re at fastmail.us (john_re)

Subject: [PLUG] BerkeleyTIP Great progress VOIP November - Dec 6 = Improve
	VOIP
Message-ID: <1228305867.13559.1288014345@webmail.messagingengine.com>

We made GREAT progress with the November 1 meeting! :)  I really can't
believe how happy I am about it, & how far we advanced.

We went from in September having no online attendees,
to in October having 1 person remote on IRC, to in
November having 7 people around the US all in a VOIP conference!  It was
_fantastic_!  I was very impressed.  

I'm especially impressed with our online members, who basically took the
info I had in the VOIP data page, & found a conference #, set up a
conference, & got logged in, all while I was taking a short break!  :)

Besides two of us on VOIP in Berkeley, we had Oakland, San Fran, San
Jose, Washington state, & North Carolina.  Plus we had at least two
other person on IRC who didn't have time to get on VOIP.

It was so very enjoyable talking & listening to the guy in North
Carolina - he had a _very_ strong southern accent, & I _rarely_ get to
talk with someone with that accent.  It was so fun knowing I was
listening to someone who was _unmistakeably_ _not_ from the BayArea!

We had a UCB student join us on IRC from one of the dorms - he'd seen
the announcement I sent on the UCB SciPy list.

This is all doubly exciting, because I _still_ didn't even get the
announcements out until less than 24 hours before hand. Think how many
more people might see the announcement in time to join us if I get it
out 1 or two weeks ahead of time!

Good progress is me getting _this_ announcement out about 3 weeks
before the meeting to the BTIP groups.  My goal is to get announcements
to the "outside" mailing lists both this coming weekend (2 weeks) & the
following weekend (1 week ahead).  This will allow many more people to
schedule the December 6 meeting into their schedules.  :)

===================
December 6 Progress Opportunities:

Some things I might be doing:
Getting announcements out for the first (or first advanced) time to
Debian, GNU, FreeBSD, KDE, & maybe Ubuntu, Ekiga & Asterisk & 10
California LUG lists.

Based on discussion that we didn't have a way to see a list of who was
in the VOIP conference room, like in an IRC client, that is a possible
target for the December Programming party.  Maybe we can make some web
ap that can do that?  Or, some Python program which is like a IRC client
for VOIP conference rooms?  Perhaps we can modify the Ekiga sw?

Also, I'll try to notify the Ekiga & Asterisk people about this, in case
they'd like to help out.

Discussion might be about K-Ubuntu 8.10.

There's a new video from Christine Peterson about Open Source
Environment Sensing.  If you know of any new FSW videos, please email me
or the list so I can put them on the BTIPG video page.

Any comments or questions?      Hope to see you in person in Berkeley,
or VOIP conference with you all on Sat Dec 6.  :)

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Dec  3 06:54:40 2008
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 03 Dec 2008 06:54:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] browser dinosaur cries for help!
Message-ID: <86k5ahpavj.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>


I am a habitual user of Mozilla's original product, what is now called
SeaMonkey.  It is packaged by Debian as something (for trademark
reasons) called IceApe.  It is the old browser/email/composer/
chatzilla application suite, although for all practical purposes I am
only using the browser component.  I use it because it always worked,
and because everytime I tried Firefox I discovered that Firefox (at
least in its base configuration) lacked the features I had come to
expect, and was unable to easily discover how to replicate them by
using the myriad plugins.  For a long while now (gee, Firefox was
first released in 2002, so like 6 years) I've been able to blithely
carry on about my business.  However, increasingly websites are
breaking on SeaMonkey, while operating on Firefox.  Convincing people
to fix their websites for my increasingly fossilized browser may prove
unfruitful, and anyway, untimely.

So in order to join the 21st century, I am looking for help in
replicating what I see as the useful features of SeaMonkey in modern
Firefox, presumably by finding suitable plugins adrift amongst the sea
of those available.  The Useful Features(tm) are all found in the
SeaMonkey Tools menu:

  Cookie Manager
    Block cookies from this site
    Use default cookie permissions
    Allow session cookies from this site
    Allow cookies from this site
    Manage stored cookies
  Image Manager
    Block images from this site
    Use default permissions
    Allow images from this site
    Manage image permissions
  Popup Manager
    Allow popups from this site
    Manage popups
  Password Manager
    Logout
    Manage passwords

I kinda want all of those conveniently available, not too many clicks
away.  Suggestions?


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

Well ... up until last week I had both 32-bit and 64-bit versions of
both Firefox and Seamonkey happily co-existing on my machine, and as far
as I know, the only thing Seamonkey *didn't* do was RSS feeds. But
you're right -- I don't think Seamonkey is being *enhanced*, just
maintained.

Maybe you don't get this with IceWeasel, but the standard Firefox has a
place in the Tools menu where you can go "shopping" for plug-ins. By the
way -- you can run the standard branded Firefox on Debian, and you can
build it from source. You just can't re-distribute it. IceWeasel is a
Debian religious gimmick. What does Debian call Thunderbird? IceChicken?
Wait ... I remember ... IceDove. BAH!

    This has all the info that you are looking for with maybe the exception of
Use default cookie permissions

>  Image Manager
>    Block images from this site
>    Use default permissions
>    Allow images from this site
>    Manage image permissions
Menu->Edit->Preferences->Content

>  Popup Manager
>    Allow popups from this site
>    Manage popups
Menu->Edit->Preferences->Content

>  Password Manager
>    Logout
>    Manage passwords
Menu->Edit->Preferences->Security (Password Section)

Do not all great movements degrade into a racket?

This is what Debian policies try to prevent, and have done well so far.
The Debian folks merely try to preserve what is core to open source:
the ability to freely distribute software without restriction.

It is unfortunate the Mozilla Foundation and Mozilla Corporation do not
have similar policies.  They have already started down the path to a
racket.

I don't think seamonkey is so very far out of date.  This whole
browser incompatibility thing has gotten out of hand.  Perhaps the
real answer is to go after these makers of incompatible websites.  But
the internet is a social experiment, which means anything goes.

I for one plan on phasing out HTML in favor of flash.  Not that I am
in love with Adobe, but I am tired of HTML, and HTML is just plain

them all out. Luckily they have a search button.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Dec  3 14:23:20 2008
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 3 Dec 2008 14:23:20 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] OpenVPN for noobs...
In-Reply-To: <7ae7d1de0812021301u52d07584rf3291041c0af2127@mail.gmail.com>
References: <7ae7d1de0812021301u52d07584rf3291041c0af2127@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <alpine.OSX.2.00.0812031402130.92761@guild.galois.com>

On Tue, 2 Dec 2008, Eitan Tsur wrote:

> I'd like to set up an OpenVPN server for a network with about 5 
> clients. Can someone please direct me to some newbie-friendly 
> documentation on this system?

OpenVPN is in some ways very simple to run, but the concepts it 
expects the local administrator to have mastered -- especially network 
topology and SSL public-key infrastructure -- are difficult to 
encapsulate in a brief HOWTO. Indeed, the OpenVPN HOWTO runs 15,000+ 
words and contains 24 subhead links:

   http://www.openvpn.net/index.php/documentation/howto.html

The easy-rsa scripts that ship with OpenVPN are a good start for 
certificate generation and maintenance, but they're not really a 
substitute for a general understanding of public key infrastructures.

If you're asking for something more specific, I'll try to help, but 
your original request is so broad that it's difficult to know what 
obstacles you're trying to overcome.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> http://www.madboa.com/

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Dec  3 22:25:03 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed, 3 Dec 2008 22:25:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] OpenVPN BOF meeting?
In-Reply-To: <alpine.OSX.2.00.0812031402130.92761@guild.galois.com>
References: <7ae7d1de0812021301u52d07584rf3291041c0af2127@mail.gmail.com>
	<alpine.OSX.2.00.0812031402130.92761@guild.galois.com>
Message-ID: <20081204062503.GD8660@gate.kl-ic.com>


On Wed, Dec 03, 2008 at 02:23:20PM -0800, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> The easy-rsa scripts that ship with OpenVPN are a good start for 
> certificate generation and maintenance, but they're not really a 
> substitute for a general understanding of public key infrastructures.

This is the hardest part of OpenVPN for me.  If the keying
scripts don't work right (and I could not get them to work
for the topologies I wanted, where some machines are both
clients and servers) then the user must learn more than they
might want to about the underlying processes.  What bothers
me most is that I don't know enough to be confident that I
have done key creation correctly and created secure links.

Part of what makes this hard is that we normally think about
moving information, not about restricting it, and the whole
VPN/SSL process is about protecting information from unwanted
release.  In the real world, there are resourceful psychopaths
that want to hurt me for sport, and we design encrypted VPN
tunnels to hide from them.  That is quite unpleasant and
depressing to think about.

Software designers use surprisingly little design automation
- a Software CAD tool that designs and deploys certificate
and keying systems for arbitrary topologies would be an
obvious tool that would hide the complexity of this process
from overworked or part-time sysadmins.  A pretty good
"beta" version of such a tool would be a decent master's
project for a CS student, and might lead to a great job.

I am changing my firewall from an old laptop to an ALIX single
board computer running OpenWRT, and rebuilding my OpenVPN tunnels
around that.  I will probably be generating new certificates and
keys for all the machines that talk to the firewall because of 
that, so this is an opportunity for me to do OpenVPN "right".

Suggested solution - an OpenVPN BOF meeting

It might be useful to arrange a meeting of people with similar
OpenVPN needs and learn to do this together.  I've got Verizon
FIOS connectivity, an offsite server, and other bits and pieces
here at my Beaverton home office that we could use as a meeting
place.  Before I shut down my old system, other folks can look
at config files and log files with me, and see how I've got it
working now.  Perhaps we set up two nearby meeting places, and
create tunnels between them (I might talk my neighbor into it). 
Or somebody else can design some test systems that run across
my internal network.  Or even do it with a couple of VMWare
instances.   Sadly, I don't have the skill to make one of
these internal setups for experimentation and demonstration,
or the time to organize yet another meeting.  

If somebody else volunteers to arrange a time and gather people
and hector them into reading (if not understanding) the OpenVPN
documentation, perhaps we can set something up.  If smart guys
like Paul want to stop by and help, that would be most welcome.

Keith

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Dec  4 10:27:52 2008
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 4 Dec 2008 10:27:52 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] OpenVPN BOF meeting?
In-Reply-To: <20081204062503.GD8660@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <7ae7d1de0812021301u52d07584rf3291041c0af2127@mail.gmail.com>
	<alpine.OSX.2.00.0812031402130.92761@guild.galois.com>
	<20081204062503.GD8660@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <alpine.OSX.2.00.0812041009230.95346@guild.galois.com>

On Wed, 3 Dec 2008, Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> Part of what makes this hard is that we normally think about moving 
> information, not about restricting it, and the whole VPN/SSL process 
> is about protecting information from unwanted release.  In the real 
> world, there are resourceful psychopaths that want to hurt me for 
> sport, and we design encrypted VPN tunnels to hide from them.  That 
> is quite unpleasant and depressing to think about.

Another way to think about it is that life is full of data and 
communications that aren't meant for the public record. Some 
relationships demand more privacy than others, but the slice of my 
life that I want to open to all of humanity is fairly small. Most 
relationships assume some level of privacy.

Relationships conducted via digital media are no different. A VPN 
tunnel is one way to install confidence of all involved in the 
relationship that the expected privacy level will be maintained.

At our office, all of us from the CEO on down work in cubicles. No one 
has a private office. I don't take it as an insult -- or as a sign of 
paranoia -- when some colleagues go to a meeting room for a private 
discussion. They have things to do that don't involve me, and four 
walls and a door are a reasonable tool to ensure privacy.

When my wife and I need to discuss a point of parenting on which we're 
not in full agreement, we do the same sort of thing: go on a walk or 
retire to our bedroom. While the artifacts of that discussion will be 
made plain to our daughters, the discussion itself is more private.

To my mind, a VPN is no different. It's a method -- not much different 
than a conference room or a whispered conversation -- to instill 
confidence among people who need to communicate privately.

Can security be an artifact of paranoia or a symbol that someone has 
no trust in their surroundings? Sure. Need it be? No.

> Suggested solution - an OpenVPN BOF meeting
>
> [helpful details snipped]
>
> If somebody else volunteers to arrange a time and gather people
> and hector them into reading (if not understanding) the OpenVPN
> documentation, perhaps we can set something up.  If smart guys
> like Paul want to stop by and help, that would be most welcome.

A BOF or a non-Wednesday advanced topics meeting would be cool. I'd be 
happy to help out or even make a presentation.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> http://www.madboa.com/

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec  5 05:53:24 2008
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 5 Dec 2008 05:53:24 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] GIS software for mortals
In-Reply-To: <200812042355.47642.scratchcomputing@gmail.com>
References: <200812042355.47642.scratchcomputing@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812050548310.17101@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 4 Dec 2008, Eric Wilhelm wrote:

> What open source GIS software is good for casual or one-time users?

Eric,

   What do you want to do? Are you working with raster or vector data? Do you
want to draw pretty maps or do spatial analyses heavy with spatial
statistics and map algebra?

   I'm inclined to suggest that there is _no_ GIS software suitable for
casual or one-time use, just as there is no statistical software for such a
use. If you don't understand what's going on and how to use it appropriately
you end up mis-using it and not getting valid results.

   If the need is simple, I can refer you to a colleague of mine whose
exclusive business is developing GIS applications for clients. He could
probably do a one-off analysis more cost effectively than you could.

Rich

From russell at personaltelco.net  Fri Dec  5 06:35:05 2008
From: russell at personaltelco.net (Russell Senior)
Date: 05 Dec 2008 06:35:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] GIS software for mortals
In-Reply-To: <200812042355.47642.scratchcomputing@gmail.com>

>>>>> "Eric" == Eric Wilhelm <scratchcomputing at gmail.com> writes:

Eric> Hi all, There was a question at the meeting about GIS software
Eric> which I would love to see discussed on the list.

Eric> What open source GIS software is good for casual or one-time
Eric> users?

When Caleb Phillips and I were working on our Unwire PDX Watch report
(the volunteer MetroFi-testing project we did), we used QGIS, and
relied heavily on the friendly people on the associated irc channel
for help.  It has hooks into GRASS.  We weren't doing much analysis,
we mostly just wanted to plot dots (or radii) on top of orthoimagery
to generate maps.  I think the most analytical thing we did with it is
to compute the union of areas within 500 and 1000 feet of a SkyPilot.

On Fri, 5 Dec 2008 04:18:55 -0800
"David Kaplan" <davek52 at gmail.com> dijo:

> I found it, and ran the command. It then told me to reboot. After restarting
> I get a Grub erroe 15 and then it hangs. May have to reinstall Mint.

Grub Error 15 means it cannot find the files it needs to boot.

I haven't been reading this thread so I may be repeating.

When your computer starts up hit Esc in order to bring up the Grub boot
menu. You should see at least two boot options. Usually there will be a
kernel option and then the same kernel option listed as "Recovery
mode." If you see more than one set, try the lower one. Having upgraded
my laptop numerous times my menu list displays this:

Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-21-generic
Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-21-generic (recovery mode)
Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-19-generic
Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-19-generic (recovery mode)
Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-18-generic
Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-18-generic (recovery mode)
Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-16-generic
Ubuntu 8.04.1, kernel 2.6.24-16-generic (recovery mode)
Ubuntu 8.04.1, memtest86+

So if something is wrong with the 2.6.4-21 kernel I can try its
recovery mode, or one of the older kernels below it.

Hopefully you can get one of the kernels in your list to boot. If so
you can then fix whatever is wrong with your current kernel.

> >topology and SSL public-key infrastructure -- are difficult to
> >encapsulate in a brief HOWTO. Indeed, the OpenVPN HOWTO runs 15,000+
> >words and contains 24 subhead links:
> >
> >    http://www.openvpn.net/index.php/documentation/howto.html
> >
> >The easy-rsa scripts that ship with OpenVPN are a good start for
> >certificate generation and maintenance, but they're not really a
> >substitute for a general understanding of public key infrastructures.
> >
> >If you're asking for something more specific, I'll try to help, but
> >your original request is so broad that it's difficult to know what
> >obstacles you're trying to overcome.

From eehouse at eehouse.org  Fri Dec  5 12:19:34 2008
From: eehouse at eehouse.org (Eric House)
Date: Fri, 5 Dec 2008 12:19:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] OpenVPN for noobs...
Message-ID: <20081205201934.GA6133@onyx.spiritone.com>

On Tue, 2 Dec 2008, Eitan Tsur wrote:

> I'd like to set up an OpenVPN server for a network with about 5
> clients. Can someone please direct me to some newbie-friendly
> documentation on this system?

I went through this a couple of years ago linking residences in Oregon
and California.  Both are running LEAF routers, so I followed the docs
at leaf.sf.net.  LEAF hasn't modified openvpn, merely packaged it, so
the docs should apply wherever you get the package.  They walk you
through the process of creating keys in a pretty step-by-step fashion,
IIRC.

The connection's been great, BTW.  The only hiccup stems from having
dynamic IP addresses.  If an ip address changes and ez-ipupdate fails
for some reason I have to go run it manually.  With that done the vpn
connection comes right back up.

--Eric

On Fri, 5 Dec 2008 09:28:03 -0800
"David Kaplan" <davek52 at gmail.com> dijo:

> hitting Esc does nothing.

If your bootloader is Grub, then hitting Esc will bring up the Grub
boot menu. If it does not, you are not hitting Esc at the right moment.
You need to hit it right after the BIOS stuff finishes and before the
OS boot screen starts.

Is the track ball a USB device?  Do you have an optical mouse you can
try?  The reason I ask is because the optical mouse will give you an
obvious sort of feedback if it's running (a red light), which means
the usb-hid kernel module is loaded.  lsmod doesn't show any such
driver on my machine, but I believe I built it into the kernel.

Carlos Konstanski

On Sat, 6 Dec 2008, Carlos Konstanski wrote:

> Is the track ball a USB device?

Carlos,

   No. It plugs into the DIN mouse hole socket on the rear of the
motherboard.

> lsmod doesn't show any such driver on my machine, but I believe I built it
> into the kernel.

   Bingo! Even though gpm was running, for some reason the psmouse module was
not loaded. I just loaded it and ... now the cursor works in both console
mode and X Window System.

   This brings up an issue that I'll continue on a new thread.

   Thanks very much. I totally forgot to see if the mouse module was loaded
because I assumed it must be.

Rich

From cjdaniel at gmail.com  Sat Dec  6 23:17:09 2008
From: cjdaniel at gmail.com (cjdaniel at gmail.com)
Date: Sun, 07 Dec 2008 07:17:09 +0000
Subject: [PLUG] OpenMoko experiences?
Message-ID: <0016e64f6820d63838045d6fb21c@google.com>

I've had my G1 for a few weeks now. Adding a bit to the mention of the lack  
of a way to close applications -- there can be at most six apps open at any  
one time, and when you open a seventh, the least recent one gets closed. I  
haven't had much of a problem with this, but then, I don't use very  
intensive applications.

Google provides a terminal app, but it doesn't really get you much of  
anywhere, as getting root on Android version RC30 and later is (currently)  
not possible. My favourite application so far is the SSH client, ConnectBot  
(http://code.google.com/p/connectbot/). Also, I love having a physical  
QWERTY keyboard on my phone, versus silly on-screen keyboards.

Android is pretty nice, and I can see it going places. The second Android  
phone was announced by an Australian manufacturer last week, I think, for  
US $192.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Dec  7 00:41:59 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun, 7 Dec 2008 00:41:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] "brief" ifconfig?
Message-ID: <20081207084159.GB16789@gate.kl-ic.com>


Does anyone know of a brief version of ifconfig? 
The no arguments behavior, returning network interface status. 
Text, I want to be able to run it from a console. 

As is, an ifconfig on my firewall and vpn termination machine
generates 8 to 10 lines of info per interface, and with 13 real
or virtual interfaces.  That is more than will fit in one screen.

If there is no such program, I will write a Perl wrapper for
ifconfig: one line per interface, with only the most important
information.  It will probably look like:

# ifcb

ifc         encap       HWaddr            inet        rx+tx bytes   errors
--------- - ----- ----------------- --------------- --------------- ------
br-lan    U Enet  00:04:76:11:D3:68    192.168.02.1        15976691      0
br-dmz    U Enet  00:00:86:05:33:4E  91.122.042.131       501921704      4
eth1      U Enet  00:00:86:05:33:4E            none               0      0
eth2      U Enet  00:00:86:05:32:3F    192.168.03.1      2422497553    127
lo        U Loop  none                    127.0.0.1         3229943      0
tun0      U Unsp  none                 172.231.08.1        92579996      0
tun1      D Unsp  none                 172.231.36.1               0      0
tun2      U Unsp  none                 172.231.06.1        11601166      0
tun3      U Unsp  none                 172.231.28.1      2318814934      0

(74 char wide, no ipv6 for now)

I would probably also add a -l option to make it loop and redraw,
like "top", so I can watch data moving between interfaces.

That will probably take a few hours to write and debug, but it will
make controlling the network easier.  It will be even easier if 
somebody has already done it.

Keith

On Sun, Dec 07, 2008 at 10:43:20AM -0800, Eric Wilhelm wrote:
> You could let someone else parse it?

>   http://search.cpan.org/dist/Net-Ifconfig-Wrapper/

The 'list" option is interesting - but AFAICS, all it provides
is interface name, mac address, and IP address.  Not the spec,
the byte count, or the error count.  Still, it is the right
idea, and more portable than my cargo cult Perl.


I went ahead and wrote "ifbr" major kludge version 0.1, without
any option processing yet.  It turns out that the platform that
I want to run it on doesn't have Perl (!!).  On the other hand,
I would rather run the command on a different host anyway, so I
will run ifconfig on the target host with ssh, then pipe the
output into this program running on a more powerful machine
that DOES have Perl.   A problem becomes an improvement.

So, one of the options on V0.2 will be specifying the target
host, and others will include version number, help, loop
count and timing.

The Perl isn't that long, so I appended it.  Only tested on
two machines so far.  Note that the byte counts are large, 
so I used bigint .  However, bigints don't work right with
printf "%d", so I used printf "%s" for them;  kludgy but
functional.  Please don't read this so-called code less
than an hour after eating, thanks!

Later versions will be at http://www.keithl.com/ifbr  . 
I could have called it merely "ifb", but the acronym
needs a letter for "retarded".

Keith

/usr/local/bin/ifbr
--------------------------- cut here -----------------------------

#!/usr/bin/perl
#  ifbr -  brief network interface list
#  V0.1  Keith Lofstrom   KLIC   2008 Dec. 7

use bigint ;
my $ifc    ;
my $encap  ;
my $mac    ;
my $updn   ;
my $inet   ;
my $txrx   ;
my $err    ;

print "interface  s encp hdwr address      ipv4 address    errors  rx+tx bytes    \n";
print "---------- - ---- ----------------- --------------- ------- ---------------\n";
open (IFOUT, "/sbin/ifconfig |" );
while (<IFOUT>) {
   if( /(\w+)\s+Link encap:(\w+)/ ) {
      $ifc=$1 ;
      my $ec = $2 ;
      if(    $ec eq "Ethernet" ) { $encap = "Enet" }
      elsif( $ec eq "Local"    ) { $encap = "Loop" }
      elsif( $ec eq "UNSPEC"   ) { $encap = "Unsp" }
      else                       { $encap = "????" }

      if( /HWaddr\s+([01234567890ABCDEF:]+)/ ) {
         $mac=$1;
      } else {
         $mac="no hwaddr";
      }
      $inet = "none" ;
      $err = 0 ;

   } elsif( /inet addr:([\d\.]+)/ ) {
      $inet = $1 ;
   } elsif( /RUNNING/ ) {
      if( / UP / ) { $updn="U" } 
      else         { $updn=" " }
   } elsif( /X packets:\d+\s+errors:(\d+)/ ) {
      $err += $1 ;
   } elsif( /RX bytes:(\d+).+TX bytes:(\d+)/ ) {
      $txrx = $1+$2 ;
      
      #the grand output
      printf "%10s%2s%5s%18s%16s%8s%16s\n" ,
	     $ifc,$updn,$encap,$mac,$inet,$err,$txrx ;
   } 
}
close IFOUT;
--------------------------- cut here -----------------------------

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

> diff -r -s <folder1> <folder2>
>
> Carlos Konstanski

Or, better yet, if you just want the problem fixed, use rsync to make
a mirror copy of a directory tree:

rsync -av --delete folder1/ folder2/

Notice the trailing slashes.  These are vitally important in rsync.
You want to copy the contents of folder1 into folder2.  Always use
rsync like this to avoid disaster, especially when using the --delete
switch.  When not specifying --delete, you can get away with copying
folder1 itself to a destination (i.e. leaving off one or both trailing
slashes) without causing major data wiping.

Or, if you don't want to bother with a network mount, use rsync over
ssh:

rsync -e ssh -av --delete folder1/ user at desthost:folder2/

or if the source folder is on the remote host, and the destination is
local:

rsync -e ssh -av --delete user at sourcehost:folder1/ folder2/

Carlos Konstanski

> rsync -av --delete folder1/ folder2/
> 
> Notice the trailing slashes.  These are vitally important in rsync.
> You want to copy the contents of folder1 into folder2.  Always use
> rsync like this to avoid disaster, especially when using the --delete
> switch.  When not specifying --delete, you can get away with copying
> folder1 itself to a destination (i.e. leaving off one or both trailing
> slashes) without causing major data wiping.
> 
> Or, if you don't want to bother with a network mount, use rsync over
> ssh:
> 
> rsync -e ssh -av --delete folder1/ user at desthost:folder2/
> 
> or if the source folder is on the remote host, and the destination is
> local:
> 
> rsync -e ssh -av --delete user at sourcehost:folder1/ folder2/

I have not tried rsync in over two years. That is because it is far too
complicated for me. I cannot get the syntax correct. Plus it locked up
at random times. Luckily I never lost anything, but I had numerous
close calls. Yes, I know there are front ends for it and scripts
galore, but I don't understand the scripts either. I don't even
understand what the instructions mean. 

However, "copy" is a concept I can handle. I think a backup system I
can understand is better than a backup system I do not understand.

However, I want to steer this discussion far away from whether my
backup strategies are elegant, suitable, correct, or whatever. All I
want to do is get to the bottom of why Nautilus failed to copy a third
of the files. There were no error messages. The progress bar
continuously showed it copying files. The number of files remaining
continually decreased. The time remaining continually decreased until
it got to 0. The MB/sec indicator adjusted occasionally. The progress
bar progressed to the end. 

Thanks muy mucho for the  "diff -r -s" command. It gave me a list of
files that didn't make it. The bad news is that there is no pattern
that I can see. Some are hidden files, but a lot of hidden files and
folders did make it. Some are OOo documents, some are PDF files, some
are log files - in the list of files that didn't make it there is an
example for just about every kind of file on the computer. Also, some
are tiny, some are large, yet files of all sizes made it.

The laptop (source) has 79 GB free and the desktop (destination) has 45
GB free. The total of ~/ on the laptop is only 14.1 GB.

Still scratching my head.

On Sun, 7 Dec 2008 19:28:59 -0800
John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> dijo:

> Well, I just discovered that it did not copy the file used by

> And also why there were about 50 other normal, smaller files it did not
> copy.
> 
> Making some progress, but still shaking head.

OK, I finally found out what the problem was.

It did copy the Virtualbox folder, including the Windows 2000 vdi file
(6.3 GB). In fact, it reliably copied everything. 

The problem is in Nautilus' Properties utility. When you right click on
a folder and select Properties it gives you the details about the
folder, including the total size. It reported 7.3 GB when, in fact, the
folder contained 14.1 GB. And the reason is that the Properties utility
does not count hidden files. Dumb, eh?

Meantime, while struggling to figure this all out, I discovered
Flyback. Flyback is a python based front end for rsync. It lacks a few
niceties - no progress bar, no final statistics. Also, there seems to
have been no development for the past year. But it runs faster than
copying with Nautilus. And you can exclude folders and file types by
pattern matching. You can do the latter in rsync too, if you can get it
to actually work.

So next is to upgrade to Intrepid. Y'all cross your fingers. :)

supported version for their upgrade already "*Upgrades from 8.04 LTS to 8.10

for older releasees..
ii  update-manager-core
1:0.87.30                                 manage release upgrades

then get to a point where going to Intrepid is easy..  and managed by

ii  update-manager-core
1:0.93.34                                            manage release upgrades

It all seemed to be nicely documented for me when I went through the
process.

Backing up your files including your config files before upgrade should be a
given anyway.

On Mon, 8 Dec 2008, Bruce KIlpatrick wrote:

> This is my experience, too. I have tried the upgrade process on a desktop
> AMD machine and an AMD laptop with NVidia graphics. Both were complete
> disasters in the end. I wiped and started from scratch on both.

   This brings to mind a question I've had for years: why do distribution
upgrades become so FUBARed that folks recommend installing from scratch?

   Since I switched to Slackware (from Red Hat) in September 2003 I've had a
minor hassle during the 10.2->11.0 upgrade because of changes in how tools
were packaged and where they were installed. But the CHANGES_AND_HINTS.TXT
file detailed everything I needed to know ... when I finally read the whole
thing. Similarly, the huge jump from 11.0->12.0 (including changing from BSD
to SysV style init scripts and /etc contents was also very well documented.
But, the latter did take a long time to complete, and I needed expert help
from those more guru'd than I.

   The nVidia graphics chip is a bother. For each of the major distribution
upgrades mentioned above, I had to us my notebook to get the latest driver
version from their web site, then build and install it.

   Regardless, since Red Hat 4.0 I've done upgrades rather than fresh
installations. Yet I read that many folks take the latter route. I'm curious
-- without challenging anyone's views -- why this is.

Rich

Message-ID: <20081208114405.23c98551.johnxj@comcast.net>

On Mon, 8 Dec 2008 11:16:51 -0800
"David Kaplan" <davek52 at gmail.com> dijo:

> I've tried many times to use the Esc to bring up boot menu, but nothing
> works.
> 
> How do you re-enable grub? The hdd is ok but until I can get grub to work I
> can do a thing.

There should be a plain text file: /boot/grub/menu.lst. Before doing
anything else, make a copy for backup purposes. Then open it in your
favorite text editor as root. On Ubuntu that would be "sudo
gedit /boot/grub/menu.lst." You can also open it in a terminal with
"sudo nano /boot/grub/menu.lst."

You should find a section that says:

## hiddenmenu
# Hides the menu by default (press ESC to see the menu)
hiddenmenu

Comment out the "hiddenmenu" line so it says 

#hiddenmenu

Save the menu.lst file and reboot.

On Mon, Dec 8, 2008 at 11:13 AM, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>wrote:

>   This brings to mind a question I've had for years: why do distribution
> upgrades become so FUBARed that folks recommend installing from scratch?
>


While I'm sure there are many reasons that this happens, it is difficult to
avoid because of all the different package revisions that happen and change
over time.  Often formatting and options of config files change, breaking
backward compatibility.  Some locations of things change, kernel modules
don't remain loaded/compiled in, etc.

It isn't just Linux though.  Windows has the same pitfall, but with the
amount of different programs and authors or software, coordinating upgrades
is madness.  So usually it is generally just easier to install fresh when
you know most packages will be using the newest versions, and not have
issues with old config files, dependencies, etc.  Package maintainers cannot
test your exact combination of software, but distribution vendors can test
the combination of software that makes it into their releases.

-Nye

Eitan Tsur wrote:
> Anyone know how to convert the capitalized character after apostrophe(s) in
> a string to lowercase? (using s/// in sed, perl, etc...)
> _______________________________________________

Use tr(1), e.g.

     $ tr A-Z a-z  <in > out

Also, in Perl

     tr/SEARCHLIST/REPLACEMENTLIST/
     y/SEARCHLIST/REPLACEMENTLIST/

    ... see the perlop(1) man page for details ..

I'm a fan of dovecot. Used it combined with postfix for a while on some 
smallish servers with 5-25 clients each. It's supposed to scale really 
well, though. It also plugs in nicely with a lot of the other bits and 
pieces (postfix, getmail, ...).

If you wanted to go for more than just IMAP email, the Zimbra server 
provides a lot of nice functionality, albeit at the cost of a license. 
Unsure how hairy the back end is, though. We out-sourced to a Zimbra 
provider, when we switched from pop3, because we just didn't have the time

If you are referring to what we usually call the clinic, it is normally 
held from 1-5 PM each third Sunday, which this month would be the 21st.

Christmas, but I don't recall what was decided.
>   Do we need to bring more equipment than the CPU.
Most of the time, your CPU is all you need. Sometimes it's more 
productive to have your own monitor. I recall one clinic where I did not 
bring my flat screen monitor. The glass monitors available did not 
support the resolution my machine normally expects. That caused some 
difficulties, which were solved for the clinic, but which I had to 
re-solve once I got home. Since my flat screen monitor isn't hard to 
haul, I now take it with me when I go to the clinic. YMMV.

Other things you might need to take would be hardware unique to your 
installation -- a scanner, perhaps.

Nope.  You have it down exactly right.  In truth what I was doing was a
kludge, as I'm running a script to organize my music collection.  Here's the
line:
newName="`echo "$i" | sed 's/_/\ /g' | sed 's/  /\ /g' | perl -p -e
's/(\\w+)/\\u\\L$1/g;' | sed 's/[mM]4[aA]/m4a/g' | sed
's/[mM][pP]3/mp3/g'`";

Basically the first sed replaces underscores with spaces, the second I
think(?) escapes space characters, the perl bit looks confusing to me and
I'm really too lazy to figure out exactly what it does.  What I _think_ it
does is capitalize the first letter of every word, which is why I get stuff
like "Fred'S " when I want "Fred's ".  (I'm assuming an apostrophe acts like
a word break or something).  The last two sed parts lowercase stuff in a way
which I am sure could be made more pretty.

From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Dec  8 19:56:10 2008

Subject: [PLUG] (st_uid=1000)

After upgrading to Intrepid Virtualbox will not launch. From the
command line I get:

jjj at Devil7:~$ virtualbox
VirtualBox: supR3HardenedVerifyDir: Cannot trust the directory
"/usr/lib/virtualbox": not owned by root (st_uid=1000)

After a few moments of puzzlement it suddenly dawned on me - this is a
residual problem from the day when I took ownership of the entire /usr
folder. Hey, I'm the user, right? So they're my files, right? Evidently
the new version of Vitualbox in Intrepid has some security thing going
on that requires the above folder to be owned by root.

So fine, I'll make root the owner of the folder. I did

sudo chown root:root /usr/lib/virtualbox

And the command indeed made root the owner of the folder. But I still
get the same error message as above.

I should add that I have Virtualbox on my desktop as well, and after
upgrading it to Intrepid Virtualbox still works fine. But I did not
take ownership of the /usr folder on the desktop. So that has to be the
source of the problem on the laptop.

Looking at the desktop, the /usr/lib/virtualbox permissions are
rwxr-xr-x, which I think translates to 755. I chmod'd the folder to
that on the laptop, but 755 set it to rwsr-xr-x, and I still get the
same error message when I try to launch Virtualbox. I can't figure out
what the "s" is in there or how to change it to "x." (Set user ID?)
I've googled almost to the end of the internet and Google seems to have
run out of answers. Or maybe Google is just sick of me.

Oh, and I also reinstalled Virtualbox from Synaptic, but no joy.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Dec  8 20:28:02 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon, 8 Dec 2008 20:28:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ifconfig: rx_bytes and tx_bytes wrap to word size
Message-ID: <20081209042802.GA3864@gate.kl-ic.com>


I never noticed before, but the ifconfig fields RXbytes and TXbytes
wrap to the word size of the machine.  That is, for a 32 bit machine
they max out at 4,294,967,295 (2^32-1) then start counting at zero
again.  For a 64 bit machine, they go much larger (my 64 bit compute
server, which has been up for 260 days, has transmitted 31.5 GiB so
far).

This is the equal to the values stored in:

/sys/class/net/*/statistics/tx_bytes and ... /rx_bytes

... which wrap the same way.

So, I may change my ifbr script to count packets rather than
bytes.  Those will still measure data movement, but they will
wrap much less often.

Interestingly, "ip -s link" wraps at 32 bits for both 32 bit and
64 bit machines.  How very "special".  Not.

This behavior was observed with a 2.6.18 kernel (RHEL5) and a
2.6.24 kernel (Ubuntu 8.04 Heron).  I guess it's a "feature".

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Dec  8 20:39:18 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon, 8 Dec 2008 20:39:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ifconfig: rx_bytes and tx_bytes wrap to word size (2)
In-Reply-To: <20081209042802.GA3864@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20081209042802.GA3864@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <20081209043918.GB3864@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Mon, Dec 08, 2008 at 08:28:02PM -0800, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> 
> I never noticed before, but the ifconfig fields RXbytes and TXbytes
> wrap to the word size of the machine.  That is, for a 32 bit machine
> they max out at 4,294,967,295 (2^32-1) then start counting at zero
> again.  For a 64 bit machine, they go much larger (my 64 bit compute
> server, which has been up for 260 days, has transmitted 31.5 GiB so
> far).
> 
> This is the equal to the values stored in:
> 
> /sys/class/net/*/statistics/tx_bytes and ... /rx_bytes
> 
> ... which wrap the same way.
> 
> So, I may change my ifbr script to count packets rather than
> bytes.  Those will still measure data movement, but they will
> wrap much less often.
> 
> Interestingly, "ip -s link" wraps at 32 bits for both 32 bit and
> 64 bit machines.  How very "special".  Not.
> 
> This behavior was observed with a 2.6.18 kernel (RHEL5) and a
> 2.6.24 kernel (Ubuntu 8.04 Heron).  I guess it's a "feature".
> 
> Keith

I thought of more google search terms, and learned that this has
been an issue for a while.  See:

http://lkml.org/lkml/2004/2/18/169

I suppose they are silently hoping for this to go away as 64 bit
machines replace the 32 bit ones.  A 32 bit machine, connected to
10 gigabit ethernet, is going to wrap the counter about 10 times
per minute ...

On Mon, Dec 08, 2008 at 02:14:07PM -0800, Don Buchholz wrote:
> Eitan Tsur wrote:
> >Anyone know how to convert the capitalized character after apostrophe(s) in
> >a string to lowercase? (using s/// in sed, perl, etc...)
> >_______________________________________________
> 
> Use tr(1), e.g.
> 
>     $ tr A-Z a-z  <in > out
> 
> Also, in Perl
> 
>     tr/SEARCHLIST/REPLACEMENTLIST/
>     y/SEARCHLIST/REPLACEMENTLIST/
> 
>    ... see the perlop(1) man page for details ..

You misread the question - Eitan wants to replace FRED'S with
FRED's, which is more grammatically correct (me, I would prefer
Fred's ).   A lot would depend on context, which Eitan did not
give.  Is this an isolated word, or correcting words as part of
text, or what?  For example, Fixing "FRED'S NAP'STER FILE" 
will be interesting if the second S is not supposted to get
lower cased;  otherwise, just replace all instances of "'S"
with "'s".    If text, what about end-of-line issues?  What
about non-Roman characters?  What matters here?
 
Sometimes, the best way to get started on a problem like this
is to produce a few examples and expected outputs, and "design
to the test".  A clear set of tests may result in simpler code.

Ok, so here's a few examples... (from my music collection)

Guns N' Roses
FAT FREDDY'S DROP
black_rebel_motorcycle_club

The end results SHOULD be like so:
Guns N' Roses
Fat Freddy's Drop (note the 's is not capitalized)
Black Rebel Motorcycle Club (underscores converted to spaces)

Basically capitalize every first letter of every word, convert underscores
to spaces, (these are folder names by the way,) and NOT capitalize letters
after an apostrophe and before a space.  That should take care of most
cases.  For non-roman chars I may have to look into that.  I have a few
folders with those in the text.  The reason for this is to have consistent
naming and format of all folders.

Subject: [PLUG] substitution question...
In-Reply-To: <7ae7d1de0812091056k57edbb91n6adc9b1e8461b556@mail.gmail.com>
References: <7ae7d1de0812081335q58c0f8bfi83a14500d2ea14ff@mail.gmail.com>
	<493D9C2F.5070207@easystreet.net>	<20081209183325.GB7846@gate.kl-ic.com>
	<7ae7d1de0812091056k57edbb91n6adc9b1e8461b556@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <493EC50C.7090701@fredjame.cnc.net>

Eitan Tsur wrote:
> Ok, so here's a few examples... (from my music collection)
>
> Guns N' Roses
> FAT FREDDY'S DROP
> black_rebel_motorcycle_club
>
> The end results SHOULD be like so:
> Guns N' Roses
> Fat Freddy's Drop (note the 's is not capitalized)
> Black Rebel Motorcycle Club (underscores converted to spaces)
>   
Eitan Tsur
Oops - I made an incorrect assumption ... assuming that the file name 
would have underscores instead of spaces (as in the 
"black_rebel_motorcycle_club" example) this would work (see below) ... 
but it won't work with spaces (i.e., "FAT FREDDY'S DROP")
But you could use 'ls -1' to make a text file of names, (one name per 
line/record) and then feed those into the loop one line at a time - does 
that help?
Regards
Fred James

#! /bin/bash
#       naming.sh
#       Usage: ./naming.sh directorypath
Dir=$1
for oldName in `ls -1 $Dir`
do
        echo "old name ${oldName}"
        tempName=`echo ${oldName} | gawk -F\_ '{
                for (i = 1;i < NF;i++) {
                        if (length($i) > 1) {
                                printf("%s", toupper(substr($i,1,1)))
                                printf("%s_",substr($i,2))
                        } else {
                                printf("%s_", toupper($i))
                        }
                }
                if (length($i) > 1) {
                        printf("%s", toupper(substr($i,1,1)))
                        printf("%s",substr($i,2))
                } else {
                        printf("%s", toupper($i))
                }
        }'`
        tempName=`echo ${tempName} | sed -e 's/_/ /g'`
        newName=`echo ${tempName} | sed -e 's/ /\ /g'`
        echo "->$oldName<-"
        echo "->$newName<-"
done
exit 0

Wow...  Well all I really need is something that matches
"[apostrophe][letter][space]" and lowercases that letter in a string.  I
assume this can be done with sed or some other tool.  I'll tack it on to the
end of what I have so far, which does most of what I need already.

On Tue, Dec 9, 2008 at 11:20 AM, Fred James <fredjame at fredjame.cnc.net>wrote:

> Eitan Tsur wrote:
> > Ok, so here's a few examples... (from my music collection)
> >
> > Guns N' Roses
> > FAT FREDDY'S DROP
> > black_rebel_motorcycle_club
> >
> > The end results SHOULD be like so:
> > Guns N' Roses
> > Fat Freddy's Drop (note the 's is not capitalized)
> > Black Rebel Motorcycle Club (underscores converted to spaces)
> >
> Eitan Tsur
> Oops - I made an incorrect assumption ... assuming that the file name
> would have underscores instead of spaces (as in the
> "black_rebel_motorcycle_club" example) this would work (see below) ...
> but it won't work with spaces (i.e., "FAT FREDDY'S DROP")
> But you could use 'ls -1' to make a text file of names, (one name per
> line/record) and then feed those into the loop one line at a time - does
> that help?
> Regards
> Fred James
>
> #! /bin/bash
> #       naming.sh
> #       Usage: ./naming.sh directorypath
> Dir=$1
> for oldName in `ls -1 $Dir`
> do
>        echo "old name ${oldName}"
>        tempName=`echo ${oldName} | gawk -F\_ '{
>                for (i = 1;i < NF;i++) {
>                        if (length($i) > 1) {
>                                printf("%s", toupper(substr($i,1,1)))
>                                printf("%s_",substr($i,2))
>                        } else {
>                                printf("%s_", toupper($i))
>                        }
>                }
>                if (length($i) > 1) {
>                        printf("%s", toupper(substr($i,1,1)))
>                        printf("%s",substr($i,2))
>                } else {
>                        printf("%s", toupper($i))
>                }
>        }'`
>        tempName=`echo ${tempName} | sed -e 's/_/ /g'`
>        newName=`echo ${tempName} | sed -e 's/ /\ /g'`
>        echo "->$oldName<-"
>        echo "->$newName<-"
> done
> exit 0
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

over written so the pathing is broken. Where physically on the system does

there, maybe the old config is named httpd.conf.bak{old} which should have
happened during the upgrade.

Fred James wrote:
> Eitan Tsur wrote:
>   
>> Ok, so here's a few examples... (from my music collection)
>>
>> Guns N' Roses
>> FAT FREDDY'S DROP
>> black_rebel_motorcycle_club
>>
>> The end results SHOULD be like so:
>> Guns N' Roses
>> Fat Freddy's Drop (note the 's is not capitalized)
>> Black Rebel Motorcycle Club (underscores converted to spaces)
>>   
>>     
> Eitan Tsur
> Oops - I made an incorrect assumption ... assuming that the file name 
> would have underscores instead of spaces (as in the 
> "black_rebel_motorcycle_club" example) this would work (see below) ... 
> but it won't work with spaces (i.e., "FAT FREDDY'S DROP")
> But you could use 'ls -1' to make a text file of names, (one name per 
> line/record) and then feed those into the loop one line at a time - does 
> that help?
> Regards
> Fred James
>
> #! /bin/bash
> #       naming.sh
> #       Usage: ./naming.sh directorypath
> Dir=$1
> for oldName in `ls -1 $Dir`
> do
>         echo "old name ${oldName}"
>         tempName=`echo ${oldName} | gawk -F\_ '{
>                 for (i = 1;i < NF;i++) {
>                         if (length($i) > 1) {
>                                 printf("%s", toupper(substr($i,1,1)))
>                                 printf("%s_",substr($i,2))
>                         } else {
>                                 printf("%s_", toupper($i))
>                         }
>                 }
>                 if (length($i) > 1) {
>                         printf("%s", toupper(substr($i,1,1)))
>                         printf("%s",substr($i,2))
>                 } else {
>                         printf("%s", toupper($i))
>                 }
>         }'`
>         tempName=`echo ${tempName} | sed -e 's/_/ /g'`
>         newName=`echo ${tempName} | sed -e 's/ /\ /g'`
>         echo "->$oldName<-"
>         echo "->$newName<-"
> done
> exit 0
>   
Eitan Tsur
Sorry - forgot to mention that if you wanted to go the text file route, 
you would want to remove the '-F\_' from the gawk statement
('gawk -F\_ {' becomes 'gawk {')
and move the first sed statement to before the gawk - hope that helps
Regards
Fred James



From rsteff at comcast.net  Tue Dec  9 13:34:28 2008
From: rsteff at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Tue, 09 Dec 2008 13:34:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: Directing mailto in Firefox to Thunderbird
Message-ID: <493EE464.3030808@comcast.net>

(I thought I sent this earlier, but discovered that it only went to 
John! Thanks to all the rest of you who also replied.)

John Hauser wrote:
> in firefox Edit|Preferences|Application change mailto to "use other"
> and type in thunderbird %s
>   
The GUI did not provide a means to get to the directory where 
thunderbird lives, nor is there a text box in which to type in 
thunderbird %s.
> or nore generally:
> http://kb.mozillazine.org/Default_mail_client#Linux_-_Gnome
>   
Their instructions aren't complete enough to cover Ubuntu. However, it 
gave me enough to work with to go find the right place to make the 
change. Mozillazine's instructions say:

Go to "Applications -> Desktop Preferences -> Advanced -> Preferred 
Applications."

In Ubuntu Hardy, you have to:

Go to "System -> Preferences -> Preferred Applications. "

The first tab on the window is Internet, with  Web Browser and Mail 
Reader as the two  applications to set. Thunderbird is one of the two 
choices available for Mail Reader on my system, and thunderbird %s is 
listed in the "command" text box.

After changing that selection from Evolution to Thunderbird I now get a 
Thunderbird composition window when I click on a mailto link.

Thanks for pointing me in the right direction.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
www.dicksteffens.com
