# from VY
# on Tuesday 09 December 2008 10:37:

>Can anyone recommend a good ATSC USB tuner that has good Linux
> support? I am hoping to get one to decode HD signals.

The HVR-850 works (only as ATSC, but the analog support won't matter in 
a couple months anyway.)  The instructions on the linuxtv wiki are not 
very good.  (The dvbscan program is currently broken, so after messing 
with firmware, I didn't know the tuner was working until I tried 
the 'scan' program.)  The firmware you need is:

  http://www.steventoth.net/linux/xc5000/

At least, if you have kernel 2.6.26 and the xc5000 gets automatically 
loaded.  There seems to have been some talk about the HVR-850 having 
various innards.

On Tue, 9 Dec 2008, drew wymore wrote:

> What user/group is Apache running as? It seems that perhaps Apache is not
> running as nobody.nobody so the permissions are too restrictive to allow
> access to rshepard.conf

Drew,

   Up to -12.0 or -12.1 (I forget in which version it changed), the package
was called apache, the configuration file was /etc/apache/httpd.conf, and
user.group was nobody.nobody. Now, the package is called httpd, the
configuration file is /etc/httpd/httpd.conf, and user.group is
apache.apache. In addition, there is now a /srv/httpd which is a soft link
to /var/www.

> You could change the user/group to nobody.nobody in the httpd.conf and
> restart Apache so that you wouldn't have to change anything else.

   I'll give this a try, wait one ... nope:

Internal Server Error

The server encountered an internal error or misconfiguration and was unable
to complete your request.

Please contact the server administrator, rshepard at appl-ecosys.com and inform
them of the time the error occurred, and anything you might have done that
may have caused the error.

More information about this error may be available in the server error log.

   Keep those ideas coming, though!

Thanks,

Rich

an address ending in .1, like 192.168.16.1?  I am about to install a

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812100558110.28824@grond.sourballs.org>

On Mon, 8 Dec 2008, chris (fool) mccraw wrote:
> On Mon, Dec 8, 2008 at 18:19, Eitan Tsur <eitan.tsur at gmail.com> wrote:
> > Nope.  You have it down exactly right.  In truth what I was doing was a
> > kludge, as I'm running a script to organize my music collection.  Here's the
> > line:
> > newName="`echo "$i" | sed 's/_/\ /g' | sed 's/  /\ /g' | perl -p -e
> > 's/(\\w+)/\\u\\L$1/g;' | sed 's/[mM]4[aA]/m4a/g' | sed
> > 's/[mM][pP]3/mp3/g'`";

It seems to me the simplest way to handle the possessive apostrophe case 
would be to tack on a second perl bit that makes sure final S's are 
lowercase; replace 

 perl -p -e 's/(\\w+)/\\u\\L$1/g;'

with

 perl -pe 's/(\w+)/\u\L$1/g; s/S\b/s/g;'

e.g.:

$ echo "SAM FRED'S O'MALLEY'S" | perl -pe 's/(\w+)/\u\L$1/g; s/S\b/s/g;'
Sam Fred's O'Malley's

(notice I said simple, not elegant.)


> having written the same script lo these many years ago, i can only
> advise heartily against spaces in filenames. 

Seconded.

--
David Fleck
david.fleck at mchsi.com



From david.fleck at mchsi.com  Wed Dec 10 04:38:36 2008
From: david.fleck at mchsi.com (David Fleck)
Date: Wed, 10 Dec 2008 06:38:36 -0600 (CST)
Subject: [PLUG] substitution question...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812100558110.28824@grond.sourballs.org>
References: <7ae7d1de0812081335q58c0f8bfi83a14500d2ea14ff@mail.gmail.com>
	<493DA5B6.6000203@fredjame.cnc.net>
	<7ae7d1de0812081819j4c887a40k79a5b506c35dbc5f@mail.gmail.com>
	<ae2db4620812082016g74552f85p5cc4f30efd405cdd@mail.gmail.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812100558110.28824@grond.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812100630560.28824@grond.sourballs.org>

On Wed, 10 Dec 2008, David Fleck wrote:
> On Mon, Dec 8, 2008 at 18:19, Eitan Tsur <eitan.tsur at gmail.com> wrote:
> > Nope.  You have it down exactly right.  In truth what I was doing was a
> > kludge, as I'm running a script to organize my music collection.  Here's the
> > line:
> > newName="`echo "$i" | sed 's/_/\ /g' | sed 's/  /\ /g' | perl -p -e
> > 's/(\\w+)/\\u\\L$1/g;' | sed 's/[mM]4[aA]/m4a/g' | sed
> > 's/[mM][pP]3/mp3/g'`";

As a followup, I'd also note that you can simplify this whole line by:

* combining all the sed invocations into a single one
* replacing the backticks with $( ... )  (assuming you're using bash or 
ksh)
* dumping the double-quotes around the whole thing 

to produce:

newName=$(echo $i | perl -pe 's/(\w+)/\u\L$1/g; s/S\b/s/g;' | sed -e 
's/_/\ /g' -e 's/ */ /g' -e 's/[mM][pP]3/mp3/g' -e 's/[mM]4[aA]/m4a/g')

--
David Fleck
david.fleck at mchsi.com

From johnxj at comcast.net  Wed Dec 10 08:57:34 2008
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Wed, 10 Dec 2008 08:57:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Is it Comcast or Motorola?
Message-ID: <20081210085734.ec465c0c.johnxj@comcast.net>

I have Comcast cable at home, connected with a Motorola SB5100
SurfModem. The network is ethernet; all components are rated cat6.

I download distros via torrent using Ktorrent 3.1.2 on Intrepid. I like
to set Ktorrent to allow a lot of connections per torrent because it
increases the download speed. I also like to leave it running until the
share ratio is at least 1.00 (which means that I have uploaded as many
bytes as I have downloaded). I do this with my desktop computer.

The other day I upgraded my laptop to Intrepid. After the progress
window said it had finished downloading all the new packages I started
downloading four versions of Kubuntu on the desktop, because I figured I
no longer needed any bandwidth for the laptop upgrade. The maximum
allowable connections per torrent was set to 500. In the middle of
installing all the new packages the laptop upgrade halted on
flashplayer. Looking at the terminal I could see that it was
downloading flash. I didn't realize that it hadn't really finished
downloading *all* the new packages. It had stalled on the flash
download. Looking at Ktorrent on the desktop I could see that it had
also stalled.

After several minutes of scratching my head in panic over the stalled
upgrade I decided to power cycle the modem. A minute or two after
plugging it back in the network was back and the laptop upgrade
proceeded normally. Ktorrent also started back up.

Since then I have had to power cycle the modem every hour or so to
restore the connection. I have set Ktorrent down to allow only 50
connections per torrrent, but I still lose the connection, even with
only four torrents running. If I leave Ktorrent on Pause the connection
stays up perfectly.

So I am wondering if it is Comcast or the modem. Comcast swears they
are no longer throttling torrents. (Now they just charge you extra if
you exceed 100 GB per month.) Every recent discussion that Google can
find leads me to believe they are telling the truth. The modem is
several years old. Maybe all the bits that have passed through it have
finally eroded its little wires. :)

Or maybe there is something about having too many connections that gets
the modem flummoxed.

It could also be Ktorrent, but that seems less likely to me. It is a
new version that came with Intrepid, but I have been using Ktorrent for
years without a problem.

Does anyone here have any experience that could shed light on the
issue? Suggestions for troubleshooting?

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Dec 10 13:32:32 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed, 10 Dec 2008 13:32:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Is it Comcast or Motorola?
In-Reply-To: <20081210085734.ec465c0c.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20081210085734.ec465c0c.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20081210213232.GA14888@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Wed, Dec 10, 2008 at 08:57:34AM -0800, John Jason Jordan wrote:
...
> So I am wondering if it is Comcast or the modem. Comcast swears they
> are no longer throttling torrents. (Now they just charge you extra if
> you exceed 100 GB per month.) Every recent discussion that Google can
> find leads me to believe they are telling the truth. The modem is
> several years old. Maybe all the bits that have passed through it have
> finally eroded its little wires. :)

Comcast ( A.K.A Comcan't ) was limiting downloads because their
network is inadequate.  Their network is still inadequate, but
they removed the limits to avoid censure.  

As I understand it, one of the inadequacies is limited bandwidth
signal amplifiers in the local loop, between your cable and their
switching centers.  I was told (by a second-level Comcast service
tech) that the power consumption of the amplifiers is a function 
of data rates, and that they overheat with high packet rates.
That sounds like flakey design, but I can imagine legacy hardware
behaving like that.

One of the main reasons I switched fromn Comcast to Verizon FIOS
is that the fiber infrastructure is first rate, and potentially
enormously fast.  Coax cable local loops are at their limits,
so Comcast will have to replace their entire infrastructure if
they want to improve.  Since I like competition, I hope they
survive, but not enough to suffer from their service myself.

What to do?  Can you schedule your downloads to occur when other
people on your local loop aren't using the Internet?  See if that
helps.  "at" is your friend.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Dec 10 15:50:15 2008
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 10 Dec 2008 15:50:15 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Cannot Load Local Web Site, No Reported Errors
In-Reply-To: <alpine.LNX.2.00.0812090714040.1607@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 9 Dec 2008, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Since the distribution upgrade of my server/workstation I can no longer
> access SQL-Ledger ... a critical issue I need to fix right away.

   A very public "thank you" to Wes for pointing me to the correct error_log
file location. For whatever reason, there was no README that expanded on the
implications of changing the apache package to an httpd package. Sigh.

   Looking at the file I found the source of the problem: the DBD::Pg module
was for the previous version of perl, not the updated version installed with
the -12.x series. I know we have folks here who think the programming sun
rises and sets on perl, but I find it opaque, fragile, and a serious PIMyA.

   Regardless, the pain is gone. Running CPAN and installing the latest and
greatest Pg.pm fixed the problem. I now have access to SQL-Ledger.

   A sincere thanks to Drew, too, for sharing his greater Slackware expertise
in helping me find the subtle changes that I miss since I'm only a part-time
SysAdmin.

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Dec 10 15:52:59 2008
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 10 Dec 2008 15:52:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Now To Fix .Xmodmap -- FIXED
In-Reply-To: <alpine.LNX.2.00.0812091851250.18913@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <alpine.LNX.2.00.0812091851250.18913@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <alpine.LNX.2.00.0812101550300.9151@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 9 Dec 2008, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   No errors are reported, so I have no idea why it's no longer being
> invoked from the xinitrc file.

   It turns out this is a documented bug in xinit that is triggered by having
the xmodmap line following the xfce4-session line in ~/.xfce4/xinitrc.
Moving that command above the session command fixes the problem.

   The xinitrc file on my server/workstation is different from the one on the
notebook for some reason. That's why I saw this behavior on only the latter
host.

Rich

Thanks to all for the suggestions and observations.

The Intrepid upgrade installed Ktorrent 3.1.2 on KDE 4.1.3. When I
first launched it I was getting horrible download speeds. It was set to
a maximum of 10 connections per torrent by default. Unfortunately, I do
not recall how many connections per torrent the previous version was
set to. 

Because of the horrible download speed I bumped it up to 100, then 200,
then finally 500 connections per torrent. If I recall correctly I was
trying to get Fedora, which had hundreds of seeders. I had no problem
at that time with the net connection. 

Now that I am having problems I have knocked it back to 10 connections
per torrent and am still getting disconnected every few minutes.
Ktorrent worked fine with 500 connections per torrent before, but now
can't handle even 10. Because of this I conclude that it is not
Ktorrent. On the other hand, in the past I have been surprised by my
failure to grasp something obvious, so who knows for sure?

Keith's suggestion that it might be Comcast's equipment makes a lot of
sense. However, unless I miss my guess, the situation is continuing to
deteriorate. Right now I can't run even one torrent at 10 connections
without getting disconnected. And the disconnect first happened after a
couple of hours, where now I get cut off in a matter of minutes after
taking Ktorrent off Pause.

So at this point I'm voting for the modem as the culprit. Anyway,
they're not expensive, so a quick trip to Fry's may confirm or disprove
the modem hypothesis. Worst case I end up with an unneeded cable modem.

From eitan.tsur at gmail.com  Thu Dec 11 01:37:24 2008
From: eitan.tsur at gmail.com (Eitan Tsur)
Date: Thu, 11 Dec 2008 01:37:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for the right rsync command...
In-Reply-To: <1228984700.13305.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1228984700.13305.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <7ae7d1de0812110137j7a75e326l48d6f4890063b2f1@mail.gmail.com>

Let me verify what I think you want: Some way to have a filesystem mirrored
real-time, to a remote location, via a network connection, and you are
asking whether rsync can do this for you.

Well, from what I know of rsync, (which is hardly anything, so don't think
this is definitive,) it merely synchronizes files as they are when it is
run.  If you wanted the files to be synchronized between your system and a
backup location often, you'd have to re-run rsync say every minute via a
scheduled task or something.  If this were good enough for your purposes,
then maybe that works.  Someone with a better understanding of rsync and
_all_ of it's features may be able to shed more light on this matter for you
however.  I've only used it for backup purposes, where real-time
synchronization was never a requirement.

Regards,
-Eitan-

Denyhosts does exactly this!  It's a perl script that runs as a daemon
from /etc/init.d.  It puts IP addresses into hosts.deny after the
configured number of failed login attempts.

I like to a step further, and disallow password authentication
entirely.  On my public-facing server, I must use authorized keys.  I
still run denyhosts though, using ssh as a honeypot to attract the
undesirables of the internet, for the same people might try to attack
other services as well.

Carlos


From ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com  Thu Dec 11 09:01:04 2008
From: ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com (Carlos Konstanski)
Date: Thu, 11 Dec 2008 10:01:04 -0700 (MST)
Subject: [PLUG] Looking for the right rsync command...
In-Reply-To: <1228984700.13305.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1228984700.13305.1.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812110944140.6682@localhost.localdomain>

On Thu, 11 Dec 2008, robinson-west user wrote:

> Date: Thu, 11 Dec 2008 08:38:19 +0000
> From: robinson-west user <plug_1 at robinson-west.com>
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] Looking for the right rsync command...
> 
> rsync -HpogD --exclude /proc --exclude /tmp -exclude /backup -
> alrv / /backup/remote_backup/goose_live/
>
> I want to mirror my live Linux filesystem to another hard drive on a
> remote system.  Can rsync do this for me or is it not compatible with
> files that are changing?

rsync does not "freeze" the filesystem to get a true snapshot in time.
It merely copies files as it comes to them.  One technique that works
reasonably well is to run the command twice.  The second time it will
run a lot faster, thereby narrowing the window of time between the
beginning and end of the command's runtime greatly.

You can get rid of -HpogDlr.  You only need -a, and if you want
verbosity -v, and if you want more verbosity --progress.

I usually use --exclude-from, and put the file in /etc.  My file looks
like this:

/proc
/tmp
/var/tmp/portage
/sys

I'm thinking that /proc and /sys are mount points:

/proc on /proc type proc (rw,nodiratime)
sysfs on /sys type sysfs (rw,nosuid,nodev,noexec)

I would exclude /dev too, if I were sure that there were no persistent
device nodes.  But I'm not.

Even on a busy server, there is probably only small spots on the
filesystem that are changing all that much.  rsync will race right
through those.  but it won't be a perfect snapshot in time.  If that
is what you need, maybe LVM2 snapshots?

Carlos

   I have learned by experience that /dev/console is apparently created anew
each time the system boots. The device is owned by group tty, and I added my

   However, after shutting down the system overnight and rebooting today, I
see that the permissions are returned to root access only. This means that
loadkeys won't run because I don't have root permissions. Annoying.

   What would be the most appropriate way to get past this issue? Perhaps
editing /etc/sudoers to all user me to run loadkeys as root? Would this work
within the .bash_profile script?

   What is particularly frustrating is the non-working loadkeys and xmodmap
are isolated on my notebook. There have been no similar problems with the
server/workstation.

>   I have learned by experience that /dev/console is apparently created anew

> user self to that group, then changed the permissions from crw------- to
> crw-r-----. That worked when I logged out then logged back in.

> see that the permissions are returned to root access only. This means that

> editing /etc/sudoers to all user me to run loadkeys as root? Would this work

>   What is particularly frustrating is the non-working loadkeys and xmodmap
> are isolated on my notebook. There have been no similar problems with the
> server/workstation.

Sounds like udev.  I find a rule for /dev/console in
/etc/udev/rules.d/50-udev-default.rules:

rules.d/50-udev-default.rules:9:KERNEL=="console",              MODE="0600", OPTIONS="last_rule"

This page is a great doc for writing udev rules:

http://reactivated.net/writing_udev_rules.html

I'll bet you'll have the ownership rule figured out in minutes.

Carlos

i'll give second vote for denyhosts.  what i like best about is that
my 20 or so public servers all run it, and once the brute force scan
starts on one IP, it rarely stops before going through all of them,
since some are contiguous addresses.  denyhosts can be configured to
report naughty IP's to a centralized server (yours or theirs--i use
the internet-wide one) and the other servers pick up the message about
it being naughty and deny it before it can start.  my hosts.deny files
on the machines using it are thousands of lines long (but that doesn't
seem to affect the speed of connections, even on some old slow 700mhz
machines).

in the past 3 months, i've seen a couple of attacks from a botnet or
similar--one login attempt per IP from a zillion different IP's, which
denyhosts won't catch with my settings.  fortunately those have been
focused on single servers and i can just disable ssh on an individual
server until the attacks stop.

This looks suspiciously like the .rules files are ordered by their
leading numbers in the same way init scripts are ordered.  Since your
local rules file starts with a lower number, it is probably being run
first, and then is later overritten by the default rules.

What if you rename your 10-local.rules file to 99-local.rules?

> > Date: Thu, 11 Dec 2008 06:49:28 -0800 (PST)
> > From: ron at tymeless-tech.com
> > Is it possible to block an IP after three attempts to login to a
> server???
> >
> > I have a server that I use to host websites for my clients and every once
> > in a while, someone will try to bring it down or at least gain access to
> > it via a brute force attack. Thus, I would like to simply only allow
> three
> > attempts from any one IP address. Once they have failed, block the IP
> > permanently.
> >
> >
>

> Denyhosts does exactly this!  It's a perl script that runs as a daemon
> from /etc/init.d.  It puts IP addresses into hosts.deny after the
> configured number of failed login attempts.
>
> I like to a step further, and disallow password authentication
> entirely.  On my public-facing server, I must use authorized keys.  I
> still run denyhosts though, using ssh as a honeypot to attract the
> undesirables of the internet, for the same people might try to attack
> other services as well.
>


Also look into AllowUsers or AllowGroups in sshd_config as a good addition
to your ssh belt tightening.

to the hard drive.  Perhaps udev doesn't touch already-existing device
nodes.  You might want to boot with knoppix, mount the root partition, and
check.  If it's there, delete it.

The continuing saga:

So far I have determined that cable modems are available from Motorola,
Arris, Linksys and RCA. RCA modems have a horrible reputation with
consumers, so they are scratched off the list. Linksys cable modems all
have wireless routers built in (which I do not need or want). Motorola
seems to have the highest reputation. 

Comcast tells me they are rolling out DOCSIS 3.0 on December 16.
Therefore, it makes sense to get a DOCSIS 3.0 modem. Any DOCSIS 3.0
modem is backwards compatible with DOCSIS 2.0, 1.1 and 1.0. Comcast
gave me a list of modem models, but none are DOCSIS 3.0.

Motorola makes one DOCSIS 3.0  modem for the US market: the model
SB6101.

I can't find anyplace that sells the SB6101. Even Motorola won't sell
me one, as they seem to do only large wholesale lots; no consumer
sales. Arris seems to have some DOCSIS 3.0 modems, but I can't even
figure out which models they are. Not that it matters because
apparently Arris also does wholesale business only.

Local stores sell the Motorola SB5101 only (Circuit City, Fry's, Best
Buy). Enuinc sells no cable modems at all. The SB5101 has an excellent
reputation, but is still just a DOCSIS 2.0 modem. It is the successor t
my SB5100, which lasted me about six years.

Unanswered questions:

If Comcast is rolling out DOCSIS 3.0 on December 16, what happens to
all their current users who have DOCSIS 2.0 modems? Will they see a
speed boost? If so, what would be the point of getting a DOCSIS 3.0
modem? If not, why is Comcast making a big deal in their advertising
about impending speed increases?

The more I figure out the more confused I become.

I could do lookups against the zen.spamhaus.org RBL at work, but not
at home. Do you rely on your ISP's nameservers? Maybe they consider
your ISP "high traffic" and are dropping them.

I've noticed that I can query a spamhaus.org nameserver directly and
get a response, but not via my ISP's nameservers, FWIW:

~ dyoung$ dig @r.ns.spamhaus.org +short in a 2.0.0.127.zen.spamhaus.org
127.0.0.2
127.0.0.10
127.0.0.4
~ dyoung$ dig +short in a 2.0.0.127.zen.spamhaus.org
;; connection timed out; no servers could be reached

John Jason Jordan wrote:

> If Comcast is rolling out DOCSIS 3.0 on December 16, what happens to
> all their current users who have DOCSIS 2.0 modems? Will they see a
> speed boost? If so, what would be the point of getting a DOCSIS 3.0
> modem? If not, why is Comcast making a big deal in their advertising
> about impending speed increases?

They're rolling out a service that doesn't yet have products to market 
that match it. That's why you can't buy the modems yet. Nothing will 
happen to the 2.0 modem users. They will get their speed boost as 
advertised.

DOCSIS 2.0 supports speeds well beyond anything Comcast offers right 
now. I recommend getting a Toshiba. I had one when using Comcast for 
years and it was rock solid. I might have to move back over to them. 
They have a business package for $70 that is 12Mb/2Mb after the speed 
increase with 5 statics.

- m0gely

Message-ID: <20081211194842.135f16fc.johnxj@comcast.net>

On Thu, 11 Dec 2008 19:17:34 -0800
"drew wymore" <drew.wymore at gmail.com> dijo:

> Download an ISO via HTTP instead of Torrent and see what happens to the
> connection or see if you can use a proxy for your traffic to hide it from
> any sniffing Comcast is doing. You'll be taxing it then. Pick a fast mirror
> like kernel.org.

That was already suggested, and I did it. I downloaded the Edubuntu
addons from cat.pdx.edu directly instead of via torrent (3-400 MB each)
and they downloaded without issue.

But when using torrents you have dozens if not hundreds of connections.
Plus, (I don't understand this well) there is a lot of back and forth
to the tracker. I haven't been using torrents for the past 24 hours and
my connection has been fine. But when downloading Fedora recently I had
500 connections per torrent and I was downloading/uploading four
torrents - no problem at all. Now I can't maintain even ten connections
per torrent for just two torrents without getting disconnected.

Something has changed. 

Add the fact that when using Ktorrent I first got disconnected every 12
hours or so. Now I get disconnected every 15 minutes. The degradation
has been a straight line. If Comcast was throttling torrents I would
assume it would be an all or nothing situation, not a gradual
degradation in service. 

And one other matter - if you google on cable modem problems you will
find dozens of posts from consumers whose modems failed. And just about
every one says they had to recycle the modem more and more often until
finally they couldn't restore the connection at all. The symptoms echo
what is happening to me.

I can't be sure it's the modem, but it is six years old and all fingers
are pointing at it, yelling "j'accuse!"

So I may be posting later that I was completely wrong. But for the
moment the #1 suspect is the modem. Maybe Microsoft has an investment
in Motorola, so it has a feature which makes it die after so many Linux
downloads. :)

It looks like the best option at the moment is a Motorola SB5101. I'm
off to buy one on eBay or wheverever.

Just an update on my thoughts.

John, could be the modem (I wasn't convinced at first). As I mentioned I was
suffering a similar situation using different gear. Thinking I was being
Sanvined by Qwest I tunneled everything through SSH and still had some weird
issues. I found a new firmware image for the Actiontec CPE I am using and it
seems like at least tunneled torrents are being downloaded properly without
issue. I haven't tried to test without using a tunneled proxy set up yet
though, that will answer at least my question. The new firmware did
anecdotally make a difference though.

After further googling I discovered that owners of Linksys CM100 modems
love them, especially those who switched from a Motorola modem. So I
found one locally and talked them into $55 for it. It took some hassle
to get Comcast to recognize it because the idiot forgot to tell his
software that it should no longer be looking for a Motorola.

I have to say that it seems significantly faster. Whether that was due
to the degraded condition of the old modem or what I cannot say. A lot
of people have reported significantly faster speeds with the CM100
compared to the Motorola SB5101 and SB5120, even when both are brand
new.

Anyway, the saga is at an end. (I hope.)

I purchased a Motorola SB5101 modem today and I called Comcast to update my 
modem's MAC address. I plugged the new modem in and it started up before I 
called Comcast support.  Once I got through all of the phone menus I got a 
rep on the phone.  With the status page showing my new modem was operational 
I gave the guy my new MAC address.  It didn't show up on their system and so 
he made me connect my old modem again. It showed I was operational as it 
showed up their network.

I was glad I was persistent and so I told him I wanted to reconnect the new 
modem again and power it up. It finally showed up on their network with the 
assigned MAC address. He set it up and told me it was going to reboot and 
once I rebooted my hardware router everything was working again.

My download speeds are quite a bit faster and peak out at around 6mbps now. 
Now I need to return my Comcast owned modem or I'll keep getting charged 
$3.00 a month. Cable modems are pretty cheap now and so I've wasted quite a 
bit of money for renting a modem for nearly 9 years now.

What ATSC format(s)?  Some of the cards don't support the ATSC QAM format
needed to pick up unencrypted signals from cable.

I have a Haupagge HVR-950 that is plug and play with Ubuntu Intrepid
(previous releases required compiling the driver manually).  However, the
HVR-950 only supports broadcast HDTV and the analog tuner conflicts with
other Happauge PVR-150 cards and the analog tuner audio doesn't work.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Dec 14 15:54:34 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun, 14 Dec 2008 15:54:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] booting from a compact flash card
Message-ID: <20081214235433.GA3414@gate.kl-ic.com>


I'm using compact flash cards as the boot drive for an ALIX
single board computer.  I'm also looking at building a new
computer for my wife's office, where quiet and power savings
are important, and booting from a CF card might be an option.

Saturday (not as crowded as you might expect), Fry's was
selling Kingston 8GB 133x CF cards for $20, marked down from
the normal $50 .  This is about 500x more storage than the
ALIX will need, but it is a pretty good size for a small
Ubuntu system.  

I connected the card through a $20 SYBA IDE to CF adapter.
I installed Hardy 8.04.1, and it worked, more or less (it is
faster than the CD, but slower than a disk, based on subjective
impressions).

But it does work.  My wife uses her office machine for browsing
and email and some documents (stored on another server).  I may
buy a 32GB card (they are under $100 at Newegg), but 8GB seems
to be enough.  

OTOH, there are SATA-II 30GB solid state drives (no adapter
necessary) for $75 after rebate at Newegg, and those run at
170MB/s read - apps would come up blazingly fast.  By the time
I actually build the system. the drives will probably be even
larger and cheaper.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

I built a system based on the D201GLYL2 (celeron based, not atom) board I
picked up from Iguana Micro (locally in Hillsboro), about a year ago.
Including a GeForce 6200 and a 60-80 or so watt 12V DC/DC power supply, the
entire system draws maybe 40 watt from the wall plug at full-load.  (most of
that is the video card).  Can even play halflife 2 at 1920x1080 on low to
mid settings, so I'd assume the processors are plenty fast for what the
average user would need.

-Eitan-

From eitan.tsur at gmail.com  Sun Dec 14 16:15:12 2008
From: eitan.tsur at gmail.com (Eitan Tsur)
Date: Sun, 14 Dec 2008 16:15:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] booting from a compact flash card
In-Reply-To: <20081214235433.GA3414@gate.kl-ic.com>

Message-ID: <7ae7d1de0812141615g5efdef39t1157b3ee913e0b76@mail.gmail.com>

Beware of the SSD's.  Read the reviews.  Some drives do NOT work well on
filesystems that require frequent writes.  I'd read one review that said
that using reiser worked very well, however EXT3 performance on the same
drive was absolutely horrid.  Gotta do your research.

In-Reply-To: <7ae7d1de0812141615g5efdef39t1157b3ee913e0b76@mail.gmail.com>

On Sun, Dec 14, 2008 at 04:15:12PM -0800, Eitan Tsur wrote:
> Beware of the SSD's.  Read the reviews.  Some drives do NOT work well on
> filesystems that require frequent writes.  I'd read one review that said
> that using reiser worked very well, however EXT3 performance on the same
> drive was absolutely horrid.  Gotta do your research.

Good points.  Thanks for the feedback.

Of course, it is good to move caches and /tmp to RAM and set the
noatime option in /etc/fstab .  I found more useful ideas here:

http://tombuntu.com/index.php/2008/09/04/four-tweaks-for-using-linux-with-solid-state-drives/

Are there other pages I should be looking at?

I used ReiserFS for some systems, but I did not have good luck
with it - it was fast, but it did not handle disk errors well. 
And I worry about my wife's safety with Reiser around :-). 
Your mileage may vary, of course. 

I will have to think about ext2 vs. ext3 vs. "other".  I expect I
will set up a boot partition with ext2 (journalling is not needed
if the files don't change much), and use some solid-state-friendly
file system such as jffs2 for the main partition (or at least
/home and /var).  More to learn...

Keith

> On Mon, Dec 15, 2008 at 8:48 AM, Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> wrote:
> > I will have to think about ext2 vs. ext3 vs. "other".  I expect I

> > if the files don't change much), and use some solid-state-friendly

On Mon, Dec 15, 2008 at 09:46:53AM +0800, Cheng Renquan wrote:
> The Linux 2.6.27 has a
> 
> UBIFS is a new filesystem designed to work with flash devices,
> developed by Nokia with help of the University of Szeged
> 
> http://kernelnewbies.org/Linux_2_6_27
> 
> http://www.linux-mtd.infradead.org/doc/ubifs.html
> 
> Think you can try it.

Interesting to know about - but UBIFS is designed to work with
raw flash memory devices, such as the ones in PDAs and cell
phones, not memory products with built-in controllers like
Compact Flash Cards (CF) and Solid State Drives (SSD).  Unless
there is some way to bypass the controller and get at the raw
memory at the erase block level (128Kb or more) I can't use
UBIFS.  Here is "The Big Red Note" from the second document:

   One thing people have to understand when dealing with UBIFS is
   that UBIFS is very different to any traditional file system -
   it does not work on top of block devices (like hard drives,
   MMC/SD cards, USB flash drives, SSDs, etc). UBIFS was designed
   to work on top of raw flash, which has nothing to do with block
   devices. This is why UBIFS does not work on MMC cards or USB
   flash drives - they look like block devices to the outside
   world because they implement FTL (Flash Translation Layer)
   support in hardware, which simply speaking emulates a block
   device on top of the built-in flash chip.

I will be working with either Compact Flash (which has an IDE
parallel interface) or with a SATAII solid state drive.  Those
have built-in controllers and block level ATA interfaces.  
Since UBIFS looks like "The Best Way To Do It", there will
hopefully be standards and devices available in the next few
years that support the raw flash interface, permitting the
use of UBIFS at the consumer level.  

Thanks for the pointer, though.  If I ever work with a device
that provides direct access to the flash (I imagine that
reprogrammable wireless access points, the Google Android,
and other open platforms do) then UBIFS will be very useful.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993

On Sun, 2008-12-14 at 16:15 -0800, Eitan Tsur wrote:
> Beware of the SSD's.  Read the reviews.  Some drives do NOT work well on
> filesystems that require frequent writes.  I'd read one review that said
> that using reiser worked very well, however EXT3 performance on the same
> drive was absolutely horrid.  Gotta do your research.
> 

Interesting stuff. This bit from an Acer Aspire Wiki concurs:
http://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Acer_Aspire_One 

"Solid state drives are made of flash memory, they are fast in reading
but slow in writing data and you cannot overwrite countless times, so
for a long SSD life take care to:

     1. Never choose to use a journaling file system on the SSD
        partitions.
     2. Never use a swap partition on the SSD.
     3. Edit your new installation fstab to mount the SSD partitions
        "noatime".
     4. Never log messages or error log to the SSD.

These rules ensure that we won't reach the maximum limit of writes on
our SSD faster than we should."

Thanks,
Mike



From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Dec 14 21:20:53 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun, 14 Dec 2008 21:20:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Booting from a USB Thumb Drive
Message-ID: <20081215052053.GA4105@gate.kl-ic.com>


While playing with compact flash cards for hard disk replacement, I
also built Ubuntu on top of a 4GB USB thumb drive attached to my
Thinkpad T30.  The T30 has a USB1.1 interface, and is dreadfully slow
with a flash drive - 5 minutes to boot and login to the desktop. 

I plan to use a flash drive as my OpenVPN certification environment.
Running offline and booting from the flash, I can sign keys for VPN
clients without exposing the process to The Bad Guys.  I then copy
the keys to the hard drive, boot normally, and distribute the keys to
the appropriate machines.  If I was extra paranoid, I could boot each
target machine from the thumb drive and copy one key each, offline.

Perhaps there is an easier way to do it.  I don't want to sign
keys with an online machine, I don't want to maintain a whole
offline computer, and 4GB thumb drives are less than $10 and easily
carried around.  I can keep a couple of spares locked in my safe.

Keith

On Sun, Dec 14, 2008 at 3:54 PM, Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> wrote:
>
> I'm using compact flash cards as the boot drive for an ALIX
> single board computer.  I'm also looking at building a new
> computer for my wife's office, where quiet and power savings
> are important, and booting from a CF card might be an option.
>
> Saturday (not as crowded as you might expect), Fry's was
> selling Kingston 8GB 133x CF cards for $20, marked down from
> the normal $50 .  This is about 500x more storage than the
> ALIX will need, but it is a pretty good size for a small
> Ubuntu system.
>
> I connected the card through a $20 SYBA IDE to CF adapter.
> I installed Hardy 8.04.1, and it worked, more or less (it is
> faster than the CD, but slower than a disk, based on subjective
> impressions).
>
> But it does work.  My wife uses her office machine for browsing
> and email and some documents (stored on another server).  I may
> buy a 32GB card (they are under $100 at Newegg), but 8GB seems
> to be enough.
>
> OTOH, there are SATA-II 30GB solid state drives (no adapter
> necessary) for $75 after rebate at Newegg, and those run at
> 170MB/s read - apps would come up blazingly fast.  By the time
> I actually build the system. the drives will probably be even
> larger and cheaper.
>

When using CompactFlash as a drive, it can be a good idea to get the
faster cards.  There are 266x and 300x cards which cost a little more
but greatly improve the performance.  266x is 40 MB/s which is getting
closer to the performance of a slow hard drive.

One advantage I discovered is that the CompactFlash card can be
written with a card reader on another machine.  This was very handy
when putting together a machine without a CD or floppy drive.

 - Ian

setting up the BIOS, is considers removable devices to equate to
floppy disks - a USB thumb drive is considered a hard disk, and
always the second one unless I go into BIOS setup before every
boot and swap the boot order of the drives.  Which, I assume,
is wearing out the NVRAM in the laptop.  Fooey.

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Dec 15 13:03:37 2008
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Mon, 15 Dec 2008 13:03:37 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ANNOUNCEMENT PLUG Advanced Topics December 17th 2008
Message-ID: <1229375017.6133.6.camel@rotwang.fnordora.org>

PLUG Advanced Topics Meeting
December 17th, 2008  7pm

Jax Bar
826 SW 2nd Ave
Portland, OR 97204
(503) 228-9128

Speaker:     Eric Wilhelm <scratchcomputing at gmail.com>

Codeless GUI Programming
  A Declarative Syntax Layer for Desktop Graphical User Interfaces

This will be the world premiere of a game-changing advancement in the 
development of desktop graphical user interfaces (GUIs).  FreeTUIT 
removes the verbosity, tedium, and confusion from GUI development and 
provides a unified syntax for widget layout and configuration which 
supports good software design practice without getting in the way of 
rapid application development.

FreeTUIT is a syntax and runtime for concisely declaring the layout and 
configuration of GUI widgets (such as forms, toolbars, buttons, and 
dialogs).  The freetuit interpreter drives a unified object layer which 
is accessible from event callbacks.  This takes you from a blank page 
to a static demo of the layout with zero setup and allows desktop 
applications to be developed and deployed faster than web applications 
by simply removing the HTML, CSS, XML, HTTP, Javascript, Database, 
Network, and User Agent components.

Jax is next to the 2nd Ave Max stop, so you don't need to park at the
downtown icerink.

nope, that is where it should be.  however, i can't tell where it came
from--that file doesn't appear to be owned by any package though that
directory is multiply-owned.  below are the php-related packages i
have installed for my successful apache2/php5 hardy server.  obviously
you won't need curl, gd, mcrypt, mysql, or pgsql, unless you do =)  i
think that libapache2-mod-php5 is the most likely missing candidate,
and after you install him, you may need to use a2enmod(8) to inform
your apache install about it.

i've also noticed that using the apache2ctl utility to muck with
apache does not always do the right thing, for instance, when changing
certain config directives (ssl-related for the most part) and other
configuration settings re: modules, so you might want to do an
old-school /etc/init.d/apache2 restart instead of an apache2ctl
graceful or whatever your norm is.

Gentoo is nice because it has a very modular way of arranging the config. 
That makes it easy for me to copy and paste everything you need to get
apache to run PHP correctly.  It doesn't matter which distro you are
using, this stuff doesn't change hardly at all.  The <IfDefine PHP5> may
not apply directly; gentoo passes -D PHP5 into apache on the command line.

You will definitely need the LoadModule and AddType lines.  The
DirectoryIndex makes it so that any directory you visit with an index.php
or index.phtml file will cause it to be automatically run.

<IfDefine PHP5>
    # Load the module first
    <IfModule !mod_php5.c>
        LoadModule php5_module    modules/libphp5.so
    </IfModule>

    # Set it to handle the files
    <IfModule mod_mime.c>
        AddType application/x-httpd-php .php
        AddType application/x-httpd-php .phtml
        AddType application/x-httpd-php .php3
        AddType application/x-httpd-php .php4
        AddType application/x-httpd-php .php5
        AddType application/x-httpd-php-source .phps
    </IfModule>

    DirectoryIndex index.php index.phtml
</IfDefine>

Once you are done putting this into your apache config (or simply figuring
out how to turn it on, as with the gentoo -D PHP5 command line switch),
don't forget to pay a visit to your php.ini file.

Carlos

> configuration of GUI widgets (such as forms, toolbars, buttons, and
> dialogs).  The freetuit interpreter drives a unified object layer which
> is accessible from event callbacks.  This takes you from a blank page
> to a static demo of the layout with zero setup and allows desktop
> applications to be developed and deployed faster than web applications

Also available here for $300:

http://www.amazon.com/Intel-Processor-Drive-Linux-Black/dp/B001HPNDJ2/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&s=pc&qid=1229391808&sr=1-2

This looks pretty tasty.  Perhaps you can bring it to one of the
meetings and (with warning) I can look at it with my power meter,
and in general admire your purchasing acumen.  If you bring it to
the clinic, we can start it up with available monitors and keyboards.

Something so small presents a theft hazard (it is for my doctor
wife, who has patients with mental as well as physical problems)
but it supposedly will attach to the back of her LCD monitor.
Thieves must be very large and very ambitious to steal the monitor,
too.  It is also nifty that these are claimed to boot in a few
seconds, meaning that the machine can be quickly turned on and
off between uses, saving even more power.   Perhaps this is only
with the installed EZOS Linux distro (whatever that is).

It was offputting at first to see that it doesn't have a CD/DVD
drive.  External USB drives are surprisingly expensive, but I have
a USB case and a bare CD/DVD drive I can cobble together for the
rare occasions one is needed.  During the 99% of the time that an
internal CD drive is NOT being used, it just wastes space and power.

I asked my wife how often she uses the drive in her current office
machine (which the new system will replace) and she said "never,
I'm afraid to use it".  So perhaps I shouldn't worry about it.

On Mon, Dec 15, 2008 at 07:26:21PM -0800, Eitan Tsur wrote:
> Yeah, those look about the same size as what I built.  Same price too.
> Granted, no assembly required for the Eee's.  Are those using the dual-core

> consider availability of (I assume) proprietary power supplies if it's
> internal).  Also, some of these small cases have a laptop tether slot so you
> can lock them to your desk, etc...

What started this thread for me was working with an ALIX board from
PC Engines, running the flash-optimized OpenWRT.  Using a CF card
with JFFS for mass storage, these consume 3 to 4 watts, and the full
kit costs less than $200 (and a heck of a lot of time to configure)
from Netgate.com .

I will be using mine for a firewall, OpenVPN, DNS, DHCP, etc. 
The ALIX uses an AMD Geode with a built-in crypto engine, so it
runs AES encryption faster than its 500MHz clock would imply.

I'm not sure ALIX boards make good email servers - flash writes
relatively slowly.  But if you keep your email forever, like I do,
then flash seems as good a way as any to do so.  With volatile
files and queues stored in ramdisk you are not limited by flash
write time, but there is a risk of losing messages during power
failures.  On the other hand, at 4 watts, a small battery backup
unit will last a long time.

The ALIX has a connector for a 2.5 inch hard drive instead of a
CF card, but the power would go up and it probably would not fit
in the metal case that Netgate offers.  The ALIX does not have a
connector for video, though the Geode chip has video outputs.

For an interactive desktop system, I want a faster processor, and
the Atom-based machines look right for that.

PTP plans to standardize on these, so there will be a lot of local
knowledge around here.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993

From eitan.tsur at gmail.com  Mon Dec 15 23:04:02 2008
From: eitan.tsur at gmail.com (Eitan Tsur)
Date: Mon, 15 Dec 2008 23:04:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] low power desktops
In-Reply-To: <49473963.50700@cesmail.net>
References: <mailman.173.1229308235.32024.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
	<20081215164158.GW22039@onyx.spiritone.com>
	<20081216031034.GA8464@gate.kl-ic.com> <49473963.50700@cesmail.net>
Message-ID: <7ae7d1de0812152304g3a9573d3h2e5b641a04daa4f0@mail.gmail.com>

Nice.  Yeah, with the Atom stuff you are never gonna get to that low of
power....  The chips run at about 4-8 watt, but the northbridges consume
something around 20 IIRC...  Still, for a mini-itx board with onboard video
and CPU under 100 bucks, the Atom boards are pretty enticing.  Obviously
when they come out with lower-power boards next year sometime it won't be
too expensive to upgrade and get better power efficiency...  And plus, at
this power range, they sell DC/DC power supplies that run off of 12 volts.
Meaning you can run one of these off a car battery for quite a while...  (In
an emergency, of course).

Note that these AV attachments are essentially pointless.  What's to stop a
virus from adding them?  Even if they were digitally signed, there's no
way for the recipient to verify it.  These are just free advertisements
for the AV companies that fill up our intertubes.

Anyway, it's kinda weird that the mailing list didn't at least bounce
those messages back to you with an explanation, if this indeed was the
cause...

From eitan.tsur at gmail.com  Tue Dec 16 18:42:33 2008
From: eitan.tsur at gmail.com (Eitan Tsur)
Date: Tue, 16 Dec 2008 18:42:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Playstation II and Linux...
In-Reply-To: <49484ACD.5020709@robinson-west.com>
References: <49484ACD.5020709@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <7ae7d1de0812161842w114807c0r90e8a35f881a69c7@mail.gmail.com>

To run unsigned code on the PS2's you're gonna want (as with most sony
products that have various versions) either an old-model "fat" ps2, or a
modchip, maybe both.  Preferrably a good one, which can cost up to 60
bucks.  There's various ways of doing the hacks to get it booting, but yeah.

-Eitan-

From larry.brigman at gmail.com  Tue Dec 16 19:42:25 2008
From: larry.brigman at gmail.com (Larry Brigman)
Date: Tue, 16 Dec 2008 19:42:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] rpm source package building
Message-ID: <ca5165530812161942p54582d52x3b5eba11a3cbafdf@mail.gmail.com>

My goggle foo is not doing too well in finding an answer to this
question (if there is an easy one).

My problem:

I need to build source rpm packages from tarballs that are not in any
distribution (newer versions,
custom patches).  I do plan to build  the binary rpm in a chroot to
isolate the build dependencies via
a build package called mock.  The problem is that mock needs a
prebuild source rpm.

The other half of the problem is that when building the source rpm,
rpmbuild does a check of
the Buildrequires packages before it build the package.  These are
only needed when building
the binary package not the source package.

Is there a method to construct the source rpm without it requiring all
of the Buildrequires packages being
installed on the system that is building the source package?

In my example case curl-7.19.2 on CentOS5.2/RHEL5.2/OL5.2:
[lbrigman at myhost SPECS]$ rpmbuild -bs curl.spec
error: Failed build dependencies:
        openssl-devel is needed by curl-7.19.2-1.x86_64
        libidn-devel is needed by curl-7.19.2-1.x86_64
[lbrigman at myhost SPECS]$
[lbrigman at myhost SPECS]$ uname -a
Linux area51 2.6.18-92.1.6.el5 #1 SMP Fri Jun 20 02:36:06 EDT 2008
x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
[lbrigman at myhost SPECS]$

There are others that are more of a problem that this.

[lbrigman at myhost SPECS]$ rpmbuild --version
RPM version 4.4.2

From eitan.tsur at gmail.com  Tue Dec 16 21:06:16 2008
From: eitan.tsur at gmail.com (Eitan Tsur)
Date: Tue, 16 Dec 2008 21:06:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Playstation II and Linux...
In-Reply-To: <49487EFF.7030601@robinson-west.com>
References: <49484ACD.5020709@robinson-west.com>
	<7ae7d1de0812161842w114807c0r90e8a35f881a69c7@mail.gmail.com>
	<49487D81.4050807@robinson-west.com>
	<49487EFF.7030601@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <7ae7d1de0812162106i1dc88980ga41627ab4f4876e5@mail.gmail.com>

To run a disk it needs a special security measure pressed into the disk (at
manufacture) around the hub, before the data area.  Without this, the PS2
won't run whatever is on it.  There's exploits to get around sony's
lockdowns, IE: a modchip.  Basically you install a device that taps into the
busses for the PS2 and screws with the signals to trick the PS2 into
ignoring it's own security "features".  Depends what you use it for and what
the latest court results are as far as modchip use legality; I don't know,
and have not researched it.  Regardless, if I had the money and could
legally buy one, I'd probably do so, just because I don't like being limited
by the device's manufacturer.  There's other exploits for the fats like
using a specially crafted memory card save (which you can install yourself
for free) and a PS1 disk to trigger the running of unsigned-by-sony code,
and if you'd like I can provide info on it.  Basically if you can run
unsigned-by-sony code, you can do whatever you want, including run Linux,
say, from a burned CD/DVD or the fat's hard drive.  ...By the way, turns out
you can put up to a 500 gig drive in the old ones, so long as it matches one
of the models in a list somewheres.  Again, if you are interested I'll find
the links for you.

From lnxknight at gmail.com  Wed Dec 17 09:05:59 2008
From: lnxknight at gmail.com (Matt McKenzie)
Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2008 09:05:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] To mod or not to mod...
In-Reply-To: <49492856.60000@robinson-west.com>
References: <49492856.60000@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <da2207740812170905p53f81225m202377ff2741466e@mail.gmail.com>

Uhm a laptop for the price of just a mod chip???  As in around $50?  Or do
you mean the price of a PS2 + mod chip ($100-200)?
In that case you are in a more realistic ballpark, for a good old PIII or
single core Centrino from Craigslist or eBay (or FreeGeek).

One example: http://portland.craigslist.org/wsc/sys/961025874.html
Another: http://portland.craigslist.org/mlt/sys/959962765.html

Old Dells are usually a safe bet for Linux, I have an old PII-200 Latitude
D300xt that runs Debian with Fluxbox or XFCE quite well.
PII era stuff would usually not have any built in networking (wifi or
ethernet), only modem, I use a PCMCIA ethernet card in it now.  PIII era
stuff should have ethernet and probably 802.11b, or maybe 802.11g depending
on the age.  Also look into old Thinkpads, similarly very good with Linux
usually.

Another possibility is an old PPC iBook or Powerbook, I have a couple old
Powerbooks, a G4 running OS X Leopard and Ubuntu dual boot, and an older G3
running Ubuntu.  G3 era has built in ethernet but not wifi, G4 era has
both.  Ubuntu doesn't "officially" support PPC anymore but it is now a
community version, other distros still do officially support it such as
Fedora.

At any rate good luck with it :).

----------
Matt M.
LinuxKnight

Well, PS2's are around 60-80 used, and then considering you DON'T have to do
the modchip route, just use the savegame FMCB (Free MemoryCard Boot)
exploit, I doubt you can find a laptop that cheap.  A laptop WOULD probably
be the better route to go though, in my opinion.  Just saying, there's ways
to get your consumer devices to bend to your will...  Furthermore, you could
buy a consumer disk such as Swap Magic, and run everything that way, without
opening the "do not remove under penalty of soul removal" warranty
sticker(s) on your device.

   I have an nVidia GeForce 6150 board and use the nVidia driver with it.
This works with my Acer 19" wide screen monitor at 1440x900 dpi.

> Where should I start to solve this problem? Any clues?

   Look at /var/log/Xorg.0.log.

   Also, a trick I just recently learned is to run (as root), 'X --configure'
and use test the resulting xorg.conf to see if it does better.

Bring your Linux desktop or laptop to the Linux Clinic, 1pm to
5pm, Sunday December 21 (always the 3rd Sunday) at Free Geek,
1731 S.E. 10th in Portland.  We have wired and wireless internet,
monitors, keyboards, mice, coffee, and cookies (bring more!).

et cetera ...


We have a few more days of cold weather coming.  I still want
to help make the Linux Clinic happen Sunday, and if John shows
up with the key, and the power is on, we have pretty much all
we need, even if Free Geek doesn't open the store as planned.

Who knows?  If it is cold enough, we might get a visit from 
Tux the Penguin.  Bring herring, just in case.

I will be coming in over the West Hills from Beaverton, and
that may take two hours longer than normal each way.  Unlike
an evening meeting, it will be light for most of the trip, and
it will be easier to get rescued if something goes wrong.
Traffic will be light, and I have 4 wheel drive and chains.

I have two requests.  One, if you are expecting me to bring 
something (like a particular bit of hardware or software or
documentation) let me know at the email below. 

Second,  please suggest nearby places serving food and warm
libations after the clinic; that will be optional, but if some
of us are stuck waiting for transit or towing, or merely facing
a long cold journey home, fortification will be beneficial.
Verify that they will be open and get taxi coordinates, please!

If the clinic does not come off at Free Geek, I probably can
open my home in Beaverton for three or four really determined
problem solving participants, especially folks coming from a
long distance.  We can make arrangements off line - send 
email please.

Keith

Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> What do you call the icon [that show up in the browser], and where [d]o I go to look for specs, such as height and width, and what format it needs to be?
>   

I have another example of my reply not making it to the list. Here's a 
summary of my experience so far:

Thanks to you all. Your info led me to Google favicon.ico with Google's 
Linux specific search. One of the sites I found told me how to make a 
.ico file from a Gimp image:

http://linuxproblem.org/art_19.html

Another site told me how to tell Apache to use the icon:

http://robert.grefstad.com/linux/apache_favicon.html

So, I created a 16 x 16 image with the GIMP, saved it as  a .pnm file, 
and installed and then ran:

ppmtowinicon -output favicon.ico favicon.pnm

I put a copy in /srv/www, and added a line to /etc/apache2/httpd.conf:

AddType image/x-icon .ico
 
I restarted apache and reloaded my local home page. But, no favicon.

I also tried uploading my favicon.ico to my hosted site. No favicon when 
I go to that site, either.

Any ideas on what step I might have missed?

www.dicksteffens.com

directly at the favicon.ico file itself via URL.  That will make your
browser start paying attention to it.

Heh.  All kidding aside, post-clinic dinnerists are going to be
cold and some will need to be alert for hazardous driving.  Cold
beer may make them drive hazardously.   Most of the Lab's food
is unheated as well, just soup and rice bowls for hot food.

when cold.  I only know three or 4 places nearby, of dubious
openness, but I'm sure locals can suggest far more.

Coffee, Tea, Hot Cocoa, Hot Spiced Cider (and microwaved Jolt
Cola) might be the beverages needed.  If Jarra's was open and
served such, then the combination of hot stimulant liquids and
Ethiopian pyro-cuisine might heat the environment sufficiently
to steam the ice off the road.

Your experience is just like mine always is.  It simply takes a lot of
coaxing to get the favicon to start working.  Eventually it will start
working for everyone who visits your site, after enough time has
passed and things fall out of cache.  Not sure why the makers of
modern web browsers find it so important to cache a 16x16 image that
can be delivered in the payload of a single packet.

If you think firefox caches overzealously, try seamonkey.  (This is a
sarcastic remark.)

Carlos

On Wed, 17 Dec 2008, David Kaplan wrote:

> I would have to install it. but I can't see the bottom of some windows where
> you have to click next.

David,

   If you visit the nVidia web site and download the linux driver for your
card, it installs in text mode. You untar the download and end up with a
file having an extension of .run. For my card I have a file called
NVIDIA-Linux-x86-177.82-pkg1.run. As root, invoke it and an ncurses
interface comes up in the middle of the monitor screen.

   Accept the license, respond appropriately to the other prompts, and it
will be installed for you. Check, using lsmod, and you should see something
like this:

nvidia               6904916  0

   This works for me. If you go this route, keep that *.run file because you
may need to reinstall it each time you reboot the machine. I've no idea why,
but it's a small enough price to pay.

Good luck,

Rich

>> I would have to install it. but I can't see the bottom of some windows where

> David,
>
>   If you visit the nVidia web site and download the linux driver for your
> card, it installs in text mode. You untar the download and end up with a
> file having an extension of .run. For my card I have a file called
> NVIDIA-Linux-x86-177.82-pkg1.run. As root, invoke it and an ncurses
> interface comes up in the middle of the monitor screen.

>   Accept the license, respond appropriately to the other prompts, and it
> will be installed for you. Check, using lsmod, and you should see something
> like this:
>
> nvidia               6904916  0
>
>   This works for me. If you go this route, keep that *.run file because you
> may need to reinstall it each time you reboot the machine. I've no idea why,
> but it's a small enough price to pay.

> Good luck,

> Rich

Not to confuse the issue, but you probably should know about this.
The 2.6.28 kernel contains changes that break both nvidia and fglrx
drivers.  Nvivia has a patch; perhaps ati does too.  Testing with vesa
will certainly circumvent this issue.  2.6.28 is super-nosebleed, but
you did mention fedora.

One reason that you might have to rerun the nvidia driver each reboot
is because you might be using a distro kernel, and have no
/lib/modules/`uname -r` directory.  That's where the module goes when
compiled.  Mine is in /lib/modules/2.6.26.7/video/nvidia.ko.  Building
a custom kernel is one way to ensure that all the parts are there.

Carlos

>> and goes nowhere. MInt, Ubuntu, both will boot up but the resolution says

>> Where should I start to solve this problem? Any clues?
>>     
>
>    Look at /var/log/Xorg.0.log.
>
>    Also, a trick I just recently learned is to run (as root), 'X --configure'
> and use test the resulting xorg.conf to see if it does better.
>
> Rich
>
>   
I ran into the fglrx problem on my Fedora 9 upgrade.  I wanted the flgrx 
driver for dual monitor use.  I found a workaround using the xrandr 
command from Intel.  Read about it at 
http://intellinuxgraphics.org/dualhead.html.

Ken

From griffint at pobox.com  Wed Dec 17 23:39:14 2008
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed, 17 Dec 2008 23:39:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] localhost
In-Reply-To: <1229584924.13301.17.camel@localhost>
References: <1229581109.13301.2.camel@localhost>
	<e2aeccd60812172300q3788b82fjca9d6cefa6acc02@mail.gmail.com>
	<1229584924.13301.17.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <200812172339.14929.griffint@pobox.com>

On Wednesday 17 December 2008 11:22 pm, linux-yug wrote:
> On Wed, 2008-12-17 at 23:00 -0800, drew wymore wrote:
> > You want to ping 127.0.0.1 which is the local loopback on the nic
>
> Well, I think you said the magic word loopback....  I do associate
> loopback with localhost.. but, does it loopback through the nic or not?
>
>
> Wondering.
>

No physical NIC is associate with the loopback address. It goes through
a separate logical NIC named "lo", not the "eth0" or "wlan0" associated
with your physical NIC.

Side point - With Linux, when pinging the host's own IP address, even
one that is associated with a physical NIC, the packets do not actually
go though the NIC. The kernel is smart enough to realize that the IP
address is it's own, and it shortcuts the packet's route.

Terry

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Dec 18 07:27:40 2008
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] localhost

	<e2aeccd60812172300q3788b82fjca9d6cefa6acc02@mail.gmail.com>
	<1229584924.13301.17.camel@localhost>
	<200812172339.14929.griffint@pobox.com>
	<1229586984.13301.22.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <alpine.OSX.2.00.0812180723230.6407@guild.galois.com>

On Wed, 17 Dec 2008, linux-yug wrote:

> So if you want to actually test the nic..
>
> You need to at least ping the gateway or another node???

See the ethtool(8) man page for info about using it to test an 
ethernet card, e.g.,

# ethtool --test eth0
The test result is FAIL
The test extra info:
Register test  (offline)         0
Eeprom test    (offline)         0
Interrupt test (offline)         0
Loopback test  (offline)         0
Link test   (on/offline)         1

In this case, the test failed because there's no cable connected, so 
the "Link test" returned an error code (1). All 0's is what you want 
to see.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> http://www.madboa.com/

All operating systems with a TCP/IP stack have some means to support
the loopback IP address of 127.0.0.1 but they don't necessarily implement
it the same way as in Linux. But in no case should it involve or require a
physical NIC. That would be a bug.

Terry

> > I had to do an ifconfig  and actually look at lo, after you brought it
> > up, to see it......After ignoring it for years.....
> >
> >
> > I hate to ask but, is there something similar in Windows??
> >
> 
> All operating systems with a TCP/IP stack have some means to support
> the loopback IP address of 127.0.0.1 but they don't necessarily implement
> it the same way as in Linux. But in no case should it involve or require a
> physical NIC. That would be a bug.
> 
> Terry


Thanks

linux-yug

On Thu, Dec 18, 2008 at 10:12:43AM -0800, David Kaplan wrote:
> How do I install Fedora 10 in safe mode? I was thinking that if I go in as
> safe mode I can install and Nvidia drivers that are needed for this mboard.

Some tricks when the video is flaky:

1) Install in text mode - most distros have an option for this.
2) Try a live CD or two.
3) "Control-Alt-F1" for a text screen.  "Control-Alt-F7" back to graphics.
4) "Control-Alt-BS" - back to the login screen 
5) SSH from another machine (if SSHD is running the firewall is off)

The Free Geek store has plenty of older video cards for $5-$20 .
Get 2 or 3, find the varieties that work.

Most of the super-powerful video cards for sale burn a lot of power
to enable you to play video games in high definition with Windows.
If this is not your goal, a garden variety AGP video card will 
probably have all the speed you need for surfing and playing videos.

Keith

From tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org  Thu Dec 18 15:59:09 2008
From: tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org (Tim)
Date: Thu, 18 Dec 2008 15:59:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] IP Address for Hong Kong Domain Name
In-Reply-To: <alpine.LNX.2.00.0812181534310.7497@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <alpine.LNX.2.00.0812181327250.7497@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<20081218214629.GL14492@merlot.com>
	<alpine.LNX.2.00.0812181524260.7497@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<b399d1c10812181531g7c78048ftf796c2400ec6dfe2@mail.gmail.com>
	<alpine.LNX.2.00.0812181534310.7497@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20081218235909.GB2430@sentinelchicken.org>

> [rshepard at salmo ~]$ host "dongjiang.com.hk"
> dongjiang.com.hk mail is handled by 10 mail.dongjiang.com.hk.
> dongjiang.com.hk mail is handled by 20 mail2.dongjiang.com.hk.
> 
>    Same results without quoting the domain name.
> 
>    dig gives me the nameservers ... by name, not IP address

So their domain has MX records defined but no A record.  This isn't that
uncommon.  Of course the MX records you see tell you that those hosts
are where mail goes when sending to them.  Commonly these will be the
same IPs you see coming at you when they're sending you mail, but
there's never any guarantee of this.

Name server records are supposed to give names.  Almost all record types
except for A and AAAA should point to another name.  Eventually all name
chains lead to an IP, but you have to follow that.  For instance:

~> host mail.dongjiang.com.hk.
mail.dongjiang.com.hk has address 220.241.112.97

~> host mail2.dongjiang.com.hk.
mail2.dongjiang.com.hk has address 220.241.112.98

~> host -t ns dongjiang.com.hk
dongjiang.com.hk name server ns8.imsbiz.com.
dongjiang.com.hk name server ns7.imsbiz.com.

~> host ns8.imsbiz.com
ns8.imsbiz.com has address 210.87.250.14

~> host ns7.imsbiz.com
ns7.imsbiz.com has address 210.87.253.2


HTH,
tim

>    OK, I should have followed the server chain. Thanks for pointing this out

Yup, no prob.

I should also mention that the whois databases for domain names and IP
addresses are separate.  Domain name whois databases are maintained by
TLD maintainers (I think) and the one for addresses is maintained by
your local RIR (I think).  In any case, if you query for a domain you'll
get something very different than query for the IP pointed to by that
domain, and for good reason.

good luck,
tim

Not that it pertains to this discussion, but in case you're curious, domain
name whois databases are maintained by the TLD maintainers (called the
Registry) except for .com and .net domains. In those cases, the whois
databases are maintained by the individual registrars of the domains.

You are correct in that the IP Address whois databases are maintained by the
RIRs. I had no idea what that was until you mentioned it.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Internet_Registry

-wes

In-Reply-To: <7ae7d1de0812190247k7eb7b77ex473e8da183d7827@mail.gmail.com>

Eitan Tsur wrote:
> Had a friend build one recently for a gaming rig.  One thing is that you can
> not buy a cheap motherboard for these right now.  Second thing is I don't
> know why Intel went back to using hyperthreading...  Doesn't make sense to
> me.  Didn't they want to move AWAY from that when they went to the Core
> achitecture? 

H y p e r t h r e a d i n g !!  S l o w l y I turned ... step by step
... inch by inch ... AUGGGHHHHHHH!!! :)

They went back to hyperthreading because it adds (a few) MIPS without
adding significant hardware cost. It's a bitch to model analytically,
but the operating systems, Linux in particular, already know how to
manage it, the design exists, and there are probably some patents that
make it a no-brainer for Intel.

What I don't understand is why Justin Rattner said they'd drop it. He
should have known he couldn't enforce that kind of decision on a large
organization like Intel.

M. Edward (Ed) Borasky, FBG, AB, PTA, PGS, MS, MNLP, NST, ACMC(P), WOM

causing trouble. I'm assuming I can use Wireshark to watch the traffic 
on the switch to which this machine (Ubuntu) is connected, but that it 
won't be able to look at any other traffic on the other router ports

From tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org  Fri Dec 19 11:29:48 2008
From: tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org (Tim)
Date: Fri, 19 Dec 2008 11:29:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Using Wireshark
In-Reply-To: <494BF494.1030806@comcast.net>
References: <494BF494.1030806@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20081219192948.GE2443@sentinelchicken.org>

> When I choose Capture > Interfaces from the Wireshark menu I get a 
> window with the title Wireshark: Capture Interfaces. It has a column 
> header line that says, Device Description   IP   Packets   Packets/s. 
> There is no list of devices below that header line.
> 
> Any ideas on what step Synaptic didn't include, or I didn't know I 
> needed to do?

In order to sniff a network interface, you typically need root access.
I'm guessing you weren't running it as root and Wireshark didn't show
you the interfaces that you don't have access to (though I could be
wrong).  Running Wireshark as root is a *bad idea* because they're
really not interested in providing a secure product, it seems, and have
had many overflows in the past.

So, I suggest running tcpdump as root (through sudo or otherwise),
storing the output of network traffic, then viewing it as your normal
user (or better yet, a much less privileged user) in wireshark.
Something along the lines of:

# tcpdump -vv -n -i eth0 -s 0 -w packet_capture.cap
...
$ wireshark packet_capture.cap


In this example, "eth0" is the ethernet device you want to sniff and
packet_capture.cap is the file where you'd store the packet capture.

HTH,
tim

If it were me, in your case, I would set up a computer with 2 network cards
and configure it as a gateway, allowing traffic to flow from one interface
to the other. Then I would use Wireshark or TCPDump or another utility (my
favorite is TCPFlows, ymmv) to monitor port 25 and look who's talking.

-wes

the downside to this method is that it doesn't allow you to use Wireshark's
built-in methods for overcoming the switch. As he mentioned in the original
post, 1 machine connected to a switch will not be able to see traffic from
another machine connected to the same switch..... unless you use Wireshark
(or something else that supports this) to instruct the switch (via ARP cache
poisoning) to send all traffic to the machine Wireshark is running on.

I consider this method to be "lame" and that's why I use the one I
mentioned: stick a machine in between the router and modem.

-wes

> built-in methods for overcoming the switch. As he mentioned in the original
> post, 1 machine connected to a switch will not be able to see traffic from
> another machine connected to the same switch..... unless you use Wireshark
> (or something else that supports this) to instruct the switch (via ARP cache

Hah!  I like the term "instruct".  ARP cache poisoning is typically
considered an exploit, since you're spoofing ARP replies.  I didn't
realize Wireshark now had this feature.

> I consider this method to be "lame" and that's why I use the one I
> mentioned: stick a machine in between the router and modem.

Yes, I didn't even intend to address his network topology.  He clearly
needs to do the sniffing on a box that has access to the packets, and I
too would recommend using a router or even the suspect machine itself.
With the approach I propose, it would be easy to tcpdump on one box and
copy the results over to wireshark, assuming he's using a decent OS for
the sniffing (i.e. not Windows).

cheers,
tim

Galen> A hub will send packets to all ports.  I keep an old 10 Mb hub
Galen> around just for this purpose.

FreeGeek occasionally also has managed switches that (I understand)
can let you dup traffic onto another physical port where you can
listen.  I picked up a couple over the past year for $10-$12 each, 24
port Intel 10/100 managed switch with fiber interfaces as well.

for $10 not a bad deal, just be aware that none of intel's switching
hardware that i ever used (if these are big gray switches, at least
2u, that are kinda loud they are probably the ones) was very good at
traffic above 10Mbps---that is, doing 2x100mbit wirespeed transfers at
once didn't get 200Mbits of throughput and adding more transfers
failed to raise the aggregate throughput numbers.  and the management
s/w was total crap.  felt more like a hub except that the traffic was
still segmented and not broadcast.

then again, maybe they put out a second revision since...wow, 1998ish,
when i was playing with 'em.

So the summary is they are preventing your machines from connecting to
port 25 on their machines because they think you are sending spam via
that route.  You would hope they could detect such things quite
reliably so it is probably true. Of course the most probable cause of
this is a  Windows computer infected with one of the prevalent botnet
trojans such as  srizbi.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Srizbi_botnet

Windows defender might be able to find and eliminate the problem.
http://www.microsoft.com/windows/products/winfamily/defender/default.mspx

Or Zonealarm
http://www.download.com/ZoneAlarm-Firewall-Windows-2000-XP-/3000-10435_4-10039884.html
might block the outgoing packets and give you some idea of which
program is trying to make the outgoing connection.

Bill

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Dec 19 18:12:27 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri, 19 Dec 2008 18:12:27 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Getting help remotely - Re:  meeting on the 21st
In-Reply-To: <0fb7f97125ebb0fe386ae0bb6987f612.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812162126370.9429@piptoo.pippiandcarlos.com>
	<20081216210119.4f0173a0.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<0fb7f97125ebb0fe386ae0bb6987f612.squirrel@webmail.pippiandcarlos.com>
Message-ID: <20081220021227.GA28484@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Fri, Dec 19, 2008 at 04:58:26PM -0700, ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com wrote:
> 
> I am sorry to report that my wife got worried about driving across Idaho
> and Oregon in the winter weather.  Our Portland trip is off.  No meeting
> for me.

Darn.  I would fly the business jet out to pick you up, but
it is currently in the shop with a bad case of imaginary.  :-)
Stay warm and safe - we'll see you in the spring.

We are crawling our way towards a swappable hard drive setup at the
clinic, so people can bring in their drives rather than their whole
machines.  We have fixed a few problems remotely with ssh login. 

But many problems require full network access.  One solution to that
is a "VPN terminal in a box" that taps your network and connects to a
service organization at the far end, but for now that is a lot of ad
hoc effort to set up with something like OpenWRT programmed into a
repurposed wireless access point or very small computer.  In the
nearer term, it will be easier to just install OpenVPN on one of
your computers, and connect to a port at our end.  Not yet.

You are having problems with networking, IIRC (setting up wpa, right?),
and working the client end of a wireless link via a VPN is difficult. 
Maybe in a few years we will have more experience or tools for that.

For now, perhaps we can work through some of your problems via the
list.  Keep in mind that you can set up secure communications with
temporary passwords, get things working with our help, then replace
the keys and passwords and IP address ranges when we are done.  As
long as there is no network connection at the time you are making
the experiments, and you return things to a more secure state before
you reconnect, you can keep the security risks low.  

Keith

Which model number was that?  There are lots of different Lenovo
X61s for sale via Google Shopping, eBay, etc.  When I did a search
on Google Shopping for "Lenovo X61 Tablet Thinkpad 1400 1050" I
got some hits, though nothing relevant for 1440.   

With the 4 digit model number (i.e. 7762 ) you can look in lots
more places.  The Lenovo Outlet Store has lots of inexpensive
X61 tablets, some with undefined screen resolutions.  Given
the model number, that is where I would look first.  There are
some highly rated stores on the lists, but that doesn't mean 
their laptops are good specimens, compared to the manufacturer.


Perhaps irrelevant to your quest, I personally prefer 1Kx768
screens - until they start making 2Kx1.5Ks.  I can fit two
80 character xterms with 5x9 fonts across a 1024 pixel screen.
The fonts look crummy until you get up to 9x15 characters, 
IMHO.  But then, most of you have better eyes than I do, so
you can see xterms with itsy bitsy characters.  1024x seems
to be the sweet spot for many websites, too.

>>>>>> "wes" == wes  <plug at the-wes.com> writes:
>
> wes> It would also be useful if you used a hub in between the router
> wes> and modem, and connected 1 port to a machine you could listen
> wes> with.
>
> That won't tell you which machine it is though, because between the
> modem and router all the clients with have the public ipaddr,
> presuming that NAT'ing occurs at the router.
>

> -- 
> Russell Senior, Secretary
> russell at personaltelco.net

You could filter the results by MAC address (a Layer 2 filter) by
using a filter expression like:

ether host 00:03:0d:10:f3:20

It suprised me to learn this, because every filter I have ever used in
the past was a Layer 3 filter (ex. 'tcp port 25').  I figured you
would have to do something extra to tell wireshark to look at a
completely different packet header.  Bt apparently not; it's smarter
than that.

If you were filtering on tcp port 25, even without a MAC filter, you
would see the offending packets, and could determine their owner by
the MAC address.  Therefore, a filter like 'tcp port 25' would yield
usable results, even if the IP address weren't useful.

Carlos
