>>>>> "Carlos" == Carlos Konstanski <ckonstanski at pippiandcarlos.com> writes:

Russell> That won't tell you which machine it is though, because
Russell> between the modem and router all the clients with have the
Russell> public ipaddr, presuming that NAT'ing occurs at the router.

Carlos> You could filter the results by MAC address (a Layer 2 filter)
Carlos> by using a filter expression like:

Carlos> ether host 00:03:0d:10:f3:20

Carlos> It suprised me to learn this, because every filter I have ever
Carlos> used in the past was a Layer 3 filter (ex. 'tcp port 25').  I
Carlos> figured you would have to do something extra to tell wireshark
Carlos> to look at a completely different packet header.  Bt
Carlos> apparently not; it's smarter than that.

Uh.  The macaddr you see between the router and the modem will be the
macaddr of the router or modem (or, presuming it is bridging, the
upstream devices).  MAC addresses don't survive routing because they
are local to each link.  If you want to see your local hosts, their
macaddrs and ipaddrs, you need to be on the inside side of your
router.

setting up ntpdate commands in root's crontab on all my servers. here's an
example:

0 * * * * /usr/sbin/ntpdate time.mit.edu > /dev/null

this syncs it up every hour.

From m0gely at gmail.com  Sat Dec 20 11:00:04 2008
From: m0gely at gmail.com (m0gely)
Date: Sat, 20 Dec 2008 11:00:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Using Wireshark
In-Reply-To: <494BF494.1030806@comcast.net>
References: <494BF494.1030806@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <494D40B4.3070606@gmail.com>

Richard C. Steffens wrote:

> I suspect my XP laptop, because it has been 
> booting pretty slowly of late, so I'll start with that.

Click 'Start' > 'Run' then type 'msconfig' and press 'OK'

Look at the 'Services' tab and check 'Hide All Microsoft Services', then 
look for anything suspicious. Then look at the Startup tab, which will 
show you all items running at login. Again, look for anything 
suspicious. If you want a more verbose 'msconfig', use this:

http://live.sysinternals.com/autoruns.exe

Also, at the command line, you can issue 'netstat' commands to see 
active connections. An alternative to netstat is here:

http://live.sysinternals.com/Tcpview.exe

If your AV is up to date and hasn't indicated any problems, you could 
try uninstalling it and try another brand as a test. AVG, Avast and 
AntiVir are all free for home use and many more with free trials that 
would work.

If none of this shows anything, you can try running this to detect rootkits:

http://live.sysinternals.com/RootkitRevealer.exe

If it find anything at all that you know is not right, then it's time to 
reinstall the OS. All the above could be done inside of 20 minutes 
unless your machine is an older slower model. I noticed you have a 
couple Win98 machines too. You let them loose on the web?

-- 
- m0gely

This gave me an inspiration and may have led me closer to a solution. 

First, I went into the System > Administration > Time and Date GUI and
discovered that I can put a tick mark in more than one server. So I
added a couple more. But time.mit.edu was not on the preordained list,
so I used the box in the bottom of the window to add it. Unfortunately,
when I clicked on Add it did nothing. Nevertheless, I now have three
servers checked, and I could add more.

Then from the command line I did this:

jjj at Devil7:~$ sudo /usr/sbin/ntpdate
[sudo] password for jjj: 
20 Dec 11:34:20 ntpdate[759]: no servers can be used, exiting

So the reason it is not updating is that it cannot find the servers. At
least I now know that it is set to use NTP servers. 

So then I went back to the GUI and put a tick mark in every server in
the US - 13 in all. Again I gave the update command, and again I got
the error message that no servers can be used.

Then I tried your command again, adding time.mit.edu, and got:

jjj at Devil7:~$ sudo /usr/sbin/ntpdate time.mit.edu
20 Dec 11:48:18 ntpdate[1386]: the NTP socket is in use, exiting

I don't know what that means. 

I could try Rich's suggest to set it to the deskop, but I doubt it
would work either. If it can't find 13 NTP servers because the NTP
socket is in use, it probably won't find the desktop either.


From aaron at madebyai.com  Sat Dec 20 12:30:07 2008
From: aaron at madebyai.com (Aaron Ten Clay)
Date: Sat, 20 Dec 2008 12:30:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Disallow raid assembly with missing device?
Message-ID: <200812201230.07858.aaron@madebyai.com>

I've got a non-critical box running raid5 where two drives are external, one 
USB and one eSATA. Occasionally for some reason one or the other is not 
detected at boot time, and the kernel will autodetect and assemble the array 
in degraded state missing one drive. This requires the whole array to be 
regenerated, which is quite time consuming.

Is there a way to force the kernel to NOT assemble an array that's missing 
disks at boot time? The raid456 module is compiled into the kernel because 
this raid array is the root filesystem. I'm not using an initrd and want to 
avoid doing so because that's a nuisance.

Kernel version 2.6.27, if it matters.

TIA,
Aaron


From plug at merlot.com  Sat Dec 20 12:57:28 2008
From: plug at merlot.com (Kurt Sussman)
Date: Sat, 20 Dec 2008 12:57:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Niggling time problem
In-Reply-To: <20081220115135.a06027a2.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20081220093223.cf49bbe1.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<b399d1c10812201047h16119110kae756ccf20b01ce3@mail.gmail.com>
	<20081220115135.a06027a2.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <20081220205728.GA14492@merlot.com>

John Jason Jordan (johnxj at comcast.net) typed this ...
> wes <plug at the-wes.com> dijo:
> > On Sat, Dec 20, 2008 at 9:32 AM, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net>wrote:
> > > For some reason my laptop (Lenovo T61) does not sync its clock with the
> > 
> > 0 * * * * /usr/sbin/ntpdate time.mit.edu > /dev/null
> 
> jjj at Devil7:~$ sudo /usr/sbin/ntpdate time.mit.edu
> 20 Dec 11:48:18 ntpdate[1386]: the NTP socket is in use, exiting

It probably means you're running a NTP server. If you're going to use
cron to keep your date in sync, you don't need the server. Use rcconf to
turn it off.

Also/alternatively, you can add the '-u' option to your 'ntpdate'
command line. Another useful trick is to use the pool.ntp.org name,
which spreads the time load over many servers.

My T61 has clock problems also...

ntpdate -u pool.ntp.org
20 Dec 12:55:53 ntpdate[30934]: step time server 209.132.176.4 offset
-9.854261 sec

--Kurt

file. I don't know exactly how to do it, however. While I generally
bitch about man files, man mdadm is pretty good.

Yeah, the system is Linux softwre RAID. However, mdadm is just a "control" 
application, if you will. It tells the kernel what to do. The kernel is what 
handles the RAID array, long before the system init scripts start running.

I've checked the kernel documentation, and the only commandline argument I've 
discovered for the entire md subystem is start_dirty_degraded, which only 
applies to an array that is both dirty and degraded. Mine is just degraded 
with a missing disk, and that's what i need to have halt a boot process.

-Aaron

IE 7 has *lots* of protective capabilites built in, and more are
available if you install one of the major protection suites, like McAfee
or Norton. If that's not enough, you could check out some of the gizmos
that large IT organizations use to protect their users and protect their
infrastructure from their users.

IE 7 with the default Internet security/privacy/parental controls, etc.
settings is pretty paranoid. About the only thing it doesn't protect you
from is Microsoft coding errors. :)

A bottle or two of de-icer, a propane blowtorch, (not to be used together
due to de-icer being alcohol which burns,) (don't wanna burn the whole place
down).  Also, if you heat the metal door too fast and it has a glass inlay
then it'll crack or break the glass potentially.  Another option is a
heat-gun or hot-air-reflow station hooked to whatever source of power you
can find.  Just heat the perimeter until it releases.  Maybe bring a small
generator just in case?

Or you can take the easy way out and use '--nodeps' ;)


$ rpmbuild -bs ./rpmbuild/SPECS/mock.spec 
error: Failed build dependencies:
	python-devel is needed by mock-0.9.7-1.noarch
$ rpmbuild -bs --nodeps ./rpmbuild/SPECS/mock.spec 
Wrote: /home/cohanna/rpmbuild/SRPMS/mock-0.9.7-1.src.rpm


--Caitlyn

On Sat, 20 Dec 2008, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> jjj at Devil7:~$ sudo /usr/sbin/ntpdate time.mit.edu
> 20 Dec 11:48:18 ntpdate[1386]: the NTP socket is in use, exiting

>From the ntpdate man page:

   ntpdate will decline to set the date if an NTP server daemon
   (e.g., ntpd) is running on the same host.

I notice also that the man page for ntpdate says:

   Disclaimer:  The functionality of this program is now available in the
   ntpd program. See the -q command line option in the ntpd - Network Time
   Protocol (NTP) daemon page. After a suitable period of mourning, the
   ntpdate program is to be retired from this distribution

so you may wish to investigate using ntpd some more.

David Fleck

I don't usually bother replying to GUI-related questions (because I am
clueless) but since no one else has...

I would start by comparing the state of files in each location. Is there an
ownership or permissions issue that gets resolved by moving them to your
home directory?

What if you create a file in /srv/www? Can you then move it to the Trash?

If nothing jumps out at us there, we will have to find some way to determine
the underlying operation that the "Move To Trash" command executes. It
probably relies on regular system utilities to do the work, so it probably
just runs something like "mv /srv/www/file /var/Trash" or the like. Once we
can determine what it's doing, we can then begin to determine why it can't
do it.

-wes

means or how to find out if you do or don't. Although it sounds a

From griffint at pobox.com  Sun Dec 21 11:43:57 2008
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Sun, 21 Dec 2008 11:43:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] xsnow RPM? WAS: Re:  Clinic Sunday ?
In-Reply-To: <d066c8c60812202303u2d6b61b2t2f18cf19fcf99f63@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d066c8c60812202303u2d6b61b2t2f18cf19fcf99f63@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200812211143.57884.griffint@pobox.com>

On Saturday 20 December 2008 11:03 pm, Amy Kelly wrote:
> > > Are we setting up for a "Donner Party" scenario?
> >
> > No, but maybe a dinner party ...
>
> "Donner, party of 10!" "Donner, party of 9!" "Donner, party of 8!"
>
> Tasteless, but I had to say it. Does anyone know where to find a
> working RPM for xsnow? Google is not spitting up anything useful for
> me. $BOY has it going on his Ubuntu box and is HIGHLY amused by it, I
> haven't found one for Fedora yet.
>
> amy

The last Fedora to have xsnow was Fedora Core 3. It appears to have been
dropped in the switch from XFree86 to xorg-x11. 

The source RPM is here:

http://archives.fedoraproject.org/pub/archive/fedora/linux/core/3/SRPMS/xsnow-1.42-15.src.rpm

I tried rebuilding on CentOS 5.2 using this command:

   rpmbuild --nodeps --rebuild xsnow-1.42-15.src.rpm

The "--nodeps" is required because of XFree86-devel (replaced by equivalent
xorg-x11 packages). Still that was not enough. I got errors because the rpmlib
is too new.

As was suggested already, I think building from source is the best bet.

The only other RPM option I can see is to try rebuilding from a source RPM 
from a non-redhat-ish distribution. According to rpmseek.com xsnow was
distributed with OpenSuSE as late as 10.2.

Terry

From eitan.tsur at gmail.com  Sun Dec 21 18:38:53 2008
From: eitan.tsur at gmail.com (Eitan Tsur)
Date: Sun, 21 Dec 2008 18:38:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Possible fried laptop...
Message-ID: <7ae7d1de0812211838w4066f72vbc750cfbf96561cb@mail.gmail.com>

Hi all,  so I lost power for a couple hours today, and my laptop was on
during the outage.  I shut it down, plugged it in, and waited until the
power came back to use it again.  Since then the power has come back on,
however the laptop will no longer POST, and the power light flashes.  This
has never happened before, (light flashing or no POST condition,) and seems
to be unaffected by being on wall power or not, with or without the battery
installed.  If anyone has any thoughts on what could cause this sort of
situation, please let me know.

Regards,
-Eitan-


From lnxknight at gmail.com  Sun Dec 21 19:03:38 2008
From: lnxknight at gmail.com (Matt McKenzie)
Date: Sun, 21 Dec 2008 19:03:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Possible fried laptop...
In-Reply-To: <7ae7d1de0812211838w4066f72vbc750cfbf96561cb@mail.gmail.com>
References: <7ae7d1de0812211838w4066f72vbc750cfbf96561cb@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <da2207740812211903x7059a15cw5692fce14605f5ba@mail.gmail.com>

It sounds like you may have done this, but have you done the old trick of:

Remove battery
Unplug AC
Wait 10-15 seconds
Plug in AC
Try to power up
Replace battery

?

Or, leave it plugged in, make sure charging light is on (sounds like it may
be charging, with the light flashing),
let battery charge up for a while (10-15 minutes at least), and then try
again.  If the battery is completely dead, some laptops won't power up at
all, regardless of AC plugged in or not.  As long as you are getting some
light activity there is a good chance you can resurrect it.

----------
Matt M.
LinuxKnight

I went through something like this a couple of months ago on my ancient
Compaq Presario 2110US. It was running fine on AC but the charge light
flashed yellow. I went on line and did a search and it said, "Dead
Battery". So I bought a new battery and it now works. So before you
throw in the towel, search for your symptoms on the vendor's support
site. It might just be a dead battery.

P.S. On mine, the light is green when fully charged, *solid* yellow when
charging and flashing yellow when there is a dead battery. I forget what
the symptom is if the charging circuit is fried.

I had a similar problem...
http://h10025.www1.hp.com/ewfrf/wc/document?docname=c01611512&lc=en&dlc=en&cc=us&product=3340198&lang=en
turned out to be HP's problem. Their fixing it for free even though it's
not under warranty. Thought this might give you another place to look.
Check the manufacturers website and see if they have anything posted
about your problem.

think was a defective suppressor) is that the battery went from 100% to
completely drained.

couple of years ago) before the laptop would start again. And I'm still

Here's my little laptop hardware story:

I had a recent experience with my even older Compaq Presario (an
1800T).  No video.  No cursor, no backlight, nothing.  I often get a
long beep, two short beeps during POST.  I was stunned recently to
discover that it was *actually* booting up okay.  It dual-boots w2k
and linux, and when I got it booting linux and I let it boot, I could
ssh in over the network and everything was fine.  Except, that is,
that lspci didn't show the video adapter.  Oops.

While I was looking for a nearby repair depot, I found HP's
diagnostics site.  The last step before sending it in for evaluation
was to reseat the memory.  I did that and *boom* it worked.  For a
little while.  The memory trick isn't working any more, and it's going
in on the first day the place is open (damned weather!).

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Dec 21 22:10:02 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun, 21 Dec 2008 22:10:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Possible fried laptop...
In-Reply-To: <7ae7d1de0812211838w4066f72vbc750cfbf96561cb@mail.gmail.com>
References: <7ae7d1de0812211838w4066f72vbc750cfbf96561cb@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20081222061002.GA32619@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Sun, Dec 21, 2008 at 06:38:53PM -0800, Eitan Tsur wrote:
> Hi all,  so I lost power for a couple hours today, and my laptop was on
> during the outage.  I shut it down, plugged it in, and waited until the
> power came back to use it again.  Since then the power has come back on,
> however the laptop will no longer POST, and the power light flashes.  This
> has never happened before, (light flashing or no POST condition,) and seems
> to be unaffected by being on wall power or not, with or without the battery
> installed.  If anyone has any thoughts on what could cause this sort of
> situation, please let me know.

The first thing to check is whether the AC adapter produces the
right voltage.  It is difficult for a power line upset "reach
through" the AC adapter and zap the laptop.  If it somehow did,
it is even more unlikely for the adapter to produce normal
voltage afterwards.  There is a lot of power regulating circuitry
in most laptop adapters, and I would expect that to blow first.

However, what CAN happen is that the line power can bounce on and
off in the wrong way, the output of a poorly designed adapter can 
bounce up and down with it, and this can stress the power input
circuitry of the laptop, wreaking havoc.  This should not happen
with well designed power hardware.  Sadly, at most places I know
about the power supply is where they save pennies on components,
and save salary cost by hiring second rate engineers.  Power
supply behavior under funny line conditions is a not banner spec
or a driver of purchasing decisions.  I have seen two battery
charging circuits fail on 1997-era laptops, necessitating depot
level repair.  IBM was great for these fixes, Levono not so 
much, Dell used to suck horribly.  But things change.

If it is a zorched power supply on the laptop motherboard, the
whole motherboard will need replacing.  You will have a hard
time isolating and identifying the blown semiconductor (s),
figuring out the part number, and finding a replacement for sale
somewhere, because they probably don't manufacture it anymore.

That said, Google is your friend.  Look to see if others have
had the problem with your model number.  And eBay is your friend;
a lot of people break screens and other components that aren't
the motherboard, so you can usually find used replacements cheap.

My bet on the broken component is (1) AC adapter, (2) battery,
(3) motherboard.  It helps to have spares for (1) and (2) anyway.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Dec 22 17:46:45 2008
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 22 Dec 2008 17:46:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] TimeVault
Message-ID: <20081222174645.740defa6.johnxj@comcast.net>

For a long time I have been searching for a backup utility that a brand
new Linux user can handle. That means no manual command line, no cron
jobs, no scripts - and GUI all the way. The GUI can be a front end to
those tools, but if we want to get desktop users away from Windows and
into Linux we have to supply them with something they can understand.
(Y'all who think Linux should never be on the desktop can stop reading
now.)  :)

I may have found it. TimeVault is a project that is under development
to provide a utility for Linux users that is very close to Apple's Time
Machine. Unfortunately, it is still under development. Moreover, it
appears that it started as a tool to be integrated into the Gnome
desktop (e.g. Nautilus), but the past several months have been devoted
to creating a KDE version as well. Thus, the core utilities have not
been worked on lately. Here are some links:

http://www.howtoforge.com/snapshot-backups-with-timevault-ubuntu-7.10
https://launchpad.net/timevault
https://wiki.ubuntu.com/TimeVault

Even if it's not close to release I'd like to try out the latest
version. However, there is no 64-bit .deb for my Ubuntu x86_64
computers, and the source that is available is for version 7.2, several
months old. I have read Ubuntu forum posts where people have installed
the 32-bit .debs with --force-architechture, and I may give that a
shot, just to take it for a spin.

Meantime, I'm also investigating rsnapshot, a dirvish-like utility
whose documentation I can actually almost understand.

From eitan.tsur at gmail.com  Mon Dec 22 23:03:12 2008

Subject: [PLUG] Possible fried laptop...
In-Reply-To: <7ae7d1de0812212220t619dbb32p476564f6e6348bb6@mail.gmail.com>
References: <7ae7d1de0812211838w4066f72vbc750cfbf96561cb@mail.gmail.com>

	<7ae7d1de0812212220t619dbb32p476564f6e6348bb6@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7ae7d1de0812222303h78f4f4bcp4746f368af52de21@mail.gmail.com>

Ok, turns out it just had some weird state in the CMOS.  Re-popped the CMOS
battery, shorted the contacts on the holder this time to discharge any
capacitance, and reassembled.  The whole thing worked, more or less, and
boots just fine now.  Only issue I have now is that the system does not
detect when the lid is closed anymore.  It worked before, so I'm guessing
there's some BIOS setting that affects it.  Anyways, thanks for all your
advice.  Really glad it wasn't fried, and next power outage I'm unplugging
it and all my other valuable unprotected-by-UPS electronics.

On Sun, Dec 21, 2008 at 10:20 PM, Eitan Tsur <eitan.tsur at gmail.com> wrote:

> Ugh...  Not exactly the news I was hoping for, but I've already popped out

> -Eitan-
>
> PS: god I hope this one doesn't last all night...
>

> On Sun, Dec 21, 2008 at 10:10 PM, Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> wrote:
>
>> On Sun, Dec 21, 2008 at 06:38:53PM -0800, Eitan Tsur wrote:
>> > Hi all,  so I lost power for a couple hours today, and my laptop was on
>> > during the outage.  I shut it down, plugged it in, and waited until the
>> > power came back to use it again.  Since then the power has come back on,
>> > however the laptop will no longer POST, and the power light flashes.
>>  This
>> > has never happened before, (light flashing or no POST condition,) and
>> seems
>> > to be unaffected by being on wall power or not, with or without the
>> battery
>> > installed.  If anyone has any thoughts on what could cause this sort of
>> > situation, please let me know.
>>
>> The first thing to check is whether the AC adapter produces the
>> right voltage.  It is difficult for a power line upset "reach
>> through" the AC adapter and zap the laptop.  If it somehow did,
>> it is even more unlikely for the adapter to produce normal
>> voltage afterwards.  There is a lot of power regulating circuitry
>> in most laptop adapters, and I would expect that to blow first.
>>
>> However, what CAN happen is that the line power can bounce on and
>> off in the wrong way, the output of a poorly designed adapter can
>> bounce up and down with it, and this can stress the power input
>> circuitry of the laptop, wreaking havoc.  This should not happen
>> with well designed power hardware.  Sadly, at most places I know
>> about the power supply is where they save pennies on components,
>> and save salary cost by hiring second rate engineers.  Power
>> supply behavior under funny line conditions is a not banner spec
>> or a driver of purchasing decisions.  I have seen two battery
>> charging circuits fail on 1997-era laptops, necessitating depot
>> level repair.  IBM was great for these fixes, Levono not so
>> much, Dell used to suck horribly.  But things change.
>>
>> If it is a zorched power supply on the laptop motherboard, the
>> whole motherboard will need replacing.  You will have a hard
>> time isolating and identifying the blown semiconductor (s),
>> figuring out the part number, and finding a replacement for sale
>> somewhere, because they probably don't manufacture it anymore.
>>
>> That said, Google is your friend.  Look to see if others have
>> had the problem with your model number.  And eBay is your friend;
>> a lot of people break screens and other components that aren't
>> the motherboard, so you can usually find used replacements cheap.
>>
>> My bet on the broken component is (1) AC adapter, (2) battery,
>> (3) motherboard.  It helps to have spares for (1) and (2) anyway.
>>
>> Keith
>>
>> --
>> Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
>> KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
>> Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

make is notoriously finicky about Makefile syntax.  Most likely there is 
something make doesn't like on line 89.  The #1 Makefile error is that the 
first line of a target description (and maybe all lines of the 
description, don't remember at the moment) MUST MUST MUST start with a tab 
character.

A fairly complete listing of browsers with a brief description can be found
at http://www.helgefjell.de/browser.php

Minimo is intriguing..

The Minimo (Mini Mozilla) project is focused on code-size and runtime
footprint reduction, and porting to small consumer devices. The primary
focus of Minimo to date has been system with ~32-64 MB of RAM, running Linux
and using the GTK toolkit. Other platforms and toolkits have been
investigated as well.

Michael Ewan wrote:

> Seamonkey is the bloatware Mozilla version of the old Netscape 
> Communicator all-in-one tool. I don't think it fits the bill here.  

The old Netscape is the bloatware AOL version of the old Mozilla Suite, 
not the other way around. The Suite/Seamonkey have a smaller memory 
footprint with mail and the browser open with several tabs than FF alone 
with a few tabs of the same sites open.

I would suggest making sure there aren't a bunch of plugins installed, 
as that is the primary reason for FF weirdness. Or try Opera.

	<49512920.3090603@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <49512F12.6070809@cesmail.net>

While we are on the subject of measuring Linux memory usage, two
not-so-subtle points:

1. Kernels from 2.6.25 to the present have better process memory usage
measurement capabilities than those up through 2.6.24. See

http://kernelnewbies.org/Linux_2_6_25#head-5a75e29195ffa59bfa5428ca28702e2e7df8f2ad
http://lwn.net/Articles/230975/

2. With any kernel, you need to account for shared memory, libraries,
etc., to properly assess the memory required by an application. The tool
that does this is in the "procps" package and is called "pmap". See

http://virtualthreads.blogspot.com/2006/02/understanding-memory-usage-on-linux.html
http://www.cyberciti.biz/tips/howto-find-memory-used-by-program.html
-- 
M. Edward (Ed) Borasky, FBG, AB, PTA, PGS, MS, MNLP, NST, ACMC(P), WOM

I've never met a happy clam. In fact, most of them were pretty steamed.

two shell processes should not ever increase in size, since their work
is done by the time the browser starts.


From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Dec 23 12:10:49 2008
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 23 Dec 2008 12:10:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Browsers, memory, and flash
Message-ID: <20081223201049.GB7342@gate.kl-ic.com>


It's been a year since I looked at it, but at that time one
of the largest memory hogs for a browser was flash animation. 
The Adobe Flash plugin is closed source, and behaves badly -
it just keeps grabbing memory and not letting go of it.  Also,
it seems to ask X to allocate memory for it, and doesn't tell
X when it is done with the memory.  So, if you leave a browser
running on a page with flash animation,  Adobe Flash will
slowly grab all your RAM.

That was a year ago - perhaps things are much better now, and
perhaps gnash is working better than Adobe flash and I should
switch to that.  For now, I run with 2GB of RAM, kill firefox
every few days, and restart X every couple of weeks.  It
amazes me that firefox takes up so much room, yet still lacks
heuristics to render badly-M$-centric pages usably.

Keith

Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 23 Dec 2008, M. Edward (Ed) Borasky wrote:
> 
>> 2. With any kernel, you need to account for shared memory, libraries,
>> etc., to properly assess the memory required by an application. The tool
>> that does this is in the "procps" package and is called "pmap".
> 
> Ed,
> 
>    Thank you. I was not aware of pmap before ... or I completely forgot about
> it.
> 
>    Germane to this thread, how would I apply pmap to determine the memory
> used by firefox when I have these three processes running?
> 
>   9484 ?        S      0:00 /bin/sh /usr/bin/firefox
>   9496 ?        S      0:00 /bin/sh /usr/lib/firefox-2.0.0.20/run-mozilla.sh /usr
>   9501 ?        Sl     4:20 /usr/lib/firefox-2.0.0.20/firefox-bin
> 
>    Do I measure only 9484? Add the results of all three?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Rich
> 

One of the links covers that, but essentially every thread has two types
of RAM that it is using -- RAM that it shares with one or more other
threads and RAM that is unique to it. Towards the bottom of one of the
pmap displays for each thread -- I forget whether it is -x or -d --
there is a total of the shared and unique RAM. So, you count the shared
RAM once and add the unique RAM for all of the processes.

about doing the 64-bit Linux plugin.

Ubuntu and openSUSE.

with other Linux distros but competing with Windows and MacOS X. Are any
of you close enough to Fedora or Ubuntu to know if they have similar
philosophies? After Shuttleworth made his statement about nobody being
able to make money with the Linux desktop, I wonder about stuff like
that. :)

From plug_1 at robinson-west.com  Tue Dec 23 17:29:28 2008
From: plug_1 at robinson-west.com (someone)
Date: Tue, 23 Dec 2008 17:29:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] The trouble with different browsers...
Message-ID: <20081223172928.4g4avl74bosk4gso@web.robinson-west.com>

There is so much rotgut on the Net.  If you go with a browser
other than Firefox, you can't install Procon.  In the interest
of being filtered, looking for a lower memory footprint browser
might not be the greatest idea.  There's also the issue of
compatibility.  Freedos 1.0 has arachne and I finally found a
packet driver for my built-in Intel nic.  Thing is, Arachne
isn't compatible with a host of web sites including horde
webmail imp sites.  As far as I know, there isn't a filter
plugin for Arachne that's comparable to procon.  I uninstalled
arachne from my freedos system because it isn't filterable.
I'm hoping that freedos 1.1 will be more compatible with MS-DOS.
I'd like to run netware where mars is simply broken.

I wish what the average person would call rotgut wasn't so easily
accessed on the Net, but there's no law enforcement and there are
no laws when it comes to web sites.  At least it seems that there
are no laws.  Maybe there's no stomach to apply the same standard
for what you can do on the street to what you can do on the Net.
Why is there a Melissa porn site that shows samples to anyone who
hasn't done a thing to identify who they are and how old they are?
There are many sites like this.  Looking at these kinds of sites
for some has cost them their marriage.  For being "harmless," the
person posing is someone's: child, brother, or sister whom your are
reducing to a mere object if you watch.  Think about it.  A non
Firefox browser may have trouble rendering some of these sites,
but chances are that plenty of inappropriate content is accessible
to anyone who uses a browser that supports pictures.

On the "harmless" point, what if there are laws that go after the
people who decide to view lude sites?  What if you get labeled a
sex offender?  The people who need to be busted are the pimps, but
is that going to happen?  There have been high profile cases where
people have been charged as sexual offenders for merely storing
samples of what they find online.  I understand that you don't have
to be a producer of lude content to get busted.  I don't know why,
but sexual addiction is treated differently than say alcoholism
even though arguably it is an addiction and similar in many
respects.  There is secrecy for example in hiding your computer
activities as opposed to say empty beer bottles.  The scary thing
is, it's better to be labeled an alcoholic than it is to be labeled
a sex offender.  What I see is a wild unregulated Internet and
innocent victims who are more likely to get into legal trouble than
the criminals who are producing inappropriate web sites in the first
place.  These victims don't have to be adults, they can be children.
It should be illegal to let just anyone view your web site if there
is nudity or sexual activity portrayed on it.  Free samples of lude
activity where no effort is made to identify who you are should be
illegal.  I'd like to outlaw the whole "adult" industry altogether,
but I realize that that isn't going to happen.

In short, there are threads on here discussing low memory footprint
browsers.  Well, does low memory footprint mean that you don't
filter your web access?  There is dansguardian, but going through
a proxy in general doesn't always work and dansguardian seems more
likely to block legitimate activity than say Procon.  Firefox is
very filterable via Procon and if someone else has the password to
it, it is hard to bypass.  Start introducing other browsers that
don't have Procon, there isn't any protection.  You defeat a major
reason for sticking with Firefox.

Even if you have no objections yourself to "lude" web sites, filtering
them out is a good legal strategy.

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> On Tue, 23 Dec 2008 16:33:40 -0800
> "M. Edward (Ed) Borasky" <znmeb at cesmail.net> dijo:
> 
>> That said, I in fact found workarounds for quite a few openSUSE issues
>> during my testing of 11.1 RC1 by searching Fedora and Ubuntu forums. :)
>> Much as I hate to admit it, I think, aside from the RPM / deb divide,
>> there's not a whole heck of a lot of difference any more between Fedora,
>> Ubuntu and openSUSE.
> 
> I tend to agree, although Ubuntu is perhaps a small bit more user
> friendly for the beginner coming from Windows or MacOS. What keeps me
> in the Ubuntu world is debian package management software, plus it's
> the devil I know. 

I don't think there's any significant difference between package
management systems using RPM and deb formats. Nor do I think there's any
significant difference between the package management software utilities
-- yum, apt-get, YaST, zypper, etc., with or without GUI wrappers. They
all do the same things: poll for updates, resolve dependencies, give you
a categorized menu of software you can install, etc.

The difference that I find significant is the *number* of packages in
the distro-specific repositories. There, Debian is a winner, and I think
Gentoo is a strong number two. You have to go hunting outside the main
distro repositories for a lot of software in the RPM-based systems.

> I didn't know he said that. In fact, I know he has said on more than
> one occasion that the goal of Ubuntu is to prove to the Linux world
> that Linux can work just fine on the desktop. And that certainly has
> been the historical thrust of Ubuntu. As for making money from it,
> Canonical makes quite a bit of money from support contracts. Dell, for
> example, is one of their customers.

http://www.tectonic.co.za/?p=3500

and also

http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Linux-and-Open-Source/Shuttleworth-Make-Desktop-Linux-Better-than-Apple/

Now, I've only looked over the shoulder of Mac users, never taken a Mac
desktop and customized it to my personal workflow. I *have* done that
for Windows and for Gnome (2.24 + Compiz as built on openSUSE 11.x), KDE
(3.x, a long time ago) and WindowMaker.

I think I still prefer WindowMaker over the others, and I'm not sure
Compiz is contributing anything except eye candy at the moment. But I
brought WindowMaker up just yesterday and it seemed somehow restrictive
after just about a month of the openSUSE Gnome. I also brought up KDE
4.1 ... I floundered around on it for half a day and decided not to mess
with it any more.

So for now I am staying with Gnome. And I'd be terribly surprised if a
Windows or Mac user looking over my shoulder would even pay attention to
whether my desktop was "prettier" than theirs, or even more "efficient".

On Tue, 23 Dec 2008 18:22:49 -0800
Michael Robinson <plug_1 at robinson-west.com> wrote:

> I know it was long.  Will nobody attempt to reply?
> 
> So, does Midori have filtering plugins?  How about Opera?

I have only recently looked at Midori, but it does not have plugins that
I can determine. It is extensible, or so it's claimed on the web site
(<http://www.twotoasts.de>), via C and possibly Lua, but I've no clue
how to do that. Probably this will become a plug-in feature in time. 
Remember that Midori is _alpha_ software, and any or all of it's
features may change with the wind. (Though IMHO it looks very clean and
useable even now.)

I have not looked at Opera in several years, so I can't say yea or nay.

> Why is it that plugins install pretty much automatically for
> people using firefox under Windows but automatic install generally
> doesn't work under Linux?

I have used Firefox under Linux (Fedora) and Windows XP Pro, and have
never had any trouble installing plugins for either platform.  (Except
for Adobe Flash, which is a frelling pain in the posterior at the best
of times.)  For most plugins the procedure is the same:  Go to the
Firefox extensions web page, browse through the plugins until you find
the one you want, then click on Download.  It will pop up a requester;
click on INSTALL (or OK) and the plugin will be installed.  Reapeat
until done.  After that, Firefox has to be restarted to activate the
plugins.  Updates occur automatically so long as they're enabled in
Preferences.

--dale

I got my desktop built at CompUsa when they still had a store here. But
I ended up with a Gigabyte motherboard and an AMD Athlon64 X2 processor,
not an Intel one. I'd recommend spending the extra bucks for the 8 GB if
you can, and you'll probably want to go for a full 64-bit distro. If
your current desktop is a 32-bit one, just moving the hard drives
"should work" but it might not be worth the troubleshooting time if it
doesn't. :)

What virtualization are you going to use? VirtualBox? Xen? KVM? Qemu?
The free ESXi?

Well ... I ran into something like this and ended up having to write a
Perl script to open the directory ("opendir"), search through it, and
then unlink all the files with the bogus names. I couldn't figure out
how to do that from the command line or a bash script -- I had to do it
in Perl.

But depending on how badly messed up other things in the filesystem are,
you might be safer making a copy of everything you do want (which you
should do anyhow), rebuilding the filesystem, and copying stuff back.

So ... first step ... back up everything! Then at least if the
filesystem is badly broken, you can get a clean one.

Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 26 Dec 2008, M. Edward (Ed) Borasky wrote:
> 
>>> On Fri, Dec 26, 2008 at 3:20 PM, Bill Barry <bill at billbarry.org> wrote:
>>>> I am deleting some old backups and I getting some errors like
> 
>> Well ... I ran into something like this and ended up having to write a
>> Perl script to open the directory ("opendir"), search through it, and then
>> unlink all the files with the bogus names. I couldn't figure out how to do
>> that from the command line or a bash script -- I had to do it in Perl.
> 
>    What happens if the rm command is followed by the file names in double
> quotes? I know this works when there are blanks or undisplayable characters
> in the filename, but I've no idea what the question marks might indicate.
> 
> Rich
> 
That's the problem ... the question marks stand for characters that have
no printable equivalent. I had to read them with Perl code and pass the
name strings to the unlink routine to get rid of them. There may be a
command-line routine that will convert them to hexadecimal or something,
but the Perl thing worked before I had a chance to dig into other hacks.

Now if you have the inode numbers (ls -li), there might be a way to get
rid of them by inode number. I think I tried that, but I don't remember.
I also think I tried "rm -i *" and saying yes for the bogus ones and
that didn't work either for some reason. It was faster for me to do it
in Perl. That also gave me the ability to print the file names, etc., in
hexadecimal.

One old UNIX trick on deleting files with funky names is to use the find 
command  with the  ls -i command.  ls -i gives you the inode for the 
file.  You can then use the find command to locate the file using the 
inode and with the -exec option of find remove it.

[me at mysystem ~]$ touch inode
[me at mysystem ~]$ ls -i inode
2907819 inode
[me at mysystem ~]$ find . -inum 2907819 -exec rm {} \;
[me at mysystem ~]$ ls -l inode
ls: cannot access inode: No such file or directory
[me at mysystem ~]$

Ken
CAD 2 CAM

Ed,

Suggestion on the "rm" you tried.  Try
	rm -i .??*
That should pickup almost all of the files starting with a "." except "."
and "..".
Suggest doing an
	ls .??*
First to verify it picks up the file in question.

From gently at gmail.com  Fri Dec 26 21:40:49 2008

Message-ID: <ae2db4620812262140t6a5e6585h66b1176e731f1310@mail.gmail.com>

On Fri, Dec 26, 2008 at 17:20, Bill Barry <bill at billbarry.org> wrote:
> I am deleting some old backups and I getting some errors like
>
> rm: cannot remove `rpl_ignore_table.test': Permission denied

this is, as may not have been clear from earlier replies, a red herring.


> I am root, but still I get permission denied.
>
> When I do a directory listing I get a bunch of question marks where I
> should get owners, groups, etc
>
> ls -l
>
> ?????????? ? ? ? ?            ? rpl_ignore_table.test

that's unfortunate and indicates filesystem corruption in my
experience.  if it's a network filesystem, it may just be some
confusion over the wire--i have an SMB mount point that is unusable
and unfixable on one machine (which i don't want to reboot), while
remounting the same FS on a different directory makes the files show
up as expected...but every time i've ever seen that on a mounted,
local filesystem (NB, i rarely use non-unix filesystems like HFS,
NTFS, etc, so those might just want remounting too), it's been
filesystem corruption, and a run past fsck will scoot those inodes
over to the lost+found directory if the FS is salvageable at all.

whatever you do, do it soon, since corruption tends to spread.

Filesystem corruption was indeed the problem. It took 9 hours to run,
but among the things fsck did was to remove the problem files.

I tried deleting the files using the inode number

ls -i
9921738 rpl_ignore_table.test
find . -inum 9921738 -exec rm {} \;
find: `./rpl_ignore_table.test': Permission denied

which would be a good trick for files with crazy names, but this
wasn't the problem.

Then I ran
fsck.reiserfs  --rebuild-tree  /dev/sdb2

One of the log messages revealed that the problem was an entry
pointing to nowhere.

rebuild_semantic_pass: The entry [9920235 9921738]
("rpl_ignore_table.test") in directory [12616279 12630835] points to
nowhere - is removed

9 hours later fsck was done, I remounted the filesystem and the
troublesome files were gone.

Thanks Chris and everyone else for your suggestions,

Bill

the cause of the corruption my reasoning is a bit short sighted  and I
will have to reconsider the disk size/ stability tradeoff.

others that never gave me any trouble. I've never tried JFS. At the
moment, I use XFS, because it had the best characteristics on most
benchmarks. The only operation where it seems to be really slow is a
moderate-sized recursive "rm".

I'm waiting for ext4 and btrfs to stabilize; then I'll re-evaluate.

-- 
M. Edward (Ed) Borasky, FBG, AB, PTA, PGS, MS, MNLP, NST, ACMC(P), WOM

I've never met a happy clam. In fact, most of them were pretty steamed.

From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Dec 29 17:39:34 2008
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 29 Dec 2008 17:39:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] kio_http is a pig
Message-ID: <20081229173934.6fda9045.johnxj@comcast.net>

My favorite torrent client is Ktorrrent (3.1.2 on KDE 4.1.3), even
though my computer uses standard Gnome desktop with Intrepid x86_64.

At the moment one torrent is running (downloading), and there is only
one seeder. The computer is jerky, screens don't refresh smoothly,
mouse and keyboard are intermittent, and basically the CPU cores are
tied up. Looking in System > Administration > System Monitor reveals
that there are three instances of kio_http running, each consuming 30+%
of CPU time. That is, 30+% on each of the dual cores. For both cores
the little lines in the graph are pegged at the top. I have a little
CPU widget in the Gnome panel and it reflects 2.00 GHz for the CPUs,
where it normally displays 800 or 1600. The CPU fan has been running
constantly all day. Little wonder the computer is unresponsive. The
kio_http's are also each consuming about 250 MB of RAM, although the
computer has 4 GB, so that is probably not an issue.

Google only reveals that this has been reported over and over. Looking
at dozens of complaints, I haven't found any that has received an
answer or a solution.

If I close down Ktorrent the computer returns to normal. But stopping
all torrents changes nothing - that is, even if Ktorrent is completely
paused the three instances of kio_http remain running and continue
sucking down most of the CPU time. Closing down Ktorrent makes all
three disappear. 

Any suggestions welcome.

resources. Much like setting priorities for a process in Windows.

nice -19 {I believe thats the lowest priority but I may have it backwards, I
haven't used nice in a few years}  <$PID or process name>

>
> nice -19 {I believe thats the lowest priority but I may have it backwards, I
> haven't used nice in a few years}  <$PID or process name>

>From the nice(1) man page, on my debian box:

"Nicenesses  range from -20 (most favorable scheduling) to 19 (least
favorable)."

I believe the value is how "nice" the process is to others.  So a high
niceness results in a lower priority.  Things that are unimportant
should be run with a higher niceness than important things.

--Rogan

> Tell me more about nice. I see a column in System > Administration >
> System Monitor that is labeled "nice." Sadly, it never occurred to the
> developers of System Monitor to create documentation explaining what
> "nice" is;.


man nice....


NAME
       nice - run a program with modified scheduling priority

SYNOPSIS
       nice [OPTION] [COMMAND [ARG]...]

DESCRIPTION
       Run  COMMAND  with  an  adjusted niceness, which affects process
scheduling.  With no COMMAND, print the current niceness.
       Nicenesses range from -20 (most favorable scheduling) to 19
(least favorable).

       -n, --adjustment=N
              add integer N to the niceness (default 10)

       --help display this help and exit

       --version
              output version information and exit

       NOTE: your shell may have its own version of nice, which usually
supersedes the version described here.  Please  refer  to
       your shell?s documentation for details about the options it
supports.



HTH

linux-yug

Subject: [PLUG] External CSS vs in a <style> tag in the <head> section

I have some style code that works when it is in the <head> section of a 
web page, but not when it is in an external file. Shouldn't it work the 
same? The style code for the body, #sidebar, and #main sections appear 
to work correctly. Any idea why the parts between the body section and 
the #sidebar section are ignored when they are imported from an external 
file, but work correctly when they are inside <style></style> tags in 
the .html file?

Here's the current <head> section:

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" 
"http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
  <head>
    <title>Winter Storm, December, 2008</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style.css" />
    </head>

I copied the entire <style> section and put it in a file named 
style.css. I removed the <style></style> tags, before saving it.

Here's the contents of style.css:

/* Style Sheet for Comcast Site */

body {
  background: #EED;
  margin: 0;
  }

div.pic {
  float: left;
  height: 190px;
  width: 130px;
  padding: 0 5px;
  margin: 5px 3px;
  }
div.pic img {
  border: 1px solid;
  border-color: #444 #AAA #AAA #444;
  }
div.ls img {
  height: 96px;
  width: 128px;
  margin: 32px 0 0;
  }
div.pt img {
  height: 128px;
  width: 96px;
  margin: 0 16px;
  }
div.pic ul {
  margin: 0.25em 0 0;
  padding: 0;
  font: bold small Arial, Verdana, sans-serif;
  list-style: none;
  }
li.title {
  display: block;
  text-align: center;
  }

#sidebar {
  position: absolute;
    top: 32px;
  width: 130px;
  padding: 0;
  }

#main {
  position: fixed;
    top: 0;
    left: 5px;
  margin: 0 0 0 140px;
  }

Just a couple of things off the top of my head:

- Did you specify the URL right?  That is, is the "style.css" file in
  the same directory as the main HTML document?

- Any case-sensitivity issues?  Is it "Style.css" instead?

- Permissions?  Can you actually hit the full URL for the style sheet
  manually to verify that browsers can retrieve it?

On Tue, 30 Dec 2008, Tim wrote:

> Date: Tue, 30 Dec 2008 16:58:19 -0800
> From: Tim <tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org>
> Reply-To: "General Linux/UNIX discussion and help;	civil and on-topic"
>     <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>

>     <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] External CSS vs in a <style> tag in the <head> section
> 
>> External stylesheets are a bit overrated.  How can you dynamically
>> generate styles with a hardcoded file?  But it does cut down on the
>> number of bytes sent over the wire.
>
> Why would you ever need to?  I've done a lot of dynamic websites and
> tested hundreds more.  I've never seen a good reason to dynamically
> generate style sheets.  Just create multiple static ones or all of the
> classes you'll need and reference them dynamically.
>
> tim

Creating multiple copies of the same code is not good programming
practice.  It is better to create a single template, and use
programming logic to fill in the dynamic bits.  The moment you have
multiple copies of the same code, you have multiple points of
maintenance.  The moment you find yourself writing the same thing
twoce, you should stop and ask yourself, "How can I make it so I only
have to write this once?"  Avoiding duplication is one of the
fundamental rules of good programming.

Carlos

From tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org  Tue Dec 30 19:37:47 2008

	a	<style> tag in the <head> section)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812301930120.6187@localhost.localdomain>
References: <495A947E.20502@comcast.net>
	<20081230235733.GH2408@sentinelchicken.org>

	<20081231005819.GI2408@sentinelchicken.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812301930120.6187@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20081231033747.GA2442@sentinelchicken.org>

Hi Carlos,

> Creating multiple copies of the same code is not good programming
> practice.  It is better to create a single template, and use
> programming logic to fill in the dynamic bits.  The moment you have
> multiple copies of the same code, you have multiple points of
> maintenance.  The moment you find yourself writing the same thing
> twoce, you should stop and ask yourself, "How can I make it so I only
> have to write this once?"  Avoiding duplication is one of the
> fundamental rules of good programming.

Well, yes, I agree, but there are limits to this.  You have 43 copies of
the letter 'a' in your last email.  Should you write a method for that?
This philosphy only goes so far.  I've seen many programs taken too far
in this direction with dozens of layers of abstraction which accomplish
nothing except make the code hard to read.  Note that I do security code
review for a living, so I see *lots* of other peoples' code.  You can't
account for every possible feature request that comes down the road, and
Murphy's law indicates the customer will pick the one you didn't think
of.  There needs to be a balance.

As far as style sheets go, they are already a major step toward
abstraction of page look & feel.  I haven't seen many sites that have
more than a couple of dozen styles, if that.  I'm no designer, but if
you get many more, I'd guess the site might start looking hideous.
Making them dynamic saves you what?  A few paragraphs of static data
that you can't as easily ask the browser to cache?

On the flip side, most programmers still haven't figured out how to
prevent cross-site scripting bugs when they include user-supplied data
in their pages.  There are indeed ways to inject script into style
sheets.  Are you allowing user-influenced data to get in there?  Why
take the risk?

tim

> Well, yes, I agree, but there are limits to this.  You have 43 copies of

> This philosphy only goes so far.  I've seen many programs taken too far

>
> As far as style sheets go, they are already a major step toward
> abstraction of page look & feel.  I haven't seen many sites that have
> more than a couple of dozen styles, if that.  I'm no designer, but if
> you get many more, I'd guess the site might start looking hideous.
> Making them dynamic saves you what?  A few paragraphs of static data
> that you can't as easily ask the browser to cache?
>

> prevent cross-site scripting bugs when they include user-supplied data
> in their pages.  There are indeed ways to inject script into style
> sheets.  Are you allowing user-influenced data to get in there?  Why
> take the risk?
>
> tim

Your letter A example doesn't apply.  This is human readable text,
whereas I was talking about computer code.  One is meant for a human
to read, while the other is meant for a computer.  These are two very
different audiences.  Computers can perform tokenization and
substitution very easily, while humans cannot.  Humans have a hard
time reading dry, repetitous text, while computers don't care.

But let's say for the sake of argument that this weren't a factor.
How could I write a function that would result in less typing than a
single character "A"?  I think a better example be replacing every
occurance of "Kafka" with "K", as Kafka himself did liberally.

A programmer should separate the static from the dynamic.  The static
becomes the template, and the dynamic becomes the raw data.  This is
what a lisp programmer does when writing a macro.  There is a thought
process that allows a programmer to turn segments of repeated code
into a single macro with arguments.  What goes into the body of the
macro, and what becomes the arguments?  Do the arguments consist of
arbitrary executable code?  Especially in the case of a lisp macro,
the answer is often "yes".  It's part of that whole "code that writes
code" thing.

Naturally one has to consider security.  I have heard it said that
security cannot be slapped on as an afterthought; it must be an
integral part of the design.  And certainly it cannot be ignored, for
human nature dictates that any piece of code can and will fall under
attack.  So let's rank security right alongside the other fundamentals
of computer science, as is its rightful place.

Are security and avoidance of code duplication mutually exclusive?  Of
course not, but there is some non-orthagonality there; one can affect
the other, so they must be balanced against one another.  There are
other factors that act upon the structure in the same way, for example
the finiteness of resources.  Having to balance forces that are at
odds with one another, some of which are imposed from the outside by
mischievous humans, is what makes programming an artform.

Since it is an artform, its aesthetic quality ought to be a goal in
its creation.  That's why I get bothered by code duplication; it seems
bereft of artistic sensibility.  I guess that's the truth of why I
take the soapbox and speak against it.  It's a romantic, idealist
point of view.  I don't expect many others to share it.  I don't see
many others sharing it in my day-to-day life at work.  Most people
think of software as a tool to get a job done, and nothing more.  As
long as it does its job, who cares if it is full of copy-and-paste
code, or if it has thousand-line if...then constructs?  Who would even
know?

Carlos

From tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org  Wed Dec 31 07:53:11 2008
From: tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org (Tim)
Date: Wed, 31 Dec 2008 07:53:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Website Programming Philosphy (was: External CSS vs in	a
	<style> tag in the <head> section)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0812302314150.6405@localhost.localdomain>
References: <495A947E.20502@comcast.net>
	<20081230235733.GH2408@sentinelchicken.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812301752320.6187@localhost.localdomain>
	<20081231005819.GI2408@sentinelchicken.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812301930120.6187@localhost.localdomain>
	<20081231033747.GA2442@sentinelchicken.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812302314150.6405@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20081231155311.GA2427@sentinelchicken.org>

Carlos,

> Your letter A example doesn't apply.  This is human readable text,
> whereas I was talking about computer code.  One is meant for a human
> to read, while the other is meant for a computer.  These are two very
> different audiences.  Computers can perform tokenization and
> substitution very easily, while humans cannot.  Humans have a hard
> time reading dry, repetitous text, while computers don't care.

I still think this analogy is a good one (if any are).  If you take code
reuse too far, you make your programs harder for humans (programmers) to
understand and don't actually save any literal lines of code.  By
writing a macro or something similar to print the letter a, and the
reference it 43 times, you'd have a similar effect where we'd have a
hard time reading it and it would only make your text bigger.


> A programmer should separate the static from the dynamic.  The static
> becomes the template, and the dynamic becomes the raw data.  This is
> what a lisp programmer does when writing a macro.  There is a thought
> process that allows a programmer to turn segments of repeated code
> into a single macro with arguments.  What goes into the body of the
> macro, and what becomes the arguments?  Do the arguments consist of
> arbitrary executable code?  Especially in the case of a lisp macro,
> the answer is often "yes".  It's part of that whole "code that writes
> code" thing.

Right.  Basically the way I see it is that styles are your macro and by
making them dynamic, you're dynamically generating your macros.  Next
will we dynamically generate server-side scripts which generate styles
which apply to pages?

Dynamically generated code (and to a lesser extent, macros) is a very
serious danger in a security context.  If you don't do it very
carefully, user-supplied input could find it's way in there and break
out of your syntax.  That often results in code execution in some
context.  Here are some examples:

  - JavaScript and HTML are essentially inseparable.  JavaScript is
    executable code (if in a sandbox most of the time) so this is how we
    ended up with most of the evils of cross-site scripting. We're
    forced to dynamically generate code because of the Web's poor
    design.  (/me glares at Netscape)

  - system() and popen().  Perhaps the most scary ones.  The command
    line *is* code after all.  Please never use these functions, as
    they're poorly designed even outside of the security implications.
    If you feel you have to use them, at least don't ever embed
    user-supplied values in the strings you pass off.

  - Ever thought of printf()-style format strings as code?  Most people
    don't, but if you allow user-supplied values to sneak into the
    templates themselves, an attacker can read/write arbitrary memory
    locations and execute code.

Anyway, so I hope you see why I don't think styles themselves should be
dynamically generated.

> Naturally one has to consider security.  I have heard it said that
> security cannot be slapped on as an afterthought; it must be an
> integral part of the design.  And certainly it cannot be ignored, for
> human nature dictates that any piece of code can and will fall under
> attack.  So let's rank security right alongside the other fundamentals
> of computer science, as is its rightful place.

Yes!  Secure coding principles desperately need to work their way into
university curricula.  I teach on-the-job training courses to
programmers off and on in order to help them improve the security of
their coding.  In conversations with students, I often ask if they had
seen any of the material in their undergrad courses.  It's very rare
that they do.  I hope some professors out there are reading this.  The
stuff I teach isn't rocket surgery.  It's really basic, "how to write
good code that happens to be secure" kinds of things.

> Are security and avoidance of code duplication mutually exclusive?  Of
> course not, but there is some non-orthagonality there; one can affect
> the other, so they must be balanced against one another.  There are
> other factors that act upon the structure in the same way, for example
> the finiteness of resources.  Having to balance forces that are at
> odds with one another, some of which are imposed from the outside by
> mischievous humans, is what makes programming an artform.

No, actually I think avoidance of code duplication, in most contexts, is
very beneficial to security.  Take the famous Code Red and Nimda worms.
One of the bugs they exploited was in IIS was a remote execution bug
which occurred due to poorly constructed repetition of URL validation
code.  Elimination of code duplication is very important for data
validation and encoding/decoding.

> Since it is an artform, its aesthetic quality ought to be a goal in
> its creation.  That's why I get bothered by code duplication; it seems
> bereft of artistic sensibility.  I guess that's the truth of why I
> take the soapbox and speak against it.  It's a romantic, idealist
> point of view.  I don't expect many others to share it.  I don't see
> many others sharing it in my day-to-day life at work.  Most people
> think of software as a tool to get a job done, and nothing more.  As
> long as it does its job, who cares if it is full of copy-and-paste
> code, or if it has thousand-line if...then constructs?  Who would even
> know?

Hey, I'm a card-carrying idealist too. =)  I think code should look
pretty too.  It's just that I've spent the last few years watching
programmers shoot themselves in the foot with respect to security and I
tend to ask "why do you need that gun anyway?".  Sure, I know guns don't
shoot people, people shoot people, but if you don't know how to work the
gun in the first place, maybe you shouldn't be packing.

regards,
tim

From david.fleck at mchsi.com  Wed Dec 31 08:50:29 2008
From: david.fleck at mchsi.com (David Fleck)
Date: Wed, 31 Dec 2008 10:50:29 -0600 (CST)
Subject: [PLUG] Hardware puzzle of the day - desktop won't boot
In-Reply-To: <da2207740809170711n2d62bb28t342c0ed5906933af@mail.gmail.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0809170807090.29169@grond.sourballs.org>
	<da2207740809170711n2d62bb28t342c0ed5906933af@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <alpine.LNX.1.10.0812311010580.2472@grond.sourballs.org>

Waaaay back in September, I sent mail describing a serious hardware 
failure (desktop machine totally non-responsive) and some efforts I made 
toward trying to fix it.  I also received cogent and generous advice from 
the mailing list, and in retrospect, the nugget of the solution was in 
there as well, but unfortunately it was overlooked until just recently. 
Since I described the problem here, for completeness I figure I should 
describe the cause and solution also.

To reiterate the problem:
> On Wed, Sep 17, 2008 at 6:27 AM, David Fleck <david.fleck at mchsi.com> wrote:
>> Seeking advice/opinions on the following situation:
>>
>> 6-year old homebuilt PC, ASUS motherboard, Athlon CPU, OpenSuSE 10.1 (not
>> that I think that part is relevant.)
>> About a week ago, I came downstairs and discovered the machine was off.
>> It was on when I left it the previous evening.
>> I pushded the button, and the fans whirred up. No other activity - no
>> POST, no HDD noise or lights.
>> I thought that maybe the power supply was bad, so I removed it and put it
>> into a spare machine (that didn't have a power supply). That machine
>> booted normally.
>> I put the power supply back into the sick machine, and unplugged all the
>> drives.  Same result - fans whir, no POST or HDD activity.
>> I removed the memory.  Same result - fans whir, no POST or HDD activity.
>> So now I am thinking it's the motherboard, and I order one of the only two
>> mobo's Newegg offers that still supports 462(A) socket processors, the PC
>> Chips M848A.  Wait for it to arrive....
>> It arrived yesterday. So I carefully disassembled my sick PC, put in the
>> new mobo, reassembled it, turned it on... and no change. Fans spin, no
>> POST, no HDD activity.
>> Take out the memory, disconnect the drives, restart - same behavior.
>> Swap in a pouer supply from my wife's machine - same behavior.
>> Remove the CPU - same behavior.

A number of suggestions came in, but unfortunately, they didn't spur me in 
the right direction (even though Rich Shepard hit upon the culprit in his 
response).  Instead, I wandered further off track:

>On Thu, 18 Sep 2008, David Fleck wrote:
>> The monitor works fine with other systems.  I tried pulling out all the 
>> daughtercards and rebooting, no change in behavior (fans whir, no 
>> lights or other activity, no video, no apparent checking for drives or
>> peripherals)
>> At this point, the only common factor I can come up with is the CPU, so
>> I'm going to take a chance on a $25.00 recycled Athlon chip and see if
>> that brings the system back to life.

Well, the 'new' chip didn't bring the system back to life either.  Not 
wanting to spend any more time or money on the whole project, I just 
switched over to a crappy backup machine for a while, and more recently 
was able to snag a bunch of semi-functional 3 - 4 year old machines that 
were being junked at work, and assemble them into one pretty good machine, 
better than the desktop that up and died on me.  I shelved the remains of 
the old desktop.

Just today, as I was doing some maintenance on my daughter's machine, I 
got it into my head to put one of her memory DIMMs into my stricken box. 
It booted up immediately.

Damn.

Rich Shepard had suggested new RAM, but I ignored that because I was 
convinced that the motherboard ought to respond, in some way - a beep, 
something - even without RAM.  It turns out that's not the case.  I was 
suspicious of the existing RAM, but foolishly assumed that the BIOS would 
respond differently when given bad RAM vs. no RAM.  Live and learn.

--
David Fleck
david.fleck at mchsi.com

This has been a great discussion.  Thank you so much for having it
with me.  It illustrates the point that programming is not an exact
science, even if many aspects of it appear to be.  Maybe that's why it
is still called a science.  When studying art (the violin, for
example), there is a lot that appears to be science-like.  Either a
note is in tune, or it is not.  Either the rhythm is accurate, or it
is not.  There is a whole system of math to describe the interplay of
tones, called Music Theory.  Yet something very real separates a
Heifetz performance from Zuckermann, even from the very first note.

You would like to see professors pay more attention to security
because they neglect the fact that it is a cornerstone of computer
science.  I would like to see corporate muckymucks understand that
programming is a creative art because they think that with enough
trendy methodology, they could get a monkey to write software.  These
sound completely unrelated, but I think we have shown that they are
two sides of the same coin.

What this discussion lacked is an example of a dynamically generated
stylesheet.  We really need to look at a specific example and decide
if it's sound or faulty.  I had one in my previous post, but then
deleted it, because it would have been far less entertaining.  Without
a specific example, the words "dynamic stylesheet" don't have enough
meaning to have a scientific discussion because there are infinite
variations on that theme.

Carlos


From vincent.leo.damewood at gmail.com  Wed Dec 31 08:58:43 2008
From: vincent.leo.damewood at gmail.com (Vincent L. Damewood)
Date: Wed, 31 Dec 2008 08:58:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] External CSS vs in a <style> tag in the <head> section
In-Reply-To: <495B9DA9.4050700@comcast.net>
References: <495A947E.20502@comcast.net>
	<25720.170.135.241.46.1230739546.squirrel@mail.jamhome.us>
	<495B9DA9.4050700@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <88b253560812310858w4ca86870q6a7bdcc73b546006@mail.gmail.com>

On Wed, Dec 31, 2008 at 8:28 AM, Richard C. Steffens <rsteff at comcast.net> wrote:
> The page is now published:
>
> http://home.comcast.net/~rsteff/Dec-2008/index.html
>
> When submitted to the validator:
>
> Result: 47 Errors, 5 warning(s)
>
> I've got some cleaning up to do!
>
> A number of the problems are from changing the concept from the
> thumbnails being links to having an onclick action. I missed getting rid
> of some of the </a> tags.
>
> Others are ones I'll have to read up on to learn what I did wrong.
>

I just tried validating your page, and it looks like you only have
three recurring syntax problems.

1: You're typing <img src="foo" alt="bar"> instead of <img src="foo"
alt="bar"/> This is okay in SGML-based HTML (Regular HTML), but
doesn't work in XML-based XHTML.

2: The </a> tags that you mentioned.

3: You have & where you need &amp;. This is another SGML/XML mismatch.
In XHTML you need to escape an ampersand, even if it's in an attribute
value or embedded Javascript and CSS. (So, there's a good reason to
take your CSS out of the head element).

Fix these issues and that should take care all but one of the errors.

Vincent Damewood

On Wed, Dec 31, 2008 at 9:32 AM, Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:
>> Rich Shepard had suggested new RAM, but I ignored that because I was
>> convinced that the motherboard ought to respond, in some way - a beep,
>> something - even without RAM.  It turns out that's not the case.  I was
>> suspicious of the existing RAM, but foolishly assumed that the BIOS would
>> respond differently when given bad RAM vs. no RAM.  Live and learn.
>>
>
> I think your assumption was entirely reasonable.  Given that the BIOS
> could temporarily use the cache RAM on the processor for stack, etc.,
> I'm surprised that the BIOS was unable to detect and report a problem
> with RAM.

Just a anecdote:

My recently assembled BYO system (AMD 780G chipset) wouldn't POST (no
beeps, but the chassis fans spun up) w/o being "powered on" for a few
minutes plus poking the reset button a few times. Finally found a
forum post describing some memory timing settings in the BIOS that
fixed it, specifically EPP mode off (not referring to the parallel
port, as far as I can tell) and "Set memory clock" to manual:

http://forums.anandtech.com/messageview.aspx?catid=29&threadid=2199171

Now it boots fine.

-- 
Dan Young


From creswick at gmail.com  Wed Dec 31 09:59:55 2008
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Wed, 31 Dec 2008 09:59:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Website Programming Philosphy (was: External CSS vs in a
	<style> tag in the <head> section)
In-Reply-To: <20081231155311.GA2427@sentinelchicken.org>
References: <495A947E.20502@comcast.net>
	<20081230235733.GH2408@sentinelchicken.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812301752320.6187@localhost.localdomain>
	<20081231005819.GI2408@sentinelchicken.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812301930120.6187@localhost.localdomain>
	<20081231033747.GA2442@sentinelchicken.org>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0812302314150.6405@localhost.localdomain>
	<20081231155311.GA2427@sentinelchicken.org>
Message-ID: <c834ec80812310959k1771b3c4ocd856ca6f1b46f80@mail.gmail.com>

On Wed, Dec 31, 2008 at 7:53 AM, Tim <tim-pdxlug at sentinelchicken.org> wrote:
>
> Anyway, so I hope you see why I don't think styles themselves should be
> dynamically generated.
>

First off, I think Tim makes a lot of very good points about why you
should not generate style information on raw (or nearly raw) user
input -- it's dangerous.  However, as Carlos points out, there are
just too many "flavors" of dynamic css to discuss them all as one
entity.

I find that CSS is a horrible language for expressing styles.  It
lacks a lot of things that other languages have to help programmers
find errors -- as was evidenced by our collective inability to find
the syntax error that was causing Richard's problem in the first
place.  That leads to one argument in favor of generating css from
some other format that provides better static analysis, things like
variables (or constants, anyway) and other abstractions that help
maintain consistency across a design.  It would also be nice to have a
cleaner way to generate styles for various browsers (so you don't
*have* to use bizzare parsing bugs in IE 6 to make it ignore all the
w3c valid code that would break the layout otherwise, or to tweak the
fonts...)

Note that each chunk of css may be essentially fixed at runtime, and
your webserver just selects the correct collections of info based on
run-time information (eg: browser type, or the page you're looking
at..).  I think this would be more easily done if the stylesheets were
referenced as separate "files", vs. being included in-line.

Anyway, I'm also a novice web developer (with only a couple years of
work with css / flow-based layouts) but I've had enough exposure to
css to know that it could be greatly improved.  One way to do so is
with a preprocessor.

--Rogan


>> Naturally one has to consider security.  I have heard it said that
>> security cannot be slapped on as an afterthought; it must be an
>> integral part of the design.  And certainly it cannot be ignored, for
>> human nature dictates that any piece of code can and will fall under
>> attack.  So let's rank security right alongside the other fundamentals
>> of computer science, as is its rightful place.
>
> Yes!  Secure coding principles desperately need to work their way into
> university curricula.  I teach on-the-job training courses to
> programmers off and on in order to help them improve the security of
> their coding.  In conversations with students, I often ask if they had
> seen any of the material in their undergrad courses.  It's very rare
> that they do.  I hope some professors out there are reading this.  The
> stuff I teach isn't rocket surgery.  It's really basic, "how to write
> good code that happens to be secure" kinds of things.
>
>> Are security and avoidance of code duplication mutually exclusive?  Of
>> course not, but there is some non-orthagonality there; one can affect
>> the other, so they must be balanced against one another.  There are
>> other factors that act upon the structure in the same way, for example
>> the finiteness of resources.  Having to balance forces that are at
>> odds with one another, some of which are imposed from the outside by
>> mischievous humans, is what makes programming an artform.
>
> No, actually I think avoidance of code duplication, in most contexts, is
> very beneficial to security.  Take the famous Code Red and Nimda worms.
> One of the bugs they exploited was in IIS was a remote execution bug
> which occurred due to poorly constructed repetition of URL validation
> code.  Elimination of code duplication is very important for data
> validation and encoding/decoding.
>
>> Since it is an artform, its aesthetic quality ought to be a goal in
>> its creation.  That's why I get bothered by code duplication; it seems
>> bereft of artistic sensibility.  I guess that's the truth of why I
>> take the soapbox and speak against it.  It's a romantic, idealist
>> point of view.  I don't expect many others to share it.  I don't see
>> many others sharing it in my day-to-day life at work.  Most people
>> think of software as a tool to get a job done, and nothing more.  As
>> long as it does its job, who cares if it is full of copy-and-paste
>> code, or if it has thousand-line if...then constructs?  Who would even
>> know?
>
> Hey, I'm a card-carrying idealist too. =)  I think code should look
> pretty too.  It's just that I've spent the last few years watching
> programmers shoot themselves in the foot with respect to security and I
> tend to ask "why do you need that gun anyway?".  Sure, I know guns don't
> shoot people, people shoot people, but if you don't know how to work the
> gun in the first place, maybe you shouldn't be packing.
>
> regards,

References: <495A947E.20502@comcast.net>	<25720.170.135.241.46.1230739546.squirrel@mail.jamhome.us>	<495B9DA9.4050700@comcast.net>

Message-ID: <495BB557.8060308@comcast.net>

Vincent L. Damewood wrote:
> I just tried validating your page, and it looks like you only have
> three recurring syntax problems.
>
> 1: You're typing <img src="foo" alt="bar"> instead of <img src="foo"
> alt="bar"/> This is okay in SGML-based HTML (Regular HTML), but
> doesn't work in XML-based XHTML.
>   

Aha! I knew about <br /> but didn't make the leap of understanding to 
realize that <img ... > needed to be <img ... />. Thanks!

> 2: The </a> tags that you mentioned.
>   

Yep. Got them.

> 3: You have & where you need &amp;. This is another SGML/XML mismatch.
> In XHTML you need to escape an ampersand, even if it's in an attribute
> value or embedded Javascript and CSS. (So, there's a good reason to
> take your CSS out of the head element).
>   

I didn't pay attention to the little voice in my head that said I should 
do that. Got that one, too. Thanks.

> Fix these issues and that should take care all but one of the errors.
>   
More than one, actually. I neglected to include:

    <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />

And I was using transitional technique in a strict setting with:

    <script language="Javascript">

For strict, you need:

    <script type="text/javascript">

The "language" part is not used in strict, and it must all be lower case.

That validator is good for validating, debugging, and teaching. I'll 
make greater use of it from now on.

On Wed, Dec 31, 2008 at 10:09 AM, Richard C. Steffens
<rsteff at comcast.net> wrote:
>> 1: You're typing <img src="foo" alt="bar"> instead of <img src="foo"
>> alt="bar"/> This is okay in SGML-based HTML (Regular HTML), but
>> doesn't work in XML-based XHTML.
>>
>
> Aha! I knew about <br /> but didn't make the leap of understanding to
> realize that <img ... > needed to be <img ... />. Thanks!

This applies to any tag that doesn't have a corresponding closing tag.
In XML all elements have to be closed (that's why you always need a
</p> for each <p>). This piece of syntax creates a single tag that
both opens and closes the element. So, <foo/> is parsed the same way
as <foo></foo>.

>> Fix these issues and that should take care all but one of the errors.
>>
> More than one, actually. I neglected to include:
>
>    <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />

I figured that was just a warning, so I didn't count it.

> And I was using transitional technique in a strict setting with:
>
>    <script language="Javascript">
>
> For strict, you need:
>
>    <script type="text/javascript">
>
> The "language" part is not used in strict, and it must all be lower case.

And I figured you'd get that one without help. So, back to the
original issue. Is your stylesheet working properly?

Vincent Damewood

Message-ID: <20081231184101.057e4dc2.johnxj@comcast.net>

I don't know the answer. But I do know that someone has figured it out.

http://www.btscene.com/details/881376/

Using Firefrox, with popup blocker enabled, click on just about
anything on that page. You will be treated to a full-screen popup
window advertising hot girls. Why they thought someone searching for a
Gernsheim symphony would be interested in hot girls escapes me.

I find this on more and more sites. Searching the Firefox forums I find
that it is being treated as a bug in the popup blocker.

So if you're creating a website and you want to annoy the hell out of
your visitors, apparently there is now a way.

As hinted at above.
'the root directory' is not the same as /root
the root directory is /
/root is the ~/ or home for the root user
